text: Pancakes
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: 1 cup all-purpose flour
label: BODY

text: 2 tablespoons sugar
label: BODY

text: 1 teaspoon baking powder
label: BODY

text: 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
label: BODY

text: 1/4 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: 1 cup buttermilk
label: BODY

text: 1 large egg
label: BODY

text: 2 tablespoons melted butter
label: BODY

text: 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: In a bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
label: BODY

text: In another bowl, combine buttermilk, egg, melted butter, and vanilla extract.
label: BODY

text: Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir until just combined.
label: BODY

text: Heat a non-stick skillet over medium heat and lightly grease it.
label: BODY

text: Pour 1/4 cup of batter onto the skillet for each pancake.
label: BODY

text: Cook until bubbles form on the surface, then flip and cook until golden brown.
label: BODY

text: Serve with syrup and your favorite toppings.
label: BODY

text: Scrambled Eggs
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: 4 large eggs
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup milk
label: BODY

text: Salt and pepper to taste
label: BODY

text: 1 tablespoon butter
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: In a bowl, whisk together eggs, milk, salt, and pepper.
label: BODY

text: Heat a non-stick skillet over medium heat and melt the butter.
label: BODY

text: Pour the egg mixture into the skillet.
label: BODY

text: Cook, stirring gently, until the eggs are set but still soft.
label: BODY

text: Serve immediately.
label: BODY

text: Serve with syrup and powdered sugar.

text: In a large pot, heat vegetable oil over medium heat.
label: BODY

text: Cook diced onion, minced garlic, and grated ginger until fragrant.
label: BODY

text: Add cubed lamb and cook until browned.
label: BODY

text: Stir in diced tomatoes, coconut milk, curry powder, cumin, coriander, turmeric, garam
label: BODY

text: masala, salt, and pepper.
label: BODY

text: Bring to a simmer and cook for 1 hour until lamb is tender.
label: BODY

text: Garnish with chopped cilantro and serve.
label: BODY

text: Lemon Herb Salmon
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: 4 salmon fillets
label: BODY

text: 1 lemon, sliced
label: BODY

text: 2 cloves garlic, minced
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: 1 tablespoon fresh dill, chopped
label: BODY

text: 1 tablespoon fresh parsley, chopped
label: BODY

text: Salt and pepper to taste
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
label: BODY

text: Place salmon fillets on a baking sheet.
label: BODY

text: In a bowl, mix minced garlic, olive oil, chopped dill, chopped parsley, salt, and pepper.
label: BODY

text: Brush the mixture over the salmon fillets.
label: BODY

text: Top each fillet with lemon slices.
label: BODY

text: Bake for 15-20 minutes until salmon is cooked through.
label: BODY

text: Serve warm.
label: BODY

text: Meatloaf
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: 1 pound ground beef
label: BODY

text: 1/2 pound ground pork
label: BODY

text: 1 small onion, diced
label: BODY

text: 2 cloves garlic, minced
label: BODY

text: 1/2 cup breadcrumbs
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup milk
label: BODY

text: 1 egg, beaten
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup ketchup
label: BODY

text: 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce
label: BODY

text: 1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: 1/2 teaspoon pepper
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
label: BODY

text: In a large bowl, mix ground beef, ground pork, diced onion, minced garlic, breadcrumbs,
label: BODY

text: milk, beaten egg, ketchup, Worcestershire sauce, salt, and pepper.
label: BODY

text: Shape the mixture into a loaf and place in a baking dish.
label: BODY

text: Bake for 1 hour until cooked through.
label: BODY

text: Let rest before slicing and serving.
label: BODY

text: Paella
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: 1/2 pound chicken breast, cubed
label: BODY

text: 1/2 pound shrimp, peeled and deveined
label: BODY

text: 1/2 pound mussels, cleaned
label: BODY

text: 1 small onion, diced
label: BODY

text: 2 cloves garlic, minced
label: BODY

text: 1 bell pepper, diced
label: BODY

text: 1 cup short-grain rice
label: BODY

text: 2 cups chicken broth
label: BODY

text: 1/2 cup white wine
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: 1 teaspoon saffron
label: BODY

text: 1 teaspoon paprika
label: BODY

text: Salt and pepper to taste
label: BODY

text: Lemon wedges for garnish
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: In a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat.
label: BODY

text: Cook cubed chicken until browned, then set aside.
label: BODY

text: In the same skillet, sauté diced onion, minced garlic, and diced bell pepper until
label: BODY

text: softened.
label: BODY

text: Stir in rice, chicken broth, white wine, saffron, paprika, salt, and pepper.
label: BODY

text: Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes.
label: BODY

text: Add shrimp, mussels, and cooked chicken, simmer for an additional 10 minutes until
label: BODY

text: seafood is cooked and rice is tender.
label: BODY

text: Garnish with lemon wedges and serve.
label: BODY

text: Pork Chops with Apples
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: 4 pork chops
label: BODY

text: 2 apples, sliced
label: BODY

text: 1 small onion, sliced
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup apple cider
label: BODY

text: 1/4 cup chicken broth
label: BODY

text: 2 tablespoons butter
label: BODY

text: 1 tablespoon olive oil
label: BODY

text: 1 teaspoon thyme
label: BODY

text: Salt and pepper to taste
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: Season pork chops with salt and pepper.
label: BODY

text: In a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat.
label: BODY

text: Cook pork chops until browned on both sides, then set aside.
label: BODY

text: In the same skillet, melt butter and sauté sliced onion and apples until softened.
label: BODY

text: Stir in apple cider, chicken broth, and thyme.
label: BODY

text: Return pork chops to the skillet and simmer for 10 minutes until cooked through.
label: BODY

text: Serve warm.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Batbout
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 1/4 teaspoons active dry yeast
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oDissolve yeast and sugar in warm water, let sit until foamy.
label: BODY

text: oMix flour and salt in a bowl, then add yeast mixture and olive oil.
label: BODY

text: oKnead until smooth, then let rise until doubled.
label: BODY

text: oDivide dough into balls and roll out into circles.
label: BODY

text: oCook on a hot griddle until puffed and golden.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.

label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oPreheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
label: BODY

text: oRoast eggplants, bell peppers, tomatoes, and onion until tender.
label: BODY

text: oPeel and slice vegetables.
label: BODY

text: oArrange on a plate and drizzle with olive oil.
label: BODY

text: oSprinkle with salt and serve warm or at room temperature.
label: BODY

text: Falafel
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 can chickpeas
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup parsley
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon cumin
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon coriander
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup flour
label: BODY

text: oOil for frying
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oDrain and rinse chickpeas.
label: BODY

text: oBlend chickpeas, diced onion, minced garlic, chopped parsley, cumin, coriander,
label: BODY

text: and salt in a food processor.
label: BODY

text: oAdd flour and mix until combined.
label: BODY

text: oForm mixture into balls and fry in hot oil until golden.
label: BODY

text: oDrain on paper towels and serve.
label: BODY

text: Farofa
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cups cassava flour
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup butter
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup bacon
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup parsley
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oSauté diced bacon, onion, and minced garlic in butter until crispy.
label: BODY

text: oAdd cassava flour and cook, stirring constantly, until golden.
label: BODY

text: oStir in chopped parsley and salt.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Fattoush
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 pita breads
label: BODY

text: o4 tomatoes
label: BODY

text: o1 cucumber
label: BODY

text: o1 small red onion
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup parsley
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup mint
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup lemon juice
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon sumac
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oToast pita breads until crispy, then break into pieces.
label: BODY

text: oDice tomatoes and cucumber, slice red onion.
label: BODY

text: oMix vegetables with chopped parsley and mint.
label: BODY

text: oWhisk lemon juice, olive oil, sumac, and salt, then pour over salad.
label: BODY

text: oToss well and serve.
label: BODY

text: Fava
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 cup yellow split peas
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup lemon juice
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oRinse split peas and cook in water until tender.
label: BODY

text: oSauté diced onion and minced garlic in olive oil until softened.
label: BODY

text: oBlend cooked peas with onion, garlic, lemon juice, and salt until smooth.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm or chilled.
label: BODY

text: Feijão Tropeiro
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cups cooked beans
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup bacon
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup cassava flour
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup parsley
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oSauté diced bacon, onion, and minced garlic until crispy.
label: BODY

text: oAdd cooked beans and cassava flour, stir to combine.
label: BODY

text: oStir in chopped parsley and salt.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Festival
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cups flour
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup cornmeal
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup sugar
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon baking powder
label: BODY

text: o1/2 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup milk
label: BODY

text: oOil for frying
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oMix flour, cornmeal, sugar, baking powder, and salt in a bowl.
label: BODY

text: oAdd milk and stir until dough forms.
label: BODY

text: oRoll out dough and cut into strips.
label: BODY

text: oFry in hot oil until golden.
label: BODY

text: oDrain on paper towels and serve warm.
label: BODY

text: Focaccia
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 1/4 teaspoons active dry yeast
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon sugar
label: BODY

text: o1 cup warm water
label: BODY

text: o2 1/2 cups flour
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: oRosemary
label: BODY

text: oSea salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oDissolve yeast and sugar in warm water, let sit until foamy.
label: BODY

text: oMix flour and salt in a bowl, then add yeast mixture and olive oil.
label: BODY

text: oKnead until smooth, then let rise until doubled.
label: BODY

text: oPress dough into a baking pan, dimple with fingers, and sprinkle with rosemary
label: BODY

text: and sea salt.
label: BODY

text: oBake at 400°F (200°C) for 20-25 minutes until golden.
label: BODY

text: Freekeh Salad
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 cup freekeh
label: BODY

text: o2 cups water
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup parsley
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup mint
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup lemon juice
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oRinse freekeh and cook in water until tender, then drain.
label: BODY

text: oSauté diced onion in olive oil until softened.
label: BODY

text: oMix freekeh with sautéed onion, chopped parsley, and mint.
label: BODY

text: oWhisk lemon juice, olive oil, and salt, then pour over salad.
label: BODY

text: oToss well and serve.
label: BODY

text: Fried Plantains
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 ripe plantains
label: BODY

text: o1 cup vegetable oil
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oPeel and slice plantains.
label: BODY

text: oHeat oil in a pan and fry plantain slices until golden.
label: BODY

text: oDrain on paper towels and sprinkle with salt.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Fried Rice
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cups cooked rice
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup peas
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup diced carrots
label: BODY

text: o2 eggs
label: BODY

text: o2 tablespoons soy sauce
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon sesame oil
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup chopped green onions
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oSauté diced onion, peas, and carrots in sesame oil until softened.
label: BODY

text: oPush vegetables to the side and scramble eggs in the same pan.
label: BODY

text: oAdd cooked rice and soy sauce, stir to combine.
label: BODY

text: oCook until heated through.
label: BODY

text: oGarnish with chopped green onions and serve.
label: BODY

text: Fufu
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cups cassava flour
label: BODY

text: o4 cups water
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oBring water to a boil.
label: BODY

text: oGradually add cassava flour, stirring constantly until thickened.
label: BODY

text: oContinue to cook, stirring, until smooth and elastic.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Gamja Jorim
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o4 potatoes
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup soy sauce
label: BODY

text: o2 tablespoons sugar
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon sesame oil
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup water
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon sesame seeds
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oPeel and dice potatoes.
label: BODY

text: oSauté potatoes in sesame oil until lightly browned.
label: BODY

text: oAdd soy sauce, sugar, and water, simmer until potatoes are tender.
label: BODY

text: oGarnish with sesame seeds and serve warm.
label: BODY

text: Garlic Bread
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 baguette
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup butter
label: BODY

text: o4 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup parsley
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oPreheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
label: BODY

text: oSlice baguette in half lengthwise.
label: BODY

text: oMix softened butter with minced garlic, chopped parsley, and salt.
label: BODY

text: oSpread mixture on bread.
label: BODY

text: oBake for 10-15 minutes until golden.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Gazpacho
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o4 tomatoes
label: BODY

text: o1 cucumber
label: BODY

text: o1 small red onion
label: BODY

text: o1 bell pepper
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o2 tablespoons red wine vinegar
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/2 teaspoon pepper
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oDice tomatoes, cucumber, onion, and bell pepper.
label: BODY

text: oBlend vegetables with minced garlic, olive oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper until
label: BODY

text: smooth.
label: BODY

text: oChill for at least 1 hour before serving.
label: BODY

text: Gigantes Plaki
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cups giant beans
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o4 tomatoes
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon oregano
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/2 teaspoon pepper
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oSoak beans overnight, then cook until tender.
label: BODY

text: oSauté diced onion and minced garlic in olive oil until softened.
label: BODY

text: oAdd diced tomatoes, oregano, salt, and pepper, simmer for 10 minutes.
label: BODY

text: oMix beans with tomato sauce and transfer to a baking dish.
label: BODY

text: oBake at 375°F (190°C) for 30 minutes.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Goi Cuon (Spring Rolls)
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 package rice paper wrappers
label: BODY

text: o1/2 pound shrimp
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup rice vermicelli
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup lettuce
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup mint
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup cilantro
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup basil
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup carrots
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup cucumber
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oCook shrimp and slice in half.
label: BODY

text: oCook rice vermicelli according to package instructions, then drain.
label: BODY

text: oSoak rice paper wrappers in warm water until pliable.
label: BODY

text: oPlace a small amount of shrimp, vermicelli, lettuce, mint, cilantro, basil, julienned
label: BODY

text: carrots, and cucumber on each wrapper.
label: BODY

text: oRoll tightly and serve with dipping sauce.
label: BODY

text: Gomae (Spinach with Sesame Dressing)
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 bunch spinach
label: BODY

text: o2 tablespoons sesame seeds
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon soy sauce
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon sugar
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon mirin
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oBlanch spinach in boiling water, then rinse in cold water and squeeze out excess
label: BODY

text: moisture.
label: BODY

text: oToast sesame seeds and grind them.
label: BODY

text: oMix sesame seeds with soy sauce, sugar, and mirin.
label: BODY

text: oToss spinach with dressing and serve.
label: BODY

text: Gratin Dauphinois
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o4 potatoes
label: BODY

text: o1 cup heavy cream
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup milk
label: BODY

text: o2 cloves garlic
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup grated Gruyère cheese
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/2 teaspoon pepper
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oPreheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
label: BODY

text: oPeel and thinly slice potatoes.
label: BODY

text: oRub a baking dish with a cut clove of garlic.
label: BODY

text: oLayer potatoes in the dish, seasoning with salt and pepper.
label: BODY

text: oMix cream, milk, and minced garlic, pour over potatoes.
label: BODY

text: oSprinkle with grated Gruyère cheese.
label: BODY

text: oBake for 45 minutes until golden and bubbly.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Greek Salad
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o4 tomatoes
label: BODY

text: o1 cucumber
label: BODY

text: o1 small red onion
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olives
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup feta cheese
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup olive oil
label: BODY

text: o2 tablespoons red wine vinegar
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon oregano
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oDice tomatoes and cucumber, slice red onion.
label: BODY

text: oMix vegetables with olives and crumbled feta cheese.
label: BODY

text: oWhisk olive oil, vinegar, oregano, and salt, then pour over salad.
label: BODY

text: oToss well and serve.
label: BODY

text: Green Bean Casserole
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o4 cups green beans
label: BODY

text: o1 can cream of mushroom soup
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup milk
label: BODY

text: o1 cup fried onions
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/2 teaspoon pepper
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oPreheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
label: BODY

text: oCook green beans until tender.
label: BODY

text: oMix soup, milk, salt, and pepper in a baking dish.
label: BODY

text: oAdd green beans and half of the fried onions, stir to combine.
label: BODY

text: oBake for 25 minutes.
label: BODY

text: oTop with remaining fried onions and bake for an additional 5 minutes.
label: BODY

text: oServe warm.
label: BODY

text: Guacamole
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o3 avocados
label: BODY

text: o1 lime
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: o2 tomatoes
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon chopped cilantro
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon minced garlic
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oCut avocados in half, remove the pit, and scoop out the flesh into a bowl.
label: BODY

text: oMash the avocados with a fork.
label: BODY

text: oAdd lime juice, diced onion, chopped tomatoes, salt, cilantro, and garlic.
label: BODY

text: oMix well and serve immediately.
label: BODY

text: Gurkensalat (Cucumber Salad)
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o2 cucumbers
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup sour cream
label: BODY

text: o2 tablespoons vinegar
label: BODY

text: o1 tablespoon sugar
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon dill
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oSlice cucumbers thinly.
label: BODY

text: oMix sour cream, vinegar, sugar, dill, and salt in a bowl.
label: BODY

text: oToss cucumbers with the dressing.
label: BODY

text: oServe chilled.
label: BODY

text: Gyeran Jjim
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o4 eggs
label: BODY

text: o1 cup water
label: BODY

text: o1/4 cup green onions
label: BODY

text: o1 teaspoon salt
label: BODY

text: o1/2 teaspoon sesame oil
label: BODY

text: Instructions:
label: BODY

text: oBeat eggs with water, salt, and chopped green onions.
label: BODY

text: oPour mixture into a heatproof bowl.
label: BODY

text: oSteam for 10-15 minutes until set.
label: BODY

text: oDrizzle with sesame oil and serve warm.
label: BODY

text: Harira
label: H1

text: Ingredients:
label: BODY

text: o1 cup lentils
label: BODY

text: o1/2 cup chickpeas
label: BODY

text: o1 small onion
label: BODY

text: Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester
label: BODY

text: Qualifications Board
label: BODY

text: 1. Introduction to the Foundation Level Extensions
label: H1

text: This overview document is intended for anyone with an interest in the ISTQB Foundation Level
label: BODY

text: Extensions who wants a high-level introduction to the leading principles and an overview of the individual
label: BODY

text: extension syllabi.
label: BODY

text: From time to time, ISTQB will update this document to reflect any additional extensions that shall be
label: BODY

text: introduced for the Foundation Level, or to reflect major changes in existing ones. Publications of the
label: BODY

text: updated document will be available on the ISTQB website.
label: BODY

text: The ISTQB Foundation and Advanced Level syllabi have been defined and have been on the market for
label: BODY

text: some time. New topics emerge due to technology and methodology changes in the market which often
label: BODY

text: are brought into the ISTQB program as new Expert Level syllabi. However, not all topics are suited for the
label: BODY

text: Expert Level. For this reason, the extension syllabi are established at the Foundation Level to expand the
label: BODY

text: ISTQB program to incorporate new or updated knowledge. New extensions shall be discussed and
label: BODY

text: introduced by the ISTQB periodically. Extensions may be established at the Advanced Level as well, but
label: BODY

text: that is beyond the scope of this document.
label: BODY

text: The following Foundation Level Extension syllabus has been released:
label: BODY

text: Agile Tester
label: BODY

text: In this document, each Foundation Level Extension syllabus is summarized and the associated Business
label: BODY

text: Outcomes are stated. The Business Outcomes communicate what can be expected from a person who
label: BODY

text: achieves a Foundation Level Extension Certification in a particular subject area (e.g., Agile Tester), and
label: BODY

text: will outline the benefits for companies that are considering the development of specific testing skills at this
label: BODY

text: level.
label: BODY

text: Version 2014 Page 6 of 12 May 31, 2014
label: BODY

text: Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester
label: BODY

text: Qualifications Board
label: BODY

text: 2. Introduction to Foundation Level Agile Tester Extension
label: H1

text: The certification for Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester is designed for professionals who are
label: BODY

text: working within Agile environments. It is also for professionals who are planning to start implementing
label: BODY

text: Agile methods in the near future, or are working within companies that plan to do so, The certification
label: BODY

text: provides an advantage for those who would like to know the required Agile activities, roles, methods, and
label: BODY

text: methodologies specific to their role.
label: BODY

text: 2.1 Intended Audience
label: H2

text: The Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester qualification is aimed at four main groups of professionals:
label: BODY

text: 1. Professionals who have achieved in-depth testing experience in traditional methods and would
label: BODY

text: like to get an Agile Tester Certificate.
label: BODY

text: 2. Junior professional testers who are just starting in the testing profession, have received the
label: BODY

text: Foundation Level certificate, and would like to know more aboutthetester’srole in an Agile
label: BODY

text: environment.
label: BODY

text: 3. Professionals who are relatively new to testing and are required to implement test approaches,
label: BODY

text: methods and techniques in their day to day job in Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: 4. Professionals who are experienced in their role (including unit testing) and need more
label: BODY

text: understanding and knowledge about how to perform and manage testing on all levels in Agile
label: BODY

text: projects.
label: BODY

text: These professionals include people who are in roles such as testers, test analysts, test engineers, test
label: BODY

text: consultants, test managers, user acceptance testers, and software developers.
label: BODY

text: This Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester certification may also be appropriate for anyone who
label: BODY

text: wants a deeper understanding of software testing in the Agile world, such as project managers, quality
label: BODY

text: managers, software development managers, business analysts, IT directors, and management
label: BODY

text: consultants.
label: BODY

text: 2.2 Career Paths for Testers
label: H2

text: Building on the Foundation Level, the Agile Tester Extension supports the definition of career paths for
label: BODY

text: professional testers. A person with the Agile Tester certificate has extended the broad understanding of
label: BODY

text: testing acquired at the Foundation Level to enable him or her to work effectively as a professional tester in
label: BODY

text: an Agile project.
label: BODY

text: People possessing an ISTQB Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester certificate may use the Certified
label: BODY

text: Tester Foundation Level acronym CTFL-AT.
label: BODY

text: 2.3 Learning Objectives
label: H2

text: In general, the Foundation Level syllabus is examinable at a K1 level, i.e., the candidate will recognize,
label: BODY

text: remember and recall terms and concepts stated in the Foundation Level syllabus.
label: BODY

text: In addition, all Foundation Level syllabus learning objectives are examinable at the same K- level in an
label: BODY

text: extension exam.
label: BODY

text: Version 2014 Page 7 of 12 May 31, 2014
label: BODY

text: Qualifications Board
label: BODY

text: That said, each extension level exam focuses on the learning objectives defined in that extension
label: BODY

text: syllabus. The relevant learning objectives at K1, K2, and K3 levels are provided at the beginning of each
label: BODY

text: chapter within each particular extension syllabus.
label: BODY

text: 2.4 Entry Requirements
label: H2

text: To be able to participate in a Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester exam, candidates must have
label: BODY

text: obtained the ISTQB Foundation Level certificate.
label: BODY

text: 2.5 Structure and Course Duration
label: H2

text: The Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester syllabus has no shared or common elements with the
label: BODY

text: Foundation Level syllabus.
label: BODY

text: The syllabi must be taught in the following minimum number of days:
label: BODY

text: Syllabus Days
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2.6 Keeping It Current
label: H2

text: The software industry changes rapidly. To deal with these changes and to provide the stakeholders with
label: BODY

text: access to relevant and current information, the ISTQB working groups have created links on the
label: BODY

text: www.istqb.org web site which refer to supporting documents, changes to standards and new occurrences
label: BODY

text: in the industry. This information is not examinable under this syllabus.
label: BODY

text: 3. Overview of the Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester
label: BODY

text: Syllabus
label: BODY

text: 3.1 Business Outcomes
label: H2

text: This section lists the Business Outcomes expected of a candidate who has achieved the Foundation Level
label: BODY

text: Extension –Agile Tester certification.
label: BODY

text: An Agile Tester can…
label: BODY

text: AFM1 Collaborate in a cross-functional Agile team being familiar with principles and basic
label: BODY

text: practices of Agile software development.
label: BODY

text: AFM2 Adapt existing testing experience and knowledge to Agile values and principles.
label: BODY

text: AFM3 Support the Agile team in planning test-related activities.
label: BODY

text: AFM4 Apply relevant methods and techniques for testing in an Agile project.
label: BODY

text: AFM5 Assist the Agile team in test automation activities.
label: BODY

text: AFM6 Assist business stakeholders in defining understandable and testable user stories,
label: BODY

text: scenarios, requirements and acceptance criteria as appropriate.
label: BODY

text: AFM7 Work and share information with other team members using effective communication
label: BODY

text: styles and channels.
label: BODY

text: In general, a Certified Tester Foundation Level –Agile Tester is expected to have acquired the necessary
label: BODY

text: skills to working effectively within an Agile team and environment.
label: BODY

text: 3.2 Content
label: H2

text: Chapter 1: Agile Software Development
label: BODY

text: The tester should remember the basic concept of Agile software development based on the Agile
label: BODY

text: Manifesto.
label: BODY

text: The tester should understand the advantages of the whole-team approach and the benefits of
label: BODY

text: early and frequent feedback.
label: BODY

text: The tester should recall Agile software development approaches.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to write testable user stories in collaboration with developers and
label: BODY

text: business representatives.
label: BODY

text: The tester should understand how retrospectives can be used as a mechanism for process
label: BODY

text: improvement in Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: The tester should understand the use and purpose of continuous integration.
label: BODY

text: The tester should know the differences between iteration and release planning, and how a tester
label: BODY

text: adds value in each of these activities.
label: BODY

text: Version 2014 Page 10 of 12 May 31, 2014
label: BODY

text: © International Software Testing Qualifications Board
label: BODY

text: International
label: BODY

text: Overview
label: BODY

text: Software Testing
label: BODY

text: Foundation Level Extension –Agile Tester
label: BODY

text: Qualifications Board
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2: Fundamental Agile Testing Principles, Practices, and Processes
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to describe the differences between testing activities in Agile projects
label: BODY

text: and non-Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to describe how development and testing activities are integrated in
label: BODY

text: Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to describe the role of independent testing in Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to describe the tools and techniques used to communicate the status of
label: BODY

text: testing in an Agile project, including test progress and product quality.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to describe the process of evolving tests across multiple iterations and
label: BODY

text: explain why test automation is important to manage regression risk in Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: The tester should understand the skills (people, domain, and testing) of a tester in an Agile team.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to understand the role of a tester within an Agile team.
label: BODY

text: Chapter 3: Agile Testing Methods, Techniques, and Tools
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to recall the concepts of test-driven development, acceptance test-
label: BODY

text: driven development, and behavior-driven development.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to recall the concepts of the test pyramid.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to summarize the testing quadrants and their relationships with testing
label: BODY

text: levels and testing types.
label: BODY

text: For a given Agile project, the tester should be able to work as a tester in a Scrum team.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to assess quality risks within an Agile project.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to estimate testing effort based on iteration content and quality risks.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to interpret relevant information to support testing activities.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to explain to business stakeholders how to define testable acceptance
label: BODY

text: criteria.
label: BODY

text: Given a user story, the tester should be able to write acceptance test-driven development test
label: BODY

text: cases.
label: BODY

text: For both functional and non-functional behavior, the tester should be able to write test cases using
label: BODY

text: black box test design techniques based on given user stories.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to perform exploratory testing to support the testing of an Agile project.
label: BODY

text: The tester should be able to recall different tools available to testers according to their purpose
label: BODY

text: and to activities in Agile projects.
label: BODY

text: Ontario’s Libraries
label: BODY

text: Working T ogether
label: BODY

text: RFP: R RFP: R RFP: R RFP: Re equest f quest f quest f quest fo or Pr r Pr r Pr r Proposal oposal oposal oposal
label: BODY

text: o Present a Proposal for Developing
label: BODY

text: the Business Plan for the Ontario
label: BODY

text: Digital Library
label: BODY

text: March 21, 2003
label: BODY

text: The Ontario Digital Library will make Ontario a better place to study, work and live by ensuring that
label: BODY

text: all Ontario citizens have access to the knowledge and learning supports needed to be life-long
label: BODY

text: learners and effective contributors towards Ontario’s prosperity.
label: BODY

text: Ontario’s Digital Library
label: H1

text: A Critical Component for Implementing Ontario’s Road Map to
label: BODY

text: Prosperity Strategy
label: BODY

text: Summary
label: H2

text: The purpose of this Request for Proposal (RFP) is to invite firms and/or consultants to
label: BODY

text: present a proposal for developing the business plan for the Ontario Digital Library (ODL).
label: BODY

text: The ODL will deliver high-quality library electronic content to all Ontario residents in order to
label: BODY

text: assist people as they learn, work, and enhance their quality of life. The business plan to be
label: BODY

text: developed is to document and clearly communicate:
label: BODY

text: how the ODL will be implemented, including the timeline
label: BODY

text: the financial plan for the implementation
label: BODY

text: the financial plan for the first 2 operating years, including capital and operating costs,
label: BODY

text: revenues, etc.
label: BODY

text: a financial forecast for the succeeding 2 operating years
label: BODY

text: the services and products to be delivered by the ODL
label: BODY

text: how the ODL will operate and be managed following the implementation
label: BODY

text: who will be involved, and what their role/responsibility will be, for both the
label: BODY

text: implementation and operational stages
label: BODY

text: the marketing and communications plan for the ODL
label: BODY

text: This business plan must be completed and approved by the ODL Steering Committee no
label: BODY

text: later than September 30, 2003
label: BODY

text: Timeline:
label: H3

text: Those firms/consultants intended to submit a proposal to this RFP must indicate their
label: BODY

text: intention to do so in an e-mail to Michael Ridley (mridley@uoguelph.ca) by April 11th.
label: BODY

text: Proposals may be e-mailed, mailed, couriered or faxed to: Larry Moore
label: BODY

text: (lmoore@accessola.com), Executive Director, The Ontario Library Association, 100 Lombard
label: BODY

text: St., Suite 303, Toronto, ON M5C 1M3. Proposals must be received by Noon on Monday,
label: BODY

text: Those proposals that are short-listed will be invited to discuss their proposal during the week
label: BODY

text: of April 28, 2003. No presentation will be expected. Firms or consultants invited to an
label: BODY

text: interview will be expected to discuss the project and their approach with the selection
label: BODY

text: committee.
label: BODY

text: Contracts with the firm/consultant will be signed the week of May 5, 2003 with the work to
label: BODY

text: commence as soon as possible thereafter.
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: Please note that we reserve the right not to select any of the submitted proposals and may
label: BODY

text: seek further response to these Terms of Reference.
label: BODY

text: If you require further information or have any questions, please contact Michael Ridley by e-
label: BODY

text: mail (mridley@uoguelph.ca) only by 3:00 p.m. on Friday April 18th. All questions and
label: BODY

text: responses will be shared with those who have indicated that they will be submitting a
label: BODY

text: proposal. Please note, that firms/consultants who have not indicated in an e-mail to Michael
label: BODY

text: Ridley by April 11th that they will be submitting a proposal will not receive any further
label: BODY

text: information or question responses.
label: BODY

text: Background
label: H2

text: First, some background on the ODL. For the last two years the Ontario Library Association
label: BODY

text: has acted as a catalyst, bringing together the stakeholders needed to create the Ontario
label: BODY

text: Digital Library (ODL). These stakeholders include Ontario’s 5000+ public libraries, university,
label: BODY

text: college, and school libraries, as well as Ontario government ministries.
label: BODY

text: Libraries that serve very different clientele recognize that by working together they can create
label: BODY

text: seamless access to quality electronic library services. Through the ODL, students will be
label: BODY

text: able to explore a topic at school, use the same child-safe resources after school (either at
label: BODY

text: home or at a public library), enter college or university with a knowledge of how to use
label: BODY

text: electronic resources that are still available and then, after graduation, continue to use these
label: BODY

text: skills and resources at work or at home.
label: BODY

text: We are moving into a period of convergence. With convergence we no longer have to license
label: BODY

text: commercial products as individual libraries or institutions. We can work together to spend our
label: BODY

text: money wisely. The provincial government has made this possible by working hard to provide
label: BODY

text: all Ontarians with a stable, high-speed communications infrastructure. While there is still a
label: BODY

text: great deal of work needed to improve this infrastructure, libraries are beginning to plan how
label: BODY

text: best to exploit communications technology. We can reduce barriers to access and create the
label: BODY

text: content infrastructure needed to support a knowledge society.
label: BODY

text: The concept of an ODL is a key element in The Roadmap to Prosperity, a strategic plan to
label: BODY

text: envision and attain Ontario’s economic goal prepared by the Ontario Jobs and Investment
label: BODY

text: Board. The OJIB strategic plan recommends an electronic library to “connect students to new
label: BODY

text: workplaces, new sources of information and applied learning opportunities”. The ODL will do
label: BODY

text: that and much more. The ODL will connect students to electronic information, and will also
label: BODY

text: leverage this investment to help connect all citizens to the electronic information they need as
label: BODY

text: they make decisions, solve problems and enhance their quality of life.
label: BODY

text: Libraries have long been a key delivery point for public services. The ODL will allow that
label: BODY

text: delivery point to move closer to citizens, into the smallest of libraries and even into living
label: BODY

text: rooms.
label: BODY

text: Libraries have a long tradition of using a practical, consultative approach to solving problems,
label: BODY

text: and of learning from others. The ODL is a very practical solution to various problems.
label: BODY

text: Jurisdiction-wide digital libraries are very practical and very real. The ODL we propose is
label: BODY

text: leading edge for Ontario but several jurisdictions have forged the path with collaborative
label: BODY

text: digital libraries. We can learn from their experiences. For example, The Alberta Library (TAL)
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: was incorporated in 1997 as a province-wide library consortium. TAL works collaboratively
label: BODY

text: with its members to promote universal access to materials and resources in more than 250
label: BODY

text: public, post-secondary, special, government and regional libraries. Unlike ODL, TAL does
label: BODY

text: not include elementary or secondary schools. However, the timeline and funding we are
label: BODY

text: proposing for ODL is comparable to TAL‘s experience. TAL’s business planning took several
label: BODY

text: years. TAL’s implementation plan was supported by 8 million dollars in provincially shared
label: BODY

text: funding, spread over three years, later revised to 15 million dollars over 4 years. Not only is
label: BODY

text: Alberta’s population 30% of Ontario’s, TAL does not include elementary or secondary
label: BODY

text: schools as partners; it has 250 member libraries. ODL envisions universal access for all
label: BODY

text: 10,000,000 Ontarians, with more than 5000 Ontario libraries as partners. Although ODL can
label: BODY

text: learn from TAL’s practices, the scope of planning and implementing ODL is much larger than
label: BODY

text: TAL.
label: BODY

text: The ODL will be a partnership-based organization providing seamless electronic information
label: BODY

text: services and resources to the citizens of Ontario. It will use local libraries as the entry point for
label: BODY

text: common resources The ODL will recognize the unique responsibilities and needs of public
label: BODY

text: libraries, school libraries, college and university libraries and special libraries. The ODL
label: BODY

text: envisions a digital network of information resources, allowing members to collaborate when
label: BODY

text: there is mutual benefit and to support the common mandates of local libraries.
label: BODY

text: The principles which will define and guide the ODL are:
label: BODY

text: Equitable access for all Ontarians:
label: H3

text: We will bring consistent, high-quality electronic resources and services to 10 million
label: BODY

text: Ontario citizens
label: BODY

text: We will eliminate barriers to the access to information and create more consistent
label: BODY

text: services for library clients.
label: BODY

text: Shared decision-making and accountability:
label: H3

text: We will facilitate consensus among members regarding ODL’s portfolio of electronic
label: BODY

text: licenses and services
label: BODY

text: We will balance the interests and realities of small and large as well as rich and poor
label: BODY

text: communities and institutions.
label: BODY

text: Shared governance structure:
label: H3

text: We will share decision-making in order to enable the people we serve.
label: BODY

text: We will work based on an underlying assumption of trust and synergy.
label: BODY

text: Shared funding:
label: H3

text: We will leverage provincial, institutional, and local dollars to realize economies of scale
label: BODY

text: and put Ontario dollars to work for everyone.
label: BODY

text: We will be willing to pool talents and dollars in order to provide common services that are
label: BODY

text: truly greater than those that can be maintained by individual institutions.
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: Local points of entry:
label: H3

text: We will provide the licenses, infrastructure, services and support that enable local
label: BODY

text: libraries to provide exceptional services to their clientele. ODL will focus on support,
label: BODY

text: providing the underpinning, not overshadowing.
label: BODY

text: Services envisioned for the ODL’s include:
label: BODY

text: Access:
label: H3

text: to the “deep” web (i.e. Commercial, purchased electronic services)
label: BODY

text: to credible web sites and electronic resources
label: BODY

text: to digital government information
label: BODY

text: to local digital collections
label: BODY

text: Guidance and Advice:
label: H3

text: to support e-learning
label: BODY

text: to support citizens, in real-time, as they try to use electronic resources
label: BODY

text: to assist citizens as they use web-links
label: BODY

text: Training:
label: H3

text: for library workers
label: BODY

text: for the general public
label: BODY

text: Provincial Purchasing & Licensing:
label: H3

text: of electronic content on a consortia basis for all member libraries
label: BODY

text: Technological Support:
label: H3

text: of common standards for the preservation and archiving local digital content
label: BODY

text: of a common interface to ODL resources and services that can be imbedded in local
label: BODY

text: library web sites
label: BODY

text: What could the ODL really mean?
label: H3

text: For each Ontario citizen it could mean:
label: H4

text: One local point of entry to access seamless electronic library services and
label: BODY

text: resources for their personal, educational and professional needs;
label: BODY

text: Access to credible, high-quality, user-friendly electronic services through their
label: BODY

text: community, school, or academic library;
label: BODY

text: Confidence that the electronic services and sources they – and their children
label: BODY

text: – are using are safe, valid, and bringing them both global and local
label: BODY

text: perspectives;
label: BODY

text: Electronic information and tools that enhance job skills and the learning
label: BODY

text: experience
label: BODY

text: For each Ontario student it could mean:
label: H4

text: One local point of entry to quality, curriculum- based electronic information
label: BODY

text: resources and services
label: BODY

text: Connection to their individual educational environment, whether at the
label: BODY

text: elementary, secondary or post-secondary levels
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: Confidence that the services and resources people are using are credible,
label: BODY

text: available when they need them and adaptable to different learning styles
label: BODY

text: For each Ontario library it could mean:
label: H4

text: One point of entry for themselves and their clientele to quality electronic
label: BODY

text: resources and services that support and enhance their collections, programs
label: BODY

text: and services
label: BODY

text: The opportunity to show case their local community, collections, services, and
label: BODY

text: expertise
label: BODY

text: The opportunity to gain from the provincial, collaborative partnership in order
label: BODY

text: to provide a seamless gateway to digital resources and services
label: BODY

text: For the Ontario government it could mean:
label: H4

text: A point of entry to information services and resources for all Ontario citizens,
label: BODY

text: connecting to portal initiatives.
label: BODY

text: Support of the Ontario E-Learning strategy through a collaborative digital
label: BODY

text: library initiative that positions Ontario on the global e-learning scene
label: BODY

text: Improved access and flexibility for all students at all ages and stages
label: BODY

text: (supports Ontario’s lifelong learning strategy)
label: BODY

text: The opportunity to address emerging job skills shortages and facilitate school
label: BODY

text: to work and job to job transitions with the necessary information and
label: BODY

text: knowledge supports and tools
label: BODY

text: ODL will be an incorporated non-profit organization governed by a Board of Directors elected
label: BODY

text: by a voting membership. The Board will include representatives from all stakeholders. We
label: BODY

text: envision a governance model similar to that prepared for the province’s ORION network.
label: BODY

text: More information regarding the envisioned phasing, funding and resources required for the
label: BODY

text: ODL can be found in the appendixes.
label: BODY

text: The Business Plan to be Developed
label: H2

text: The business plan which needs to be developed for the ODL must be a formal business plan
label: BODY

text: that documents and clearly communicates the ODL’s services, funding and governance
label: BODY

text: structures, as well as implementation plans for 2004-2005, and operational plans for 2005-
label: BODY

text: 2007. The planning process must also secure the full commitment of all stakeholders, as
label: BODY

text: represented on the Steering Committee.
label: BODY

text: Specifically, the business plan must include:
label: BODY

text: how the ODL will be implemented, including the timeline
label: BODY

text: the financial plan for the implementation
label: BODY

text: the financial plan for the first 2 operating years, including capital and operating costs,
label: BODY

text: revenues, etc.
label: BODY

text: a financial forecast for the succeeding 2 operating years
label: BODY

text: the services and products to be delivered by the ODL
label: BODY

text: how the ODL will operate and be managed following the implementation
label: BODY

text: who will be involved, and what their role/responsibility will be, for both the
label: BODY

text: implementation and operational stages
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: the marketing and communications plan for the ODL
label: BODY

text: the commitment of all stakeholders to their responsibilities
label: BODY

text: The process of developing this business plan must be extremely consultative to ensure that
label: BODY

text: all stakeholders are engaged in creating a synergistic ODL organization. The proposal must
label: BODY

text: indicate how this consultative process will be approached.
label: BODY

text: The business plan for the ODL must address significant issues. There are, for example,
label: BODY

text: enormous differences in the financial resources available to libraries mandated to provide
label: BODY

text: similar services. Some post-secondary and public libraries, particularly those in large urban
label: BODY

text: areas, have the facilities, funding and technological infrastructure necessary to service their
label: BODY

text: patrons with electronic services and resources. Many others, particularly in rural regions, do
label: BODY

text: not. The proposal must indicate how these issues will be approached.
label: BODY

text: Milestones
label: H3

text: 1) A preliminary report will be issued during June 2003.
label: BODY

text: 2) It is expected that an Interim Report, suitable for distribution to the broader library
label: BODY

text: community will be available by August 1, 2003 and that there will be an opportunity
label: BODY

text: for responses to be evaluated.
label: BODY

text: 3) The business plan must be completed and approved by the ODL Steering Committee
label: BODY

text: no later than September 30, 2003.
label: BODY

text: Approach and Specific Proposal Requirements
label: H2

text: The firm/consultant (or proposed team of consultants) will be expected to work closely with
label: BODY

text: the ODL Steering Committee. Terms of reference for the Committee are in the appendix.
label: BODY

text: Given the consultative nature of this business planning process, the firm/consultant will also
label: BODY

text: be expected to travel and communicate regularly with various stakeholders as well as with
label: BODY

text: electronic resource publishers/vendors.
label: BODY

text: The proposal should include the following information:
label: BODY

text: a) name of the firm/consultant
label: BODY

text: b) names of those individuals who will be engaged in this project, their specific
label: BODY

text: responsibilities on this project and relevant experience/qualifications
label: BODY

text: c) description of similar engagements that highlight the firm’s experience in business
label: BODY

text: planning and building stakeholder commitment
label: BODY

text: d) references with details of work completed for these references
label: BODY

text: e) description of the approach that will be used for completing the business plan,
label: BODY

text: including a timeline
label: BODY

text: f) cost to complete the study including estimated expenses (i.e.: travel, etc.) and payment
label: BODY

text: structure

label: H2

text: The contract will be awarded to the bidder whose submission offers the best value; the contract will
label: BODY

text: not necessarily be awarded to the lowest bidder. We reserve the right not to award the contract to
label: BODY

text: any of the bidders responding to this RFP and we may seek further response.

text: Appendix A: ODL Envisioned Phases & Funding
label: H2

text: Phase I: Business Planning
label: H3

text: Timeline: March 2003 – September 2003
label: BODY

text: Funding Requested: ~$100,000 jointly funded by stakeholder groups and the provincial government.
label: BODY

text: Result: The ODL business plan
label: BODY

text: The first phase will be to build the ODL business plan. This plan will clearly define the ODL’s services,
label: BODY

text: funding and governance structures, as well as implementation plans for 2003-2005. It will also secure
label: BODY

text: the full commitment of all stakeholders and scope the operational plan for ODL for 2006 and beyond.
label: BODY

text: Given the number and diversity of stakeholders involved, the business planning process must be a fully
label: BODY

text: consultative approach. To ensure that the planning results in a workable plan with the full commitment
label: BODY

text: of all stakeholders it must have competent, dedicated staffing and monies for the travel and
label: BODY

text: communication components so critical in a consultative process.
label: BODY

text: Phase II: Implementing and Transitioning
label: H3

text: Timeline: April 2004 – December 2006
label: BODY

text: Funding Requested: Funding from other states and provinces suggest that the ODL could receive
label: BODY

text: funding of up to $50 Million (over 3 years). Funding to be provided partnership of government, library
label: BODY

text: stakeholders and other interested parties.
label: BODY

text: Result: The ODL is implemented and validated
label: BODY

text: The second phase will be to implement the ODL based on the business plan. This phase recognizes
label: BODY

text: that for ODL to be optimally successful libraries must transition to a new way of doing business and
label: BODY

text: providing services. The transition must occur while libraries continue to provide existing services and
label: BODY

text: respond to current challenges. This implementation phase will funded by a partnership of government,
label: BODY

text: library stakeholders and other interested parties as a means to quickly jumpstart the ODL.
label: BODY

text: The seed money requested will allow libraries to realign their budgets and services as the infrastructure
label: BODY

text: and content of the ODL is created and secured. Some of the funding will be new money, although there
label: BODY

text: is every indication that existing budgets and methods of operating may be modified as a result of
label: BODY

text: recommendations. During this phase the polices, procedures, governance structures and accountability
label: BODY

text: mechanisms of the ODL will be put in place. Pilot projects will be initiated, evaluated and expanded.
label: BODY

text: Information resources will be identified, contracts for these resources will be negotiated and resources
label: BODY

text: will be made deployed through the ODL. Regular evaluation during this phase will ensure the ODL is
label: BODY

text: achieving its objectives and is accountable to its key communities.
label: BODY

text: Phase III: Operating and Growing the ODL
label: H3

text: Timeline: January 2007 -
label: BODY

text: Funding: $50 Million annually ($35 Million requested from government)
label: BODY

text: Result: The ODL is fully operational and sustainable
label: BODY

text: In the third phase the ODL moves into the operational stage. Ontarians will experience the full benefits
label: BODY

text: of the initiative and libraries will consolidate support around the ODL to grow resources and extend
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: capabilities. The challenge is to secure resources sufficient to both sustain the original investments and
label: BODY

text: to enhance the ODL.
label: BODY

text: The ongoing funding of the ODL will be based on a partnership model involving all the key participants
label: BODY

text: (i.e. government, libraries, donors, public and private sectors). All participants (i.e. beneficiaries) are
label: BODY

text: expected to make financial contributions to the ODL. It is important in achieving the full impact of the
label: BODY

text: ODL on Ontario’s economy, society and learning support that all library sectors are participants
label: BODY

text: (university, colleges, public libraries and schools).
label: BODY

text: The proposed funding model requires a continuing government investment, but also recognizes that as
label: BODY

text: the ODL matures a growing share of ODL funding will come from libraries and non-governmental
label: BODY

text: sources. During the 3-year implementation phase (2004 – 2006) libraries will realign their budgets to
label: BODY

text: enable ongoing funding contributions to ODL. During the same period ODL must build the proposed
label: BODY

text: endowment and secure public and private sector gifts and/or in-kind contributions. The following chart
label: BODY

text: outlines the model. This model is based on these assumptions:
label: BODY

text: 1. that ODL expenditures will increase by 50% over a 10 year period
label: BODY

text: 2. that government funding will decrease from 70% to 45% during that 10 year period
label: BODY

text: 3. that library contributions, endowment and gifts/in-kind funding will increase from 30% to 55%
label: BODY

text: during the same period
label: BODY

text: OVERVIEW OF ODL FUNDING MODEL
label: BODY

text: Funding Source 2007 2017
label: BODY

text: Endowment $4.5M (9%) $15M (20%)
label: BODY

text: Gifts/In-Kind $0.5M (1%) $3.75M (5%)
label: BODY

text: TOTAL ANNUAL $50M $75M
label: BODY

text: While the private sector will be invited to participate in the ODL through the endowment, gifts and in-
label: BODY

text: kind contributions, the ODL will also explore compatible commercial services which leverage the reach
label: BODY

text: of the ODL and help to offset operating costs.
label: BODY

text: A $50M budget leverages the consortium buying power of the province’s libraries to secure the best
label: BODY

text: prices for information resources, the widest accessibility and the most favourable contracts. A budget of
label: BODY

text: this nature will ensure a core digital collection of sufficient scope and coverage to address a substantial
label: BODY

text: amount of the wide and diverse information and learning needs of the citizens of Ontario (an overview
label: BODY

text: of the nature of the ODL digital collection is appended). The proposed ODL expenditures in 2006
label: BODY

text: represent an investment of $5.00 per citizen.
label: BODY

text: It is important to recognize that every new dollar per citizen invested in the Ontario Digital Library has a
label: BODY

text: double benefit: it supports a province-wide library of high quality information resources and it
label: BODY

text: strengthens every local library in Ontario by allowing them to reinvest existing dollars in new resources
label: BODY

text: that enhance local services. This multiplier means that for every dollar invested in ODL the return
label: BODY

text: on investment is worth $2 of value for Ontario.
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: Appendix B: ODL Steering Committee Terms of Reference
label: H2

text: 1. Preamble
label: H3

text: Implementation of the Ontario Digital Library (ODL) requires a detailed business plan to be developed
label: BODY

text: and supported by its diverse stakeholder communities (see: www.odl.on.ca). The business
label: BODY

text: development planning and commitment process will be overseen by a Steering Committee, who are
label: BODY

text: accountable to potential ODL funders including the Province of Ontario.
label: BODY

text: 2. Terms of Reference
label: H3

text: In broad terms, the ODL Business Plan Steering Committee is responsible for development of the
label: BODY

text: business plan, securing sector support, and management of the planners and process. Specific
label: BODY

text: responsibilities include:
label: BODY

text: 2.1 developing a detailed business plan for the three-year implementation phase of the ODL, including
label: BODY

text: governance, management, funding model and structure, organizational structure, marketing,
label: BODY

text: staffing, and evaluation;
label: BODY

text: 2.2 consulting with and reporting to stakeholder communities, to ensure open, consistent and two-way
label: BODY

text: communication, and to ensure meaningful opportunities for stakeholder input into decision-
label: BODY

text: making;
label: BODY

text: 2.3 recruiting and managing the business planner(s);
label: BODY

text: 2.4 defining terms of reference and resource parameters for business planner(s), and authorizing
label: BODY

text: expenditures;
label: BODY

text: 2.5 serving as a focus group for business planner(s) to test ideas;
label: BODY

text: 2.6 providing signoff for business planner(s) at key decision points of business plan development;
label: BODY

text: 2.7 securing commitment from library, government, and institutional stakeholders for implementation
label: BODY

text: of the business plan;
label: BODY

text: 2.8 presenting the business plan to funders
label: BODY

text: 2.9 undertaking advocacy efforts to promote the ODL to the broader communities including library
label: BODY

text: and education communities.
label: BODY

text: 3. Membership
label: H3

text: Each of the four sectors, Schools, Colleges, Universities, and Public Libraries can appoint up to two
label: BODY

text: representatives to the steering committee
label: BODY

text: 3.1 Schools:
label: BODY

text: - Ontario School Library Association (OSLA) and The Association of Library Consultants and
label: BODY

text: Coordinators of Ontario (TALCO) (Executive Council of OSLA to name representative in
label: BODY

text: consultation with TALCO)
label: BODY

text: 3.2 Universities:
label: BODY

text: - Ontario Council of University Libraries (OCUL) (OCUL to name)
label: BODY

text: 3.3 Colleges:
label: BODY

text: - Bibliocentre, and Heads of Libraries and Learning Resources (UAG and HLLR to name)
label: BODY

text: 3.4 Public libraries:
label: BODY

text: - Administrators of Medium-sized Public Libraries of Ontario (AMPLO), Administrators of Rural
label: BODY

text: Urban Public Libraries of Ontario (ARUPLO), Administrators of Small Public Libraries of
label: BODY

text: Ontario (ASPLO) and Chief Executives of Large-sized Public Libraries of Ontario (CELPLO)
label: BODY

text: (Executives of AMPLO, ARUPLO, ASPLO and CELPLO to name)
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: 3.5 Ontario Library Association representative (ex-officio) (OLA to appoint one representative)
label: BODY

text: - Role of the OLA ex-officio member: To act as a liaison between the steering committee and
label: BODY

text: the OLA Board, and to assist the chair with the administrative responsibilities connected with
label: BODY

text: the preparation of the business plan, finance, and communications.
label: BODY

text: 3.6 It is anticipated that as planning for the ODL evolves, the Steering Committee may, at its
label: BODY

text: discretion, call on invited experts to advise on issues as required.
label: BODY

text: 4. Appointment Criteria and Process
label: H3

text: 4.1 Groups and organizations named in Section 3 above are responsible for appointing up to two
label: BODY

text: representatives to the Steering Committee.
label: BODY

text: 4.2 Desired characteristics for steering committee appointees include:
label: BODY

text: Strategic thinkers;
label: BODY

text: Committed to the concept of multi-sector partnerships;
label: BODY

text: Knowledgeable about digital libraries and resources;
label: BODY

text: Knowledgeable about government structures;
label: BODY

text: Respected by their communities; influential;
label: BODY

text: Able to take a consultative approach;
label: BODY

text: Able to devote time to Steering Committee business: approximately one day per month for
label: BODY

text: meetings plus 2-3 working days per month on related activities.
label: BODY

text: 5. Term
label: H3

text: Expected term on the Steering Committee is the time required to complete development of the
label: BODY

text: business plan plus two months. This process is expected to take approximately 6 months.
label: BODY

text: 6. Chair
label: H3

text: Chair will be appointed by the Board of the Ontario Library Association.
label: BODY

text: Role of the Chair:
label: BODY

text: In addition to the characteristics for appointees (4.2) the role of the chair will be as a process agent
label: BODY

text: working with the selected consultant(s), OLA, and the Steering Committee to prepare the business
label: BODY

text: plan. The chair must be able to devote 5-8 days per month on activities related to the preparation of
label: BODY

text: the business plan, and communications to stakeholders, funders, and government.
label: BODY

text: 7. Meetings
label: H3

text: It is expected that in person meetings are held once per month and the majority of business will be
label: BODY

text: conducted by e-mail, and teleconference.
label: BODY

text: 8. Lines of Accountability and Communication
label: H3

text: 8.1 The Steering Committee is accountable to the Province of Ontario, and to its business plan
label: BODY

text: funders.
label: BODY

text: 8.2 The role of the Ontario Library Association is to assume responsibility for funds contributed by the
label: BODY

text: ODL funders to finance the business plan, to hold the funds in a separate account, and
label: BODY

text: disperse them for purposes as directed by the Steering Committee. OLA will provide
label: BODY

text: financial reports to the Steering Committee as requested and shall comply with all
label: BODY

text: government reporting regulations for funds received.
label: BODY

text: RFP: To Develop the Ontario Digital Library Business Plan March 2003
label: BODY

text: 8.3 The Steering Committee is accountable to its constituent groups and other stakeholders for
label: BODY

text: ongoing communications and consultation on issues and progress. The Steering committee
label: BODY

text: is responsible for strong liaison with government particularly the Chief Information Officer
label: BODY

text: Community Services Cluster, ADM’s and Deputy Ministers.
label: BODY

text: 9. Financial and Administrative Policies
label: H3

text: 9.1 Service on the Steering Committee is non-remunerative
label: BODY

text: 9.2 Travel and meeting expenses for Steering Committee members are reimbursed according to the
label: BODY

text: policies of the Ontario Library Association
label: BODY

text: 9.3 Conflict of Interest:
label: BODY

text: The ODL Steering Committee will function according to standard conflict of interest guidelines
label: BODY

text: ensuring that members, their immediate family members, or their places of employment, will
label: BODY

text: not benefit financially from the decisions the Steering Committee might make. As a first
label: BODY

text: order of business, the Steering Committee will be expected to adopt a conflict of interest policy
label: BODY

text: statement and procedural guidelines that will govern its work.
label: BODY

text: What’s the best way to create a PDF?
label: H1

text: You can create PDFs from documents printed on paper, Microsoft Word documents, InDesign®
label: BODY

text: files, digital images, and more. Diﬀerent types of sources have diﬀerent tools available for PDF
label: BODY

text: conversion. In many applications, you can create PDFs by selecting the Adobe PDF printer in
label: BODY

text: the Print dialog box.
label: BODY

text: If a file is open in its authoring application (such as a spreadsheet that is open in Microsoft
label: BODY

text: Excel), you can convert it to PDF without opening Adobe Acrobat. Similarly, if Acrobat is
label: BODY

text: already open, you don’t have to open the authoring application to convert a file to PDF.
label: BODY

text: Every PDF balances eﬃciency (small file size) and quality (such as resolution and color). If the
label: BODY

text: balance between the file size and the quality is critical to your task, you must use an
label: BODY

text: appropriate conversion method.
label: BODY

text: For example, you can drag files to the Acrobat icon to create PDFs. In this case, Acrobat
label: BODY

text: applies the most recently used conversion settings without providing access to those settings.
label: BODY

text: If you want more control over the process, you’ll want to use another method.
label: BODY
