text: Balance PDF file size and quality
label: H2

text: You can select various settings to ensure that your PDF has the best balance between file size,
label: BODY

text: resolution, conformity to specific standards, and other factors. The settings you select depend
label: BODY

text: on your goals for the PDF that you are creating. For example, a PDF intended for high-quality
label: BODY

text: commercial printing requires diﬀerent settings than a PDF intended only for onscreen viewing
label: BODY

text: and quick downloading over the Internet.
label: BODY

text: Once selected, these settings apply across PDFMaker, Acrobat, and Acrobat Distiller.
label: BODY

text: However, some settings are limited to specific contexts or file types. For example, PDFMaker
label: BODY

text: options can vary among the diﬀerent types of Microsoft Oﬃce applications.
label: BODY

text: For convenience, you can select one of the conversion presets available in Acrobat. You can
label: BODY

text: also create, define, save, and reuse custom presets that are uniquely suited to your purposes.
label: BODY

text: For scanned documents, you can choose from Autodetect Color Mode or several scanning
label: BODY

text: presets that are optimized for scanning documents and images in color or black and white.
label: BODY

text: You can modify these presets or use your own custom scanning settings.
label: BODY

text: There are various ways to create a PDF file using Acrobat. You can generate a PDF quickly
label: BODY

text: using the convert to PDF tool, menu commands, dragging-and-dropping files onto the
label: BODY

text: Acrobat application icon, or converting clipboard data.
label: BODY

text: Convert a file to PDF using Acrobat menu
label: BODY

text: commands
label: BODY

text: 1.Do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select Create from the global toolbar.
label: BODY

text: The Create a PDF tool opens. On the left rail, Single file is
label: BODY

text: selected by default. Choose the Select a file button.
label: BODY

text: Select the hamburger menu > Create > PDF from File (Windows),
label: BODY

text: or File > Create > PDF from File (macOS).
label: BODY

text: 2.In the Open dialog box, select the ﬁle that you want to convert. You can browse all ﬁle
label: BODY

text: types or select a speciﬁc type from the Files Of Type drop-down menu.
label: BODY

text: 3.Optionally, select Advanced settings to change the conversion options if you're
label: BODY

text: converting an image file to PDF. The options available vary depending on the file type.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The Advanced settings button is unavailable if you choose All Files as the file type or
label: BODY

text: if no conversion settings are available for the selected file type. (For example, the
label: BODY

text: Advanced settings button is unavailable for Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel files.)
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Create to convert the ﬁle to a PDF.
label: BODY

text: Depending on the type of ﬁle being converted, the authoring applicaƟon opens
label: BODY

text: automaƟcally, or a progress dialog box appears. If the ﬁle is in an unsupported format, a
label: BODY

text: message appears, telling you that the ﬁle cannot be converted to PDF.
label: BODY

text: 5.When the new PDF opens, choose the hamburger menu > Save or Save
label: BODY

text: As (Windows), File > Save or File > Save As (macOS), and then select a name and
label: BODY

text: location for the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: When naming a PDF that’s intended for electronic distribution, limit the filename to eight
label: BODY

text: characters (with no spaces) and include the .pdf extension. This action ensures that email
label: BODY

text: programs or network servers don’t truncate the filename and that the PDF opens as expected.
label: BODY

text: Convert a file to PDF using the Convert to PDF tool
label: H2

text: 1.In Acrobat, select All tools > Convert to PDF.
label: BODY

text: 2.In the file explorer window that appears, select the file you want to convert to PDF,
label: BODY

text: and select Open.
label: BODY

text: 3.The selected file is converted to PDF and opens in Acrobat. Choose the hamburger
label: BODY

text: menu > Save or Save As (Windows), File > Save or File > Save As (macOS),
label: BODY

text: and then select a name and location for the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Drag-and-drop to create PDFs
label: H2

text: This method is best for small, simple files, such as small image files and plain text files, when
label: BODY

text: the balance between file size and output quality is not important. You can use this technique
label: BODY

text: with many other types of files, but you cannot adjust any conversion settings during the
label: BODY

text: process.
label: BODY

text: 1.Select the icons of one or more files in the Windows Explorer or macOS Finder.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag the file icons onto the Acrobat application icon. Or (Windows only) drag the files
label: BODY

text: into the open Acrobat window.
label: BODY

text: If a message appears saying that the file could not be opened in Acrobat, then that
label: BODY

text: file type cannot be converted to PDF by the drag-and-drop method. Use one of the
label: BODY

text: other conversion methods for that file.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: You can also convert PostScript and EPS files to PDF by dragging them onto
label: BODY

text: the Acrobat window or the Acrobat application icon.
label: BODY

text: 3.Save the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: (Windows only) You can also right-click a file in Windows Explorer and select Convert
label: BODY

text: to Adobe PDF.
label: BODY

text: Convert clipboard content to PDF
label: H2

text: You can create PDFs from text and images that you copy from applications on macOSor
label: BODY

text: Windows.
label: BODY

text: 1.Capture content in the Clipboard:
label: BODY

text: Use the copy command in the applications.
label: BODY

text: Press the PrintScreen key (Windows).
label: BODY

text: Use the Screenshot utility (Applications > Utilities > Screenshot), and
label: BODY

text: choose Edit > Copy to place the content on the clipboard (macOS).
label: BODY

text: In a PDF file, you can select objects using the Edit Object tool (All
label: BODY

text: tools > Use print production > Edit object), and then copy the selected
label: BODY

text: objects.
label: BODY

text: 2.In Acrobat, choose Create > Clipboard > Create,or choose All tools > Create a
label: BODY

text: PDF > Clipboard > Create.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The PDF from Clipboard command appears only when content is copied to the
label: BODY

text: Clipboard. If the Clipboard is empty, the command is disabled.
label: BODY

text: Create a blank PDF
label: H2

text: You can create a blank PDF, rather than beginning with a file, a clipboard image, or scanning.
label: BODY

text: This process can be useful for creating a one-page PDF. For longer, more complex, or heavily
label: BODY

text: formatted documents, it’s better to create the source document in an application that offers
label: BODY

text: more layout and formatting options, such as Adobe InDesign or Microsoft Word.
label: BODY

text: Do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select Create from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: The Create a PDF tool opens. On the leŌ rail, select Blank page, and then select Create.
label: BODY

text: Select the hamburger menu > Create > Blank Page (Windows),
label: BODY

text: or File > Create > Blank Page (macOS).
label: BODY

text: Acrobat creates a blank page PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: To add a blank page to an existing PDF, open the PDF and then choose Edit > Organize
label: BODY

text: pages > Insert > Blank page.
label: BODY

text: Create multiple PDFs from multiple files
label: H2

text: You can create multiple PDFs from multiple native files, including files of different supported
label: BODY

text: formats, in one operation. This method is useful when you must convert a large number of files
label: BODY

text: to PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note: When you use this method, Acrobat applies the most recently used conversion settings
label: BODY

text: without offering you access to those settings. If you want to adjust the conversion settings, do
label: BODY

text: so before using this method.
label: BODY

text: 1.In Acrobat, select Create from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 2.The Create a PDF tool opens. On the leŌ rail, select MulƟple ﬁles > Create mulƟple
label: BODY

text: PDF ﬁles, and then select Next.
label: BODY

text: 3.Choose Add Files > Add Files or Add Folders, and then select the ﬁles or folder.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select OK. The Output opƟons dialog box appears.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the Output OpƟons dialog box, specify your target folder and ﬁlename
label: BODY

text: preferences, and then select OK.
label: BODY

text: Using PDFMaker within an authoring application is a simple, one-click procedure. It involves
label: BODY

text: clicking an Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar button or choosing a command on the Adobe PDF menu.
label: BODY

text: About Acrobat PDFMaker
label: H2

text: PDFMaker is an Acrobat feature that operates within many business applications, such as
label: BODY

text: Microsoft Office applications, AutoCAD, and Lotus Notes. When you install Acrobat,
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker controls appear in the work area of the authoring application.
label: BODY

text: Note: Some PDFMaker features are not available in certain versions of the authoring
label: BODY

text: applications. For a comparison chart, see Compatible web browsers and PDFMaker
label: BODY

text: applications | Acrobat, Reader.
label: BODY

text: Using Create PDF cloud service for PDF
label: BODY

text: conversion
label: BODY

text: Acrobat provides an option to use Adobe Create PDF cloud service in addition to a local
label: BODY

text: conversion to convert Microsoft Word documents to PDFs. The created PDFs are high-quality
label: BODY

text: and provide exceptional visual fidelity. They are well-tagged for better accessibility. They also
label: BODY

text: include link recognition so that hyperlinks, internal document links, and tables of contents are
label: BODY

text: created as live links.
label: BODY

text: Convert a file to PDF using PDFMaker
label: H1

text: In Windows, Acrobat installs both an Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar and an Adobe PDF menu in
label: BODY

text: many popular authoring applications. You can use either the toolbar buttons or the Adobe
label: BODY

text: PDF menu (the Action menu in Lotus Notes) to create PDFs, but the menu also provides access
label: BODY

text: to conversion settings. Although many of the conversion options are common to all authoring
label: BODY

text: applications, a few are application-specific.
label: BODY

text: For Microsoft Office applications such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, the options for creating
label: BODY

text: PDFs are available from the Acrobat ribbon.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you don’t see the PDF toolbar buttons in an application, you must show or activate the PDF
label: BODY

text: toolbar. For other troubleshooting issues, see Troubleshoot Acrobat PDFMaker Problems.
label: BODY

text: Show or activate PDFMaker in Microsoft Office and Lotus Notes
label: H2

text: If the PDF toolbar buttons don’t appear in your Microsoft Office or Lotus Notes application, use
label: BODY

text: one of the following methods to show or activate PDFMaker.
label: BODY

text: For Lotus Notes 9, choose File > Preferences. In the dialog box that appears,
label: BODY

text: choose Toolbar > Toolbars, and select the Visible option for Acrobat PDFMaker.
label: BODY

text: For Microsoft Office, follow these steps:
label: BODY

text: 1.Select the File tab, and then choose Options.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Add-Ins on the left side of the dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 3.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: If PDFMOutlook or Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in isn't listed, choose
label: BODY

text: COM Add-Ins from the Manage pop-up menu and select Go.
label: BODY

text: If PDFMOutlook or Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in is listed under
label: BODY

text: Disabled Application Add-ins, select Disabled Items from the Manage pop-up
label: BODY

text: menu and select Go.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select PDFMOutlook or Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in and select OK.
label: BODY

text: 5.Restart the Office application.
label: BODY

text: Convert a file to PDF
label: H2

text: 1.Open the file in the application used to create it.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the Convert To Adobe PDF button on the Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar.
label: BODY

text: For Microsoft Office applications, such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, select
label: BODY

text: the Create PDF button on the Acrobat ribbon.
label: BODY

text: 3.Enter a filename and location for the PDF, and select Save.
label: BODY

text: 4.(Optional) Check View Result to open the PDF or enable Protect PDF to specify
label: BODY

text: the Security settings for the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Create a PDF and share the link for viewing or commenting
label: H2

text: Applicable to Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the file in the application used to create it.
label: BODY

text: 2.Do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: From the Home tab, choose Create PDF and share link.
label: BODY

text: Select File > Share > Create PDF and share link > Create PDF and Share link.
label: BODY

text: Select File > Share as Adobe PDF link.
label: BODY

text: 3.Acrobat converts the file to PDF, displays it in Acrobat, and copies the shareable link.
label: BODY

text: You can share the link with the desired recipients.
label: BODY

text: Create a PDF and share via Outlook
label: H2

text: Applicable to Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the file in the application used to create it.
label: BODY

text: 2.Do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: From the Home tab, choose Create PDF and Share via Outlook.
label: BODY

text: From the Acrobat tab, choose Create PDF and Share via Outlook.
label: BODY

text: Select File > Share > Email > Create PDF and Share via Outlook.
label: BODY

text: 3.Acrobat converts the file into a PDF, creates a shareable link, and opens Outlook with
label: BODY

text: the link in a new message draft.
label: BODY

text: 4.You can edit the message as desired, add the recipient's email addresses, and then
label: BODY

text: select Send.
label: BODY

text: Create a PDF as an email attachment
label: H2

text: 1.Open the file in the application used to create it.
label: BODY

text: 2.Choose Adobe PDF > Convert To Adobe PDF And Email.
label: BODY

text: For Microsoft Office applications, such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, click
label: BODY

text: the Create And Share button on the Acrobat ribbon.
label: BODY

text: When the conversion has finished, the PDF is opened in Adobe Acrobat. Click
label: BODY

text: the Send File By Email icon ( ) in Acrobat. For more information, see Share a
label: BODY

text: PDF as an email attachment.
label: BODY

text: Attach a file as PDF (Outlook)
label: H2

text: 1.In the Outlook email Message window, click Acrobat > Attach as Adobe PDF button.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select a file to attach, and click Open.
label: BODY

text: Convert files to a secured PDF and attach it to an email message
label: BODY

text: (Outlook)
label: BODY

text: 1.In the Outlook email Message window, click the Attach As Secured Adobe
label: BODY

text: PDF button
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The Attach As Secured Adobe PDF button appears only after you’ve configured an
label: BODY

text: Adobe Experience Manager Document Security using the All tools > Protect a
label: BODY

text: PDF > Set Security Properties > Security Method.
label: BODY

text: 2.Click Browse, select a file to convert, and click Open.
label: BODY

text: 3.Specify the users that can open the PDF, and then click OK:
label: BODY

text: To specify only users that receive the PDF, select Restrict Access Only To
label: BODY

text: People In This Message’s To:, Cc:, And Bcc: List. In this case, the PDF isn’t
label: BODY

text: secured until you send the email message.
label: BODY

text: To specify only users that are specified by a security policy, select Restrict
label: BODY

text: Access By Applying The Following Security Policy, and then select a security
label: BODY

text: policy in the list. In this case, the PDF is secured before it is attached to the
label: BODY

text: email message.
label: BODY

text: 4.If prompted, enter your user name and password to log in to the Adobe
label: BODY

text: LiveCycleRights Management Server.
label: BODY

text: Create a PDF and send it for review
label: H2

text: 1.Open the file in the application used to create it.
label: BODY

text: 2.Click the Convert To Adobe PDF And Send For Review button on the Acrobat
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker toolbar, or (if available) choose Adobe PDF > Convert To Adobe PDF And
label: BODY

text: Send For Review.
label: BODY

text: 3.When the Identity Setup dialog box appears, enter the appropriate information
label: BODY

text: about yourself, and click Complete.
label: BODY

text: 4.Follow the directions in the wizard that appears, as described in Start an email-based
label: BODY

text: review.
label: BODY

text: Create a PDF and run an action
label: H2

text: 1.Open the file in the application used to create it.
label: BODY

text: 2.Click the Convert To Adobe PDF And Run Action button on the Acrobat PDFMaker
label: BODY

text: toolbar, or (if available) choose Adobe PDF > Convert To Adobe PDF And Run Action.
label: BODY

text: For Microsoft Office 2010 applications such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, click
label: BODY

text: the Create PDF And Run Action button on the Acrobat ribbon.
label: BODY

text: 3.Click an action to from the button menu, and follow the onscreen prompts to save
label: BODY

text: the files.
label: BODY

text: 4.The PDF opens in Acrobat. Click Start in the right-hand pane to process the file.
label: BODY

text: View PDFMaker conversion settings
label: H1

text: PDFMaker conversion settings vary according to file types. For example, the options available
label: BODY

text: for PowerPoint files aren’t the same as the options available for Outlook files. Once you’ve
label: BODY

text: selected conversion settings, those choices apply to all subsequent PDFs you create from that
label: BODY

text: file type. It’s a good idea to review the settings occasionally.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open a PDFMaker-enabled application (such as Word or Excel).
label: BODY

text: 2.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings.
label: BODY

text: (Office 2010 applications) In the Acrobat or Adobe PDF ribbon,
label: BODY

text: click Preferences.
label: BODY

text: (All other applications) Choose Adobe PDF > Change Conversion Settings.
label: BODY

text: 3.(Optional) To revert to the original default settings, click Restore Defaults on
label: BODY

text: the Settings tab.
label: BODY

text: Settings tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
label: H2

text: The settings available for PDFMaker depend on the application in which you’re using
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker.
label: BODY

text: Conversion Settings
label: BODY

text: Specifies the standard by which the PDF will be optimized. When you choose an item in the
label: BODY

text: menu, a description of that preset appears immediately below it.
label: BODY

text: View Adobe PDF Result
label: BODY

text: Opens the converted document directly into Acrobat. (Exception: when you choose Convert To Adobe PDF And Email.)
label: BODY

text: Prompt For Adobe PDF File Name
label: BODY

text: Lets you enter a custom filename for the resulting PDF. Deselect this option to save the file in
label: BODY

text: the same folder as the source file, using the same name but with a .pdf extension.
label: BODY

text: Convert Document Information
label: BODY

text: Adds document information from the Properties dialog box of the source file. This setting
label: BODY

text: overrides the printer preferences and settings in the Advanced panel of the Adobe PDF
label: BODY

text: Settings dialog box.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The Advanced Settings button opens the Adobe PDF Settings dialog box, which contains many
label: BODY

text: additional conversion options. These conversion settings apply to all Acrobat features that
label: BODY

text: create PDFs, such as Acrobat Distiller, PDFMaker, and the Acrobat application itself.
label: BODY

text: PDF/A Compliance
label: BODY

text: Creates the PDF so that it conforms to the selected ISO standard for long-term preservation of
label: BODY

text: electronic documents.
label: BODY

text: Security tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
label: H2

text: The settings available for PDFMaker depend on the application in which you’re using
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker.
label: BODY

text: Require A Password To Open The Document
label: BODY

text: When selected, makes the Document Open Password option available, where you enter a
label: BODY

text: password that users must use to open the document.
label: BODY

text: Restrict Editing And Printing Of The Document
label: BODY

text: When selected, makes the other Permissions options available.
label: BODY

text: Change Permissions Password
label: BODY

text: Specifies a password you set that users must use in order to do any allowable printing or
label: BODY

text: editing.
label: BODY

text: Printing Allowed
label: BODY

text: Specifies whether users who use the Permissions Password can print the document and at
label: BODY

text: what resolution.
label: BODY

text: Changes Allowed
label: BODY

text: Specifies what changes users who use the Permissions Password can make.
label: BODY

text: Enable Copying Of Text, Images, And Other Contents
label: BODY

text: Prevents or allows users from copying from the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Enable Text Access For Screen Reader Devices For The Visually Impaired
label: BODY

text: Prevents or allows screen reader devices to read text. (Selected by default.)
label: BODY

text: Enable Plaintext Metadata
label: BODY

text: Specifies whether the search engine can read the document metadata. Available only when the
label: BODY

text: PDF-compatibility is set to Acrobat 6.0 (PDF 1.5) or later.
label: BODY

text: Convert Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and
label: BODY

text: Excel files to PDF
label: BODY

text: When creating a PDF from Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, or Excel, you can set conversion
label: BODY

text: options for the current file. You can also select a range of content in the file to convert. The
label: BODY

text: conversion options that you can set in the following steps are some of the most commonly used
label: BODY

text: settings from the Acrobat PDFMaker dialog box. Any changes you make to the conversion
label: BODY

text: options apply to the current conversion only.
label: BODY

text: Convert Excel files to PDF
label: H2

text: 1.Open a file in Excel.
label: BODY

text: 2.Optionally, select the cells to convert.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the Acrobat ribbon, select one of the Create options.
label: BODY

text: 4.In the Acrobat PDFMaker dialog box, select a Conversion Range, then
label: BODY

text: choose Convert To PDF.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the Save Adobe PDF File As dialog box, specify a filename and location for the PDF.
label: BODY

text: 6.Optionally, select the Options button to change the conversion settings.
label: BODY

text: 7.Select Save to create the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Convert Word and PowerPoint files to PDF
label: H2

text: 1.Open a file in Word or PowerPoint.
label: BODY

text: 2.Optionally, select objects and text (Word) or slides (PowerPoint), as needed.
label: BODY

text: 3.(Office 2010) From the Acrobat ribbon, select Create PDF, Create And Attach to Email,
label: BODY

text: or Create And Send For Review.
label: BODY

text: 4.In the Save Adobe PDF File As dialog box, specify a filename and location for the PDF.
label: BODY

text: 5.Optionally, click the Options button to change the conversion settings.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select a Page Range (Word) or Slide Range (PowerPoint). The Selection option is
label: BODY

text: available only if you have selected content in the file.
label: BODY

text: 7.Click OK, then click Save to create the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Convert email messages to PDFs
label: H1

text: You can use PDFMaker to convert one or more Microsoft Outlook or Lotus Notes email
label: BODY

text: messages or entire folders of messages to a merged PDF or PDF Portfolio. Within a PDF
label: BODY

text: Portfolio, each email message appears as a separate PDF file.
label: BODY

text: The Acrobat PDFMaker Conversion Settings dialog box contains the option that determines
label: BODY

text: whether email messages are merged into one continuous PDF or assembled into a PDF
label: BODY

text: Portfolio.
label: BODY

text: The controls that activate an email conversion to PDF appear in two places within the email
label: BODY

text: application: on the Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar and on a menu. In Outlook, the menu is
label: BODY

text: called Adobe PDF and appears to the right of the Outlook Help menu. In Lotus Notes, PDF
label: BODY

text: commands appear under the Actions menu.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: You can convert one currently open email message to PDF (not to a PDF Portfolio) by
label: BODY

text: choosing File > Print, and selecting Adobe PDF as the printer in the Print dialog box. The
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker conversion settings do not affect this process.
label: BODY

text: Specify whether email messages become merged PDFs or PDF
label: BODY

text: Portfolios
label: BODY

text: 1.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Outlook) Choose Acrobat > Change Conversion Settings.
label: BODY

text: (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings.
label: BODY

text: 2.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: To convert and merge email messages into a PDF as sequential pages of one
label: BODY

text: document, deselect Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF
label: BODY

text: File.
label: BODY

text: To assemble converted email messages as components of a PDF Portfolio,
label: BODY

text: select Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF File.
label: BODY

text: Convert an open email message to PDF (Outlook)
label: H2

text: 1.Choose Acrobat > Convert To Adobe PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note: You can also convert a different file to PDF from within an open Outlook email message if
label: BODY

text: the Attach As Adobe PDF toolbar is shown. Clicking this button opens a series of dialog boxes
label: BODY

text: for selecting and saving the new PDF and also starts Acrobat, if it is not already running. The
label: BODY

text: resulting PDF is attached to the open email message.
label: BODY

text: Convert email messages to a new PDF
label: H2

text: 1.In Outlook or Lotus Notes, select the individual email messages.
label: BODY

text: 2.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Outlook) Choose Acrobat > Selected Messages > Create New PDF.
label: BODY

text: (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > Convert Selected Messages To Adobe PDF.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the Save Adobe PDF As dialog box, select a location, type a filename, and
label: BODY

text: click Save.
label: BODY

text: Add email messages or folders to an existing PDF
label: H2

text: 1.In Outlook or Lotus Notes, select the individual email messages or folders.
label: BODY

text: 2.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Outlook) Choose Acrobat > Selected Messages > Append To Existing PDF,
label: BODY

text: or Acrobat > Selected Folders > Append To Existing PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note: If you have already created one or more PDF Portfolios, you can choose from
label: BODY

text: recently created PDF Portfolios in addition to the Append To Existing PDF option.
label: BODY

text: (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > Append Selected Message(s) To Existing
label: BODY

text: Adobe PDF, or Actions > Append Selected Folder(s) To Existing Adobe PDF.
label: BODY

text: 3.Locate and select the PDF or PDF Portfolio to which you want to add the converted
label: BODY

text: emails, and click Open.
label: BODY

text: Note: Do not type a new name for the PDF. If you do, a warning message appears
label: BODY

text: telling you that the PDF was not found. Click OK, and select a PDF without changing
label: BODY

text: its name.
label: BODY

text: 4.(Outlook only) If a message appears, alerting you that the existing PDF was created
label: BODY

text: using an earlier version of PDFMaker, do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: To create a PDF Portfolio from the original PDF archive, click Yes, and select a
label: BODY

text: name and location for the new archive. (The default name adds _Portfolio to
label: BODY

text: the original PDF filename.) When the conversion is complete and the Creating
label: BODY

text: Adobe PDF dialog box closes, the new archive opens in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Click No to cancel the process.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: For PDF Portfolios of email converted or migrated in Acrobat 8 or later, only new messages—
label: BODY

text: that is, messages that are not already part of the PDF Portfolio—are appended.
label: BODY

text: Convert email folders to a new PDF
label: H2

text: PDFMaker can convert multiple folders to PDF in one procedure. It is not necessary to select the
label: BODY

text: folders at the beginning of the process because you can select them in a dialog box that
label: BODY

text: appears automatically.
label: BODY

text: 1.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Outlook) Choose Acrobat > Selected Folders > Create New PDF.
label: BODY

text: (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > Convert Selected Folder(s) To Adobe PDF.
label: BODY

text: 2.In the Convert Folder(s) To PDF dialog box, select the folders. Then select or deselect
label: BODY

text: the Convert This Folder And All Sub Folders option.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the Save Adobe PDF File As, select a location and name for the PDF Portfolio.
label: BODY

text: When the conversion is complete, the new PDF opens in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Set up automatic email archiving
label: H1

text: 1.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Outlook) Choose Acrobat > Setup Automatic Archival.
label: BODY

text: (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > Setup Automatic Archival.
label: BODY

text: 2.On the Automatic Archival tab of the Acrobat PDFMaker dialog box, select Enable
label: BODY

text: Automatic Archival. Then select options for Frequency and the time of day at which
label: BODY

text: automatic archiving occurs.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select other options, according to your needs:
label: BODY

text: Maintain Log Of Archival
label: BODY

text: Creates a record of each archiving session.
label: BODY

text: Choose File
label: BODY

text: Specifies the name and location of the archiving log.
label: BODY

text: Embed Index For Faster Search
label: BODY

text: Creates an index that you can search to find specific words or characters instead of
label: BODY

text: having to search each individual document.
label: BODY

text: 4.Click Add, and select the email folders and subfolders. Then select or deselect
label: BODY

text: the Convert This Folder And All Sub Folders option, as preferred, and click OK.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the Save PDF Archive File As dialog box, select a name and location for the
label: BODY

text: archived email PDF. Then click Open.
label: BODY

text: 6.Review the settings and the archive folder names listed in the Acrobat
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker dialog box, and do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: To add other email folders to the list, click Add and select the folder.
label: BODY

text: To remove folders from the list, select the folders and click Delete.
label: BODY

text: To change an archive file, select any folder name from the list, click Change
label: BODY

text: Archive File, and specify the name and location.
label: BODY

text: To start archiving email immediately, click Run Archival Now.
label: BODY

text: Create PDFs from Word mail merges
label: H1

text: Mail merges from Word generate documents like form letters—for one common example—
label: BODY

text: that are personalized with information like the names and addresses of the recipients. With
label: BODY

text: Acrobat PDFMaker, you can save steps by using a Word mail merge document and
label: BODY

text: corresponding data file to output mail merges directly to PDF. You can even set up PDFMaker to
label: BODY

text: attach those PDFs to email messages that are generated during the PDF-creation process.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: For information on setting up files for the Word Mail Merge feature, see Microsoft Office Word
label: BODY

text: Help.
label: BODY

text: 1.In Microsoft Word, open the template that you have created as the basis of your mail
label: BODY

text: merge, or create the file using the Word Mail Merge toolbar and Mail Merge wizard,
label: BODY

text: as needed.
label: BODY

text: Note: Do not complete the mail merge in Word. Instead, set up and preview the mail
label: BODY

text: merge as usual, so that you can verify that the merge will work correctly.
label: BODY

text: 2.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: Choose Acrobat > Mail Merge.
label: BODY

text: Click the Mail Merge To Adobe PDF button on the Mail Merge toolbar (View >
label: BODY

text: Toolbars > Mail Merge).
label: BODY

text: 3.In the Acrobat PDFMaker - Mail Merge dialog box, select the options you want:
label: BODY

text: To specify which records in the data file will be imported into the merged
label: BODY

text: files, select All or Current, or enter a range of pages by typing in
label: BODY

text: the From and To boxes.
label: BODY

text: To name the PDF that will be created, type in the Specify PDF File Name box.
label: BODY

text: Note: The PDF will be named using this text plus a series of numbers. For example, if
label: BODY

text: you type JulyLetter in the Specify PDF File Name box, the mail-merged PDFs
label: BODY

text: might appear as JulyLetter_0000123, JulyLetter_0000124, JulyLetter_0000125, and
label: BODY

text: so forth.
label: BODY

text: 4.For Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Email, do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: To create and save merged PDFs for printing or sending later in email, leave
label: BODY

text: the option deselected, and click OK.
label: BODY

text: To create merged PDFs and attach each one to an email message to the
label: BODY

text: appropriate recipient, select this check box, and fill in the other Email options.
label: BODY

text: 5.When the Browse For Folder dialog box appears, navigate to the location you want
label: BODY

text: to use and click OK.
label: BODY

text: Status indicators appear as PDFMaker generates the individual PDFs,
label: BODY

text: 6.If you selected Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Email, a dialog box appears
label: BODY

text: asking for your email profile. Enter the appropriate information and click OK.
label: BODY

text: When the job has finished, a message appears, telling you that the process was successful.
label: BODY

text: Email options for PDF mail merges
label: H2

text: Use the pop-up menu to select the field or column in the associated data file that contains the
label: BODY

text: email addresses in each individual’s record.
label: BODY

text: Subject Line
label: BODY

text: Type the text that you want to appear in the subject line of each message.
label: BODY

text: Message
label: BODY

text: Type to add or edit text that you want to appear in the body of the email messages.
label: BODY

text: Convert Visio files to PDF (Acrobat Pro)
label: H1

text: PDFs created from Visio files preserve page sizes and support layers, searchable text, custom
label: BODY

text: properties, links, bookmarks, and comments, depending on the conversion settings. To specify
label: BODY

text: the properties
label: BODY

text: (Visio 2010) From the ribbon choose Acrobat > Preferences
label: BODY

text: When you convert your Visio file, only shapes and guides that are printable and visible in the
label: BODY

text: Visio drawing are converted and appear in the PDF. Shapes are converted regardless of their
label: BODY

text: protection or behavior. Shape custom properties can be converted to PDF object data.
label: BODY

text: When you convert the Visio file to a PDF, you can preserve all or just some layers, or you can
label: BODY

text: flatten all layers. If you flatten layers, the PDF will look like the original drawing, but won’t
label: BODY

text: contain any layer information. When flattened, the contents of only visible and printable layers
label: BODY

text: will appear in the converted PDF.
label: BODY

text: Convert Visio files
label: H2

text: 1.If you want to change the PDFMaker conversion settings, do the following. (For
label: BODY

text: information about a setting, place the pointer over the setting to display a tool tip
label: BODY

text: below.)
label: BODY

text: (Visio 2010) Choose Acrobat > Preferences
label: BODY

text: 2.If you want to convert each page in the Visio file to a bookmarked page in the PDF
label: BODY

text: file, choose Adobe PDF > Convert All Pages In Drawing. If this option is deselected,
label: BODY

text: only the current page is converted.
label: BODY

text: 3.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Visio 2010) Choose Acrobat > Create PDF.
label: BODY

text: (Visio 2010) Choose Acrobat > Convert To Adobe PDF.
label: BODY

text: (Visio 2010) Choose Acrobat > Create and Attach To Email. The PDF file
label: BODY

text: attaches to a new email message in your default email application.
label: BODY

text: (Visio 2010) Choose Acrobat > Create and Send For Review. The file converts
label: BODY

text: to an Adobe PDF file, and an email-based review process begins.
label: BODY

text: 4.If you want to include the custom properties of shapes, select that option.
label: BODY

text: 5.Click Continue.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select a layers option to retain or flatten layers in the resulting PDF, and
label: BODY

text: click Continue.
label: BODY

text: Edit text in a PDF
label: H1

text: Open the PDF you want to edit in Acrobat, and then select Edit in the global bar.
label: BODY

text: The PDF switches to the edit mode, and the Edit panel displays. If the PDF is generated from a
label: BODY

text: scanned document, Acrobat automatically runs OCR to make the text and images editable.
label: BODY

text: The Edit panel includes options to modify the page, add content, redact a PDF, and convert
label: BODY

text: various documents to PDF forms. You can use the options in the Edit panel to replace, edit, or
label: BODY

text: add text to a PDF. You can correct typos, change fonts and typeface size, adjust alignment,
label: BODY

text: add superscripts or subscripts, and resize text or paragraphs.
label: BODY

text: Set the default font for adding and editing text
label: H2

text: When you add text in a PDF, by default Acrobat chooses nearby font attributes for the new
label: BODY

text: text. When you edit text, any font that isn't available on the system is substituted by a default
label: BODY

text: fall-back font for the particular script. For example, Minion Pro is the default fall-back font for
label: BODY

text: Roman script fonts. The substitution of unavailable fonts by default fonts can introduce
label: BODY

text: inconsistency in the look and feel of text in a PDF document. To avoid inconsistency, choose a
label: BODY

text: specific font for any text that is added or modified in the PDF document from Font
label: BODY

text: Options under Content Editing.
label: BODY

text: 1.From the hamburger menu (Windows) or the Acrobat menu (macOS),
label: BODY

text: choose Preferences. The Preferences dialog box is displayed.
label: BODY

text: (Alternatively, you can press Ctrl+K keys on Windows® or Command+K keys on
label: BODY

text: macOS.)
label: BODY

text: 2.In the dialog box, select Content Editing under Categories to display Font Options.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select an appropriate font in the drop-down lists:
label: BODY

text: 1.Fallback font for Editing.
label: BODY

text: 2.Default font for Add Text and Font Size.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select OK to save the changes and close the Preferences dialog box.
label: BODY

text: Change, replace, or delete text
label: H2

text: When you edit text, the text in the paragraph reflows within its text box to accommodate the
label: BODY

text: changes. Each text box is independent, and inserting text in one text block doesn’t push down
label: BODY

text: an adjacent text box or reflow to the next page.
label: BODY

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text that you want to edit. The text-box turns blue upon selection, and a
label: BODY

text: rotation handle appears at the top of the selected text-box.
label: BODY

text: 3.Edit the text by doing one of the following:
label: BODY

text: 1.Type new text to replace the selected text, or press Delete to remove it.
label: BODY

text: 2.To rotate the text box, use the rotation handle at the top of the selected text
label: BODY

text: box.
label: BODY

text: 3.Manage list items using the list controls (bulleted and numbered) in the left
label: BODY

text: Format panel. You can create lists and, conversely, convert a list item to a
label: BODY

text: paragraph or change list types.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select a font, font size, or other formatting options in the left Format panel. You
label: BODY

text: can also try the advanced format options, such as line spacing, character
label: BODY

text: spacing, horizontal scaling, stroke width, and color.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select any area outside the selection to deselect it, and start over.
label: BODY

text: Format text
label: H2

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text that you want to change.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the FormatText section on the left panel, select a font, font size, bold, or other
label: BODY

text: formatting options. You can also try the advanced format options, such as line spacing,
label: BODY

text: character spacing, horizontal scaling, stroke width, and color.
label: BODY

text: Formatting options on the left pane
label: BODY

text: Bold : Bolds the text.
label: BODY

text: Italic : Makes the text italic.
label: BODY

text: Underline: Underlines the text.
label: BODY

text: Superscript : Converts the selected text into superscript.
label: BODY

text: Subscript: Converts the sleected text into subscript.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select outside the selection to deselect it and start over.
label: BODY

text: Add new text
label: H2

text: You can add or insert new text into a PDF using any of the fonts installed on the system.
label: BODY

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar. Then, from the Edit panel, select Text under Add
label: BODY

text: Content.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag to define the width of the text block that you want to add.
label: BODY

text: 3.The Add text tool intelligently detects the following text properties of text close to the
label: BODY

text: point of click:
label: BODY

text: Font name, size, and color
label: BODY

text: Character, paragraph, and line spacing
label: BODY

text: Horizontal scaling
label: BODY

text: These text properties are automatically applied to the text that you add at the point of click.
label: BODY

text: You can change the text properties using the options under Format in the left pane.
label: BODY

text: 4.Type the text.
label: BODY

text: 5.To resize the text box, drag a selection handle.
label: BODY

text: 6.To move the text box, place the pointer over the line of the bounding box (avoid the
label: BODY

text: selection handles). When the cursor changes to Move pointer , drag the box to the
label: BODY

text: new location. To maintain alignment with the other list items, press Shift as you drag.
label: BODY

text: Move, rotate, or resize a text box
label: H2

text: You can move or rotate text boxes on a page. The Edit tool outlines each text box, so it's clear
label: BODY

text: what text is affected. Edits are confined to the page. You can't drag a text block to another
label: BODY

text: page, or move or rotate individual characters or words within a text box. However, you can
label: BODY

text: copy text boxes and paste them on another page.
label: BODY

text: Resizing a text box causes the text to reflow within the new text box boundaries. It doesn't
label: BODY

text: change the size of the text. As with other text edits, resizing is limited to the current page. Text
label: BODY

text: doesn't flow to the next page.
label: BODY

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar. Then, from the Edit panel, select Text under Add
label: BODY

text: Content.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text box that you want to move, rotate, or resize.
label: BODY

text: 3.Do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: 1.Move: Place the pointer over the line of the bounding box (avoid the selection
label: BODY

text: handles). When the cursor changes to Move pointer , drag the box to the
label: BODY

text: desired location. Hold down the Shift key as you drag to constrain the
label: BODY

text: movement vertically or horizontally.
label: BODY

text: 2.Rotate: Click and hold the Rotation pointer , drag in the direction you
label: BODY

text: want it to rotate.
label: BODY

text: 3.Resize: Place the pointer over any of the circular selection handles, and drag
label: BODY

text: the handle to resize the text block.
label: BODY

text: Add or edit lists
label: H2

text: You can add items to a numbered or bulleted list, create list items, convert a paragraph to a
label: BODY

text: list item, and conversely. You can also change list types.
label: BODY

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar. Then, from the Edit panel, select Text under Add
label: BODY

text: Content.
label: BODY

text: 2.To add or remove items from a numbered or bulleted list:
label: BODY

text: •Note: You can add or remove items to the list at all nested levels using the
label: BODY

text: same familiar controls that you use in Microsoft® Office. For example,
label: BODY

text: press Enter at the end of a list item to insert a new row. Press Backspace to
label: BODY

text: remove the new row and position the cursor back to the end of the previous
label: BODY

text: list item.
label: BODY

text: To create a numbered or bulleted list:
label: BODY

text: 1.Place the cursor in the document at the location where you want to add a list.
label: BODY

text: 2.Choose the appropriate list type under Format Text.
label: BODY

text: To convert an existing paragraph to a list item:
label: BODY

text: Place the cursor in the paragraph, and then choose the appropriate list type
label: BODY

text: under Format Text.
label: BODY

text: To convert an existing list item to a paragraph:
label: BODY

text: 1.Select all items in the list. The appropriate list type is highlighted under Format Text.
label: BODY

text: 2.Click the highlighted list type.
label: BODY

text: To convert from one list type to another:
label: BODY

text: 1.Place the cursor in the list item or select all items.
label: BODY

text: 2.Choose the appropriate list type under Format Text.
label: BODY

text: Change font color
label: H2

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text that you want to change.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the FormatText section on the Edit panel, select Font color next to Font size.
label: BODY

text: 4.For Windows: You see a color panel for Windows to choose the color you want. Select
label: BODY

text: the color you want your text to change into.
label: BODY

text: For macOS: You see a Color dialog box with options to change the font color. You can
label: BODY

text: select the color you want and then close the dialog box to change the font color.
label: BODY

text: Change font
label: H2

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar. Then, from the Edit panel, select Text under Add
label: BODY

text: Content.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text that you want to change.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the FormatText section on the Edit panel, from the Font drop-down menu, select
label: BODY

text: the Font you want for the selected text.
label: BODY

text: Change font size
label: H2

text: 1.Select Edit in the global bar. Then, from the Edit panel, select Text under Add
label: BODY

text: Content.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text that you want to change.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the FormatText section on the Edit panel, from the Font size menu, select the font
label: BODY

text: size you want for the selected text.
label: BODY

text: Redo text in Acrobat
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in which you want to redo the text.
label: BODY

text: 2.(Windows) Select the hamburger menu in the upper left. Then select Undo, Redo &
label: BODY

text: more > Redo.
label: BODY

text: (macOS) Select Edit in the upper left. Then select Undo, Redo and More > Redo.
label: BODY

text: Undo text in Acrobat
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in which you want to redo the text.
label: BODY

text: 2.(Windows) Select the hamburger menu in the upper left. Then select Undo, Redo &
label: BODY

text: more > Undo.
label: BODY

text: (macOS) Select Edit in the upper left. Then select Undo, Redo and More > Undo.
label: BODY

text: Change paragraph spacing
label: H2

text: You can change paragraph spacing in Acrobat using format text options:
label: BODY

text: 1.Select Edit from the global bar in the upper left.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text for which you want to modify the paragraph spacing.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the FORMAT TEXT panel, select Paragraph spacing after drop-down menu and
label: BODY

text: then select the value to adjust spacing as needed.
label: BODY

text: Edit images or objects in a PDF
label: H1

text: About editing text and images
label: H2

text: Adobe Acrobat provides powerful tools and capabilities for editing PDF images and text.
label: BODY

text: You might encounter formatting challenges that require manual adjustments. Acrobat's
label: BODY

text: image-editing capabilities are limited, and using high-resolution images can lead to
label: BODY

text: performance issues due to larger file sizes. To address this, improve images using other tools
label: BODY

text: before adding them to PDF documents.
label: BODY

text: If the original font isn't available, font substitutions may occur, altering the text's appearance.
label: BODY

text: To maintain consistency across devices, we suggest you use the available fonts or embed
label: BODY

text: them within the PDF.
label: BODY

text: You can also enhance document accessibility using Acrobat's features, such as adding
label: BODY

text: alternative text for images and proper content tagging.
label: BODY

text: Refer to the following topics to learn how to add, resize, move, or replace images and objects
label: BODY

text: in a PDF using Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Add images in a PDF
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat. Select Edit a PDF from the All tools menu and then
label: BODY

text: select Image.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the drop-down menu, select Choose image to select an image from your device
label: BODY

text: or Select Generate image to generate an image from text.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: To learn how to generate images from text, go to Generate unique AI images from text.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the dialog, select the image file you want to insert.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select where you want to insert the image or select drag to resize it as you insert.
label: BODY

text: A copy of the image file appears on the page, with the same resolution as the original
label: BODY

text: file.
label: BODY

text: 5.Once the image is added, you can take any of the following actions:
label: BODY

text: To move the image, hover over the image, press and hold the move icon, and
label: BODY

text: then drag the image to the desired location.
label: BODY

text: To resize the image, select the image, hold the resize corner handles, and then
label: BODY

text: drag the handles in or out to reduce or enlarge the image size.
label: BODY

text: Modify images in a PDF
label: H2

text: To modify images in a PDF, select Edit from the global bar. Select the image you want to
label: BODY

text: modify, then from the Edit panel, under Adjust Objects,select one of the following tools:
label: BODY

text: Flip Vertical: Flips the image vertically, on the horizontal axis.
label: BODY

text: Flip Horizontal: Flips the image horizontally, on the vertical axis.
label: BODY

text: Rotate left: Rotates the selected image 90° in the counterclockwise direction.
label: BODY

text: Rotate right: Rotates the selected image 90° in the clockwise direction.
label: BODY

text: Crop image: Crops or clips the selected image. Drag a selection handle to crop the image.
label: BODY

text: Replace image: From the drop-down menu, select Choose image to select an image
label: BODY

text: from your device or Select Generate image to an image from text.
label: BODY

text: Align objects: To align multiple objects on a side - left, vertical center, right, top,
label: BODY

text: horizontal, center, and bottom.
label: BODY

text: When you align objects relative to each other by their edges, one of the objects remains
label: BODY

text: stationary. For example, the left option aligns the left edges of the selected objects with the
label: BODY

text: leftmost object.
label: BODY

text: Arrange objects: To move an image or object in front of or behind other elements. You
label: BODY

text: can push an item forward or back on just one level. Alternatively, you can send it to the front
label: BODY

text: or back of the stacking order of elements on the page.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: Place the pointer just outside a selection handle to rotate the selected image manually. When the
label: BODY

text: cursor changes to the rotation pointer , drag in the direction you want it to turn.
label: BODY

text: Delete images from a PDF
label: H1

text: 1.Open the PDF document in Adobe Acrobat. Select Edit from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the image you want to delete, and a contextual menu opens. Select
label: BODY

text: Delete from the contextual menu.
label: BODY

text: Alternatively, you can also select the image and press Delete.
label: BODY

text: Add Objects to PDF
label: H2

text: 1.Open a PDF, and then from the All tools menu, select Edit a PDF.
label: BODY

text: .From the left panel, select More from under Add Content to expand the menu and
label: BODY

text: select a desired tool.
label: BODY

text: 2.To add a button:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the left menu, select Button.
label: BODY

text: 2.Once the button coordinates appear, move the mouse to a desired location
label: BODY

text: and place the button.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the dialog that appears, provide a name to the button.
label: BODY

text: 4.To change the properties of the button, double-click the button and then select
label: BODY

text: in the dialog that appears, set the properties as desired.
label: BODY

text: 3.To add a video:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the left menu, select Video.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag your cursor on the document where you want to add the video.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the Insert Video dialog that appears, browse and select the video file that you
label: BODY

text: want to add.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select OK.
label: BODY

text: 4.To add sound to the PDF:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the left menu, select Sound.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag the cursor over the text or image that you want to add sound to.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the Insert Sound dialog that appears, browse and select the audio file that
label: BODY

text: you want to add.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select OK.
label: BODY

text: 5.To add 3D Media to the video:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the left menu, select 3D Media.
label: BODY

text: 2.Once the button coordinates appear, move the mouse to a desired location
label: BODY

text: and place the button.
label: BODY

text: 3.In the dialog that appears, browse and select the file.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Ok.
label: BODY

text: Edit an image outside Acrobat
label: H2

text: You can edit an image or graphic using another application, such as Photoshop, Illustrator, or
label: BODY

text: Microsoft® Paint. When you save the image or graphic, Acrobat automatically updates the PDF
label: BODY

text: with the changes. The applications that appear in the Edit using menu depend upon what
label: BODY

text: you've installed and the type of image or graphic you've selected. Optionally, you can specify
label: BODY

text: the application you want to use.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat, choose Edit, and then select the image or object.
label: BODY

text: Note: Select multiple items if you want to edit them together in the same file. To edit all the
label: BODY

text: images and objects on the page, choose Select All from the context menu.
label: BODY

text: 2.Under Adjust Objects in the Edit panel, select Edit using, and then choose an editor.
label: BODY

text: To choose a different editor than offered on the menu, select Open with, find the app, and the app
label: BODY

text: and select Open.
label: BODY

text: Note: If a message asks whether to convert to ICC profiles, choose Don’t Convert. If the image
label: BODY

text: window displays a checkerboard pattern when it opens, the image data couldn't be read.
label: BODY

text: Export
label: H1

text: You can save your changes to an Adobe PDF or PDF Portfolio in the original PDF or in a copy
label: BODY

text: of the PDF. You can also save individual PDFs to other file formats, including text, XML,
label: BODY

text: HTML, and Microsoft Word.
label: BODY

text: Saving a PDF in text format allows you to use the content with a screen reader, screen
label: BODY

text: magnifier, or other assistive technology.
label: BODY

text: If you don’t have access to the source files that created an Adobe PDF, you can still copy
label: BODY

text: images and text from the PDF to use elsewhere. You can also export the PDF to a reusable
label: BODY

text: format, or export images in a PDF to another format.
label: BODY

text: Adobe Acrobat Reader users can save a copy of a PDF or PDF Portfolio if the creator of the
label: BODY

text: document has enabled usage rights. If a document has additional or restricted usage rights,
label: BODY

text: the document message bar under the toolbar area describes the assigned restrictions or
label: BODY

text: privileges.
label: BODY

text: Save a PDF
label: H2

text: Use this method to save PDFs, including PDF Portfolios, and PDFs in which you have added
label: BODY

text: comments, form field entries, and digital signatures.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: Saving a digitally signed PDF invalidates the signature.
label: BODY

text: 1.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: To save changes, select Save to computer from the upper right. Alternatively
label: BODY

text: you can also select the hamburger menu and select Save. For macOS,
label: BODY

text: select File > Save.
label: BODY

text: To save a copy of a PDF in Windows, select the hamburger menu and then
label: BODY

text: select Save As. For macOS, select File > Save As.
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat Reader, for Windows, select the hamburger menu and then
label: BODY

text: select> Save As. For macOS, select File > Save asText.
label: BODY

text: To save a copy of a PDF Portfolio, select File >Save.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you are viewing a PDF in a web browser, the Acrobat File menu is not available. Use the
label: BODY

text: Save A Copy button in the Acrobat toolbar to save the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Recover the last saved version
label: H1

text: 1.On Windows, choose the hamburger Menu > Undo, Redo & more > Revert.
label: BODY

text: On macOS, select the File menu > Revert.
label: BODY

text: About the Autosave feature
label: H2

text: The Autosave feature guards against losing your work in case of a power failure by
label: BODY

text: incrementally, and at regular intervals, saving file changes to a specified location. The original
label: BODY

text: file is not modified. Instead, Acrobat creates an autosave file of changes, which includes all the
label: BODY

text: changes you made to the open file since the last automatic save. The amount of new
label: BODY

text: information that the autosave file contains depends on how frequently Acrobat saves the
label: BODY

text: autosave file. If you set the autosave interval to 15 minutes, you could lose the last 14 minutes
label: BODY

text: of your work if a problem occurs. Frequent automatic saving prevents loss of data, and is
label: BODY

text: especially useful if you make extensive changes to a document, such as by adding comments.
label: BODY

text: You can apply autosave changes to the original files when you restart Acrobat. When you
label: BODY

text: close, save manually, or revert to the last-saved version of a file, the autosave file is deleted.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you use assistive technology, such as a screen reader, you may want to disable the Autosave
label: BODY

text: feature so that you don’t lose your place when the file is reloaded.
label: BODY

text: The Autosave feature won’t work in the following cases:
label: BODY

text: A document that has its security changed. You must save the document to re-enable
label: BODY

text: automatic saving of document changes.
label: BODY

text: A document created using the Web Capture feature or extracted from a larger PDF
label: BODY

text: (All tools > Organize Pages > Extract). You must save the document to enable
label: BODY

text: automatic saving of changes.
label: BODY

text: A document displayed in a web browser or incorporated into a container document
label: BODY

text: that supports Object Linking and Embedding (OLE). This document appears outside
label: BODY

text: the default file system and cannot support automatic saving.
label: BODY

text: Recover lost changes
label: BODY

text: To prevent lost changes after an unexpected interruption, enable the Autosave feature, which
label: BODY

text: is the default setting.
label: BODY

text: Set up automatic saving
label: H2

text: 1.In the Preferences dialog box under Categories, select Documents.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Automatically Save Document Changes To Temporary File Every xx Minutes (1-
label: BODY

text: 99), and specify the number of minutes.
label: BODY

text: Recover lost changes after an unexpected shutdown
label: H2

text: 1.Start Acrobat or open the file you were working on last.
label: BODY

text: 2.When prompted, click Yes to open the autosave file or files. If multiple files were open,
label: BODY

text: Acrobat opens all of the files for you.
label: BODY

text: 3.Save the file or files with the same names as the files you were originally working on.
label: BODY

text: To control changes and quality trade-oﬀs, use PDF Optimizer in Acrobat Pro, which makes
label: BODY

text: more options available. You can also easily convert from other file formats to PDF using our
label: BODY

text: online tools such as Word to PDF and Convert PDF.
label: BODY

text: You can easily convert your PDF files into Microsoft Word (DOC or DOCX) using Adobe
label: BODY

text: Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to DOCX
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the global bar, select Convert.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the left pane, Select DOCX from the drop-down menu next to Microsoft Word.
label: BODY

text: Then select Convert to DOCX.
label: BODY

text: 4.In the Save asdialog, select a location where you want to save the file and then
label: BODY

text: select Save.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to DOC
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the global bar, select Convert.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the left pane, Select DOC from the drop-down menu next to Microsoft Word.
label: BODY

text: Then select Convert to DOC.
label: BODY

text: 4.In the Save asdialog, select a location where you want to save the file and then
label: BODY

text: select Save.
label: BODY

text: For PDF to Word conversion settings, go to File format options for PDF export.
label: BODY

text: You can easily convert your PDF files into Microsoft Powerpoint (PPT/PPTX) using Adobe
label: BODY

text: Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to PPTX
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Convert from the globar bar.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the Convert menu in the left pane, select Microsoft PowerPoint PPTX.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Convert to PPTX.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the dialog, select the location where you want to save the file and, if necessary,
label: BODY

text: change the file name.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Save.
label: BODY

text: File format opƟons for PDF export in Acrobat
label: BODY

text: To convert a PDF to different file formats, select Convert from the global bar. Each file format
label: BODY

text: includes unique conversion settings. Alternatively, you can use the Export a PDF tool from
label: BODY

text: the All tools menu.
label: BODY

text: Adobe PDF options
label: H2

text: You can resave PDFs as optimized PDFs using settings in the PDF Optimizer dialog box.
label: BODY

text: The PDF Optimizer lets you change the compatibility version of your PDFs so they can be
label: BODY

text: viewed using older versions of Acrobat or Acrobat Reader. When you change the
label: BODY

text: compatibility setting, newer features may be unavailable in the PDF. For an explanation of
label: BODY

text: each compatibility setting, view PDF compatibility levels.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you want to use the same settings every time you convert PDFs to a particular format,
label: BODY

text: specify those settings in the Preferences dialog box. In the Convert From PDF panel, select a
label: BODY

text: file format from the list and select Edit Settings. You can select the Defaults at the top of
label: BODY

text: the Save as Settings dialog box to revert to the default settings.
label: BODY

text: Image conversion settings
label: H2

text: JPEG and JPEG 2000 conversion settings
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select All tools > Export a PDF and select Image format. From the drop-down
label: BODY

text: menu next to Image format, select the format you want your image to be. You
label: BODY

text: get JPEG and JPEG 2000 options. Select the settings icon to change the export
label: BODY

text: preferences.
label: BODY

text: File settings
label: H2

text: Grayscale/Color: Specifies a compression setting that balances file size with image
label: BODY

text: quality. The smaller the file, the lesser the image quality.
label: BODY

text: Tile Size: Divides the image being compressed into tiles of the given size. (If the image
label: BODY

text: height or width is not an even multiple of the tile size, partial tiles are used on the
label: BODY

text: edges.) Image data for each tile is individually compressed and can be individually
label: BODY

text: decompressed. The default value of 256 is recommended. This option is available only
label: BODY

text: for JPEG 2000 format.
label: BODY

text: Format: Determines how the file is displayed. Available only in JPEG format. It
label: BODY

text: provides the following options:
label: BODY

text: Baseline (Standard): Displays the image when it has fully downloaded. This
label: BODY

text: JPEG format is recognizable to most web browsers.
label: BODY

text: Baseline (Optimized): Optimizes color quality of the image and produces
label: BODY

text: smaller file sizes but is not supported by all web browsers.
label: BODY

text: Progressive (3 scans-5 scans): Downloads the image first as a low-resolution
label: BODY

text: image, with incremental quality improvements as downloading continues.
label: BODY

text: Color management
label: H2

text: RGB/CMYK/Grayscale
label: H3

text: Specifies the type of color management to be applied to the output file and whether to
label: BODY

text: embed an ICC profile.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: If you use the Export To or Export All Images command on a PDF that contains JPEG and
label: BODY

text: JPEG 2000 images, and export the content to JPEG or JPEG 2000 format, the resulting image
label: BODY

text: may look different when opened in Acrobat. This can happen if the images have a color
label: BODY

text: profile included at the page level but not inside the image data. In this case, Acrobat cannot
label: BODY

text: bring the page-level color profile into the resulting saved image.
label: BODY

text: Conversion
label: H2

text: Colorspace/Resolution
label: H3

text: Specifies a color space and resolution for the output file. You can let Acrobat determine these
label: BODY

text: settings automatically. To convert color images in the file to shades of gray, choose Grayscale.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: Higher resolutions, such as 2400 pixels per inch (ppi), are suitable only for small page sizes
label: BODY

text: (up to 6.826 inches or 173.380 millimeters).
label: BODY

text: PDF to PNG conversion settings
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select All tools > Export a PDF and select Image format. From the drop-down
label: BODY

text: menu next to Image format, select PNG. Select the settings icon to change the export
label: BODY

text: preferences.
label: BODY

text: PNG format is useful for images that are used on the web.
label: BODY

text: File settings
label: H2

text: Interlace
label: BODY

text: Specifies if the image is interlaced. None creates an image that displays in a web browser only
label: BODY

text: after downloading is complete. Adam7 creates an image that displays low-resolution versions
label: BODY

text: in a browser while the full image file is downloading. Adam7 can make downloading time
label: BODY

text: seem shorter and assures viewers that downloading is in progress; however, it increases file
label: BODY

text: size.
label: BODY

text: Filter: Lets you select a filtering algorithm.
label: BODY

text: None: Compresses the image without a filter. Recommended for indexed-color
label: BODY

text: and Bitmap-mode images.
label: BODY

text: Sub: Optimizes the compression of images with even horizontal patterns or blends.
label: BODY

text: Up: Optimizes the compression of images with even vertical patterns.
label: BODY

text: Average: Optimizes the compression of low-level noise by averaging the color values
label: BODY

text: of adjacent pixels.
label: BODY

text: Paeth: Optimizes the compression of low-level noise by reassigning adjacent color
label: BODY

text: values.
label: BODY

text: Adaptive: Applies the filtering algorithm—Sub, Up, Average, or Paeth—best suited for
label: BODY

text: the image. Select Adaptive if you are unsure of which filter to use.
label: BODY

text: Color management
label: H2

text: RGB/Grayscale
label: H3

text: Specifies the type of color management for the output file and whether to embed an ICC
label: BODY

text: profile.
label: BODY

text: Conversion
label: H2

text: Colorspace/Resolution
label: H3

text: Specifies a color space and resolution for the output file. You can let Acrobat determine these
label: BODY

text: settings automatically. To convert color images in the file to shades of gray, choose Grayscale.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: Higher resolutions, such as 2400 ppi, are suitable only for small page sizes (up to 6.826 inches
label: BODY

text: or 173.380 millimeters).
label: BODY

text: PDF to TIFF conversion settings
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select All tools > Export a PDF and select Image format. From the drop-down
label: BODY

text: menu next to Image format, select TIFF. Select the settings icon to change the export
label: BODY

text: preferences.
label: BODY

text: TIFF is a flexible bitmap image format supported by virtually all paint, image-editing, and
label: BODY

text: page-layout applications. Resolution is determined automatically.
label: BODY

text: File settings
label: H2

text: Monochrome
label: H3

text: Specifies a compression format. CCITTG4 is the default and generally produces the smallest
label: BODY

text: file size. ZIP compression also produces a small file.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: Some applications cannot open TIFF files that are saved with JPEG or ZIP compression. In
label: BODY

text: these cases, LZW compression is recommended.
label: BODY

text: Color management
label: H2

text: RGB/CMYK/Grayscale/Other
label: H3

text: Specifies the type of color management for the output file.
label: BODY

text: Conversion
label: H2

text: Colorspace/Resolution
label: H3

text: Specifies a color space and resolution for the output file. You can let Acrobat determine these
label: BODY

text: settings automatically. To convert color images in the file to shades of gray, choose Grayscale.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: Higher resolutions, such as 2400 ppi, are suitable only for small page sizes (up to 6.826 inches
label: BODY

text: or 173.380 millimeters).
label: BODY

text: PDF to MicrosoŌ Word conversion seƫngs
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select All tools > Export a PDF and select Microsoft Word. From the drop-down
label: BODY

text: menu next to Microsoft Word, select the format you want your document to be in. You
label: BODY

text: get DOC and DOCX options. Select the settings icon to change the export preferences.
label: BODY

text: Layout Settings
label: BODY

text: Retain Flowing Text: Speciﬁes that text ﬂow must be retained.
label: BODY

text: Retain Page Layout: Speciﬁes that page layout must be retained.
