text: Convert PDF to PostScript or Encapsulated PostScript (EPS)
label: H1

text: You can export a PDF to PostScript for printing and prepress applications. The PostScript file
label: BODY

text: includes full DSC (Document Structuring Conventions) comments and other advanced
label: BODY

text: information preserved by Adobe Acrobat Distiller. You can also create an EPS file from any PDF
label: BODY

text: for placement or opening in other applications. The options available depend on whether
label: BODY

text: you're converting a document to PostScript or EPS. To convert PDF to PS or EPS format:
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the global bar, select Convert.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select the drop-down menu next to Other format, as required, select EPS or PS.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Convert to EPS or Convert to PS. The options will be displayed based on your
label: BODY

text: choice in the previous step.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the Save asdialog, select a location where you want to save the file and then
label: BODY

text: select Save.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you create EPS files for separations in Acrobat Pro, all image color spaces should be CMYK.
label: BODY

text: PDF to PS and EPS conversion seƫngs
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select All tools > Export a PDF and select Other format. From the drop-down menu
label: BODY

text: next to Other format, select PS or EPS. Select the settings icon to change the export
label: BODY

text: preferences.
label: BODY

text: Printer Description File
label: BODY

text: The PostScript Printer Description (PPD) provides the necessary information to format a
label: BODY

text: PostScript file correctly for a particular output device. Device Independent creates only
label: BODY

text: composite (not color-separated) PostScript or EPS files. Acrobat Default provides a starting
label: BODY

text: point and reference for creating all types of PostScript and restores all default settings for the
label: BODY

text: conversion. Adobe PDF 7.0 is compatible with most devices. This option is available only in
label: BODY

text: PostScript (PS) format.
label: BODY

text: ASCII or Binary
label: BODY

text: Specifies the output format of image data. Binary output yields smaller files, but not all
label: BODY

text: workflows can accommodate binary output.
label: BODY

text: PostScript
label: BODY

text: Specifies the level of PostScript compatibility. Use Language Level 3 only if the target output
label: BODY

text: device supports it. Language Level 2 is suitable for EPS files placed in another document and
label: BODY

text: color-separated as part of that document. Use Language Level 2 for EPS files that you import
label: BODY

text: into Microsoft applications.
label: BODY

text: Font Inclusion
label: BODY

text: Specifies the fonts to be included in the PostScript. Embedded fonts are taken from the PDF;
label: BODY

text: the referenced fonts are taken from the computer.
label: BODY

text: Include Comments
label: BODY

text: Preserves the appearance of comments in the resulting PostScript file.
label: BODY

text: Convert True Type to Type 1
label: BODY

text: Converts TrueType fonts to Type 1 fonts in the resulting PostScript file.
label: BODY

text: Include Preview
label: BODY

text: Specifies if a TIFF preview is created for the resulting EPS file. This option isn't available when
label: BODY

text: saving as PostScript.
label: BODY

text: Page Range
label: BODY

text: Specifies the pages you want to export. When you export files to EPS output, each page in the
label: BODY

text: range is saved as a separate EPS file.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to Text and XML 1.0
label: H1

text: Convert PDF to XML 1.0
label: H2

text: To export a file in XML format, go to All Tools > Export a PDF. Select other format, then the
label: BODY

text: drop-down next to other format, and then select XML 1.0.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to text
label: H2

text: To export a file in text format, go to All Tools > Export a PDF. Select other format, then the
label: BODY

text: drop-down next to other format, and then select TXT.
label: BODY

text: PDF to Text and XML 1.0 conversion settings
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat, select All tools > Export a PDF and select Other format. From the drop-down
label: BODY

text: menu next to Other format, select TXT or XML 1.0. Select the settings icon to change the
label: BODY

text: export preferences.
label: BODY

text: Output file settings
label: H2

text: Encoding
label: H3

text: Refers to the binary values, based on international standards, used to represent the text
label: BODY

text: characters. UTF-8 is a Unicode representation of characters using one or more 8-bit bytes per
label: BODY

text: character. UTF-16 represents characters using 16-bit bytes. ISO-Latin-1 is an 8-bit
label: BODY

text: representation of characters that is a superset of ASCII. UCS-4 is a Universal Character Set
label: BODY

text: coded in four octets. HTML/ASCII is a 7-bit representation of characters developed by ANSI.
label: BODY

text: Use mapping table default uses the default character encoding defined in mapping tables,
label: BODY

text: which appear in the Plug-ins/SaveAsXML/MappingTables folder. These mapping tables
label: BODY

text: specify many characteristics of how the data is output, including the following default
label: BODY

text: character encodings: UTF-8 (Save as XML or HTML 4.0.1) and HTML/ASCII (Save as HTML
label: BODY

text: Generate Bookmarks
label: H3

text: Generates bookmark links to content for HTML or XML documents. Links are placed at the
label: BODY

text: beginning of the resulting HTML or XML document.
label: BODY

text: Generate Tags For Untagged Files
label: H3

text: Generates tags for files not already tagged, such as PDFs created using Acrobat 4.0 or earlier.
label: BODY

text: If this option isn't selected, untagged files are not converted.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: Tags are applied only as part of the conversion process and are discarded after the
label: BODY

text: conversion. This is not a method for creating tagged PDFs from legacy files
label: BODY

text: Image file settings
label: H2

text: Generate Images
label: H3

text: Controls how images are converted. Converted image files are referenced from within XML
label: BODY

text: and HTML documents.
label: BODY

text: Use Sub-Folder
label: H3

text: Specifies the folder in which to store generated images. The default is Images.
label: BODY

text: Use Prefix
label: H3

text: Specifies the prefix added to the image filenames if you have several versions of the same
label: BODY

text: image file. Filenames assigned to images have the format filename_img_#.
label: BODY

text: Output Format
label: H3

text: Specifies the final format of images. The default is JPG.
label: BODY

text: Downsample To
label: H3

text: Downsamples image files to the specified resolution. If you don't select this option, image files
label: BODY

text: have the same resolution as the source file. Image files are never upsampled.
label: BODY

text: You can easily convert PDF files to JPEG images using Adobe Acrobat. You can also convert
label: BODY

text: your PDF files into PNG or TIFF file formats using Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to JPEG or JPEG 2000
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Convert from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the Convert menu in the left pane, select Image format, and then from the
label: BODY

text: drop-down menu, select JPEG or JPEG 2000.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Convert to JPEG or Convert to JPEG 2000. Different options are shown based
label: BODY

text: on your selection in the previous step.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the dialog, select the location where you want to save the file and, if necessary,
label: BODY

text: change the file name.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Save.
label: BODY

text: Each page in the PDF is saved as separate JPEG files.
label: BODY

text: For PDF to JPEG or PDF to JPEG 2000 conversion settings, go to File format options for PDF
label: BODY

text: export.
label: BODY

text: You can easily convert your PDF files into TIFF images using Adobe Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to TIFF
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Convert from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the Convert menu in the left pane, select Image format, and then from the drop-
label: BODY

text: down menu, select TIFF.
label: BODY

text: 4.elect Convert to TIFF.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the dialog, select the location where you want to save the file and, if necessary,
label: BODY

text: change the file name.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Save.
label: BODY

text: Each page in the PDF is saved as separate TIFF files.
label: BODY

text: For PDF to TIFF conversion settings, go to File format options for PDF export.
label: BODY

text: You can easily convert your PDF files into PNG images using Adobe Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Convert PDF to PNG
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Convert from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the Convert menu in the left pane, select Image format, and then from the drop-
label: BODY

text: down menu, select PNG.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Convert to PNG.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the dialog, select the location where you want to save the file and, if necessary,
label: BODY

text: change the file name.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Save.
label: BODY

text: Each page in the PDF is saved as separate PNG files.
label: BODY

text: For PDF to PNG conversion settings, go to File format options for PDF export.
label: BODY

text: Overview
label: H3

text: Acrobat allows you to export images and text selections from a PDF to different file formats.
label: BODY

text: Each format uses unique conversion settings when you export text or image selections.
label: BODY

text: Export images from PDFs
label: H3

text: Besides exporting the entire document or each page to a different format, you can export
label: BODY

text: each image in a PDF to a separate image file.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: H3

text: You can export raster images, but not vector objects.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat and select Convert from the top tools bar. Alternatively,
label: BODY

text: from the All tools menu, select Export a PDF.
label: BODY

text: The various formats to which you can export the PDF file are displayed.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the Convert panel, select image format and then from the drop-down, select the
label: BODY

text: desired image file format.
label: BODY

text: 3.Optional) To configure the conversion settings, select Settings and then modify
label: BODY

text: the settings as required. Once done, select OK.
label: BODY

text: 4.(Optional) To configure the image settings:
label: BODY

text: 1.Select Export all Images and then select Settings
label: BODY

text: 2.In the dialog that appears, specify the File Settings, Color
label: BODY

text: Management, Conversion, and Extraction settings for the file type.
label: BODY

text: 3.For Exclude images smaller than, select the smallest size of the image to be
label: BODY

text: extracted. Select No Limit to extract all images.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Ok.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you do not select the Export All Images option, all pages within the PDF are saved in the
label: BODY

text: selected image file format.
label: BODY

text: 5.Select Convert to JPEG.
label: BODY

text: 6.In the Save as dialog that appears, select a desired location or select Choose a
label: BODY

text: different folder to select alternate locations.
label: BODY

text: 7.Select Save.
label: BODY

text: It exports only the images from the PDF to the selected image file format. By
label: BODY

text: default, the source filename is used with the new extension, and the exported
label: BODY

text: file is saved in the same folder as the source file.
label: BODY

text: Export selections from a PDF to another format
label: BODY

text: To export a part of the PDF file into another format, you don’t need to convert the entire file
label: BODY

text: and then extract the relevant content. You can select text in a PDF file and save it in one of the
label: BODY

text: supported formats: DOCX, DOC, XLSX, RTF, XML, HTML, or CSV.
label: BODY

text: 1.Use the Select tool and mark the content to save.
label: BODY

text: 2.Right-click the selected text and choose Export Selection As.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select a format from the Save As Type list and select Save.
label: BODY

text: Select and copy text and images
label: H1

text: The Select tool lets you select horizontal and vertical text or columns of text, images,
label: BODY

text: vector objects, and tables in a PDF. The Select tool recognizes the type of content under
label: BODY

text: the cursor and changes automatically. You can use the Copy, Copy with Formatting, Export
label: BODY

text: Selection As, and Paste commands to copy the selected text into another application. Note
label: BODY

text: the following:
label: BODY

text: If you’re unable to select text, the text may be part of an image. In Acrobat, select All
label: BODY

text: tools > Scan & OCR, then select In this file under RECOGNIZE TEXT to export image
label: BODY

text: text to text that can be selected.
label: BODY

text: If the Cut, Copy, Copy with Formatting, and Paste commands are unavailable when
label: BODY

text: you select the text, the author may have set restrictions to copying text.
label: BODY

text: If the text you copy uses a font that isn’t available on your system, the font is
label: BODY

text: substituted with a close match or default font.
label: BODY

text: Select text and images
label: H3

text: 1.Select the Select tool , and hover over an empty part of the page. Alternatively,
label: BODY

text: press Ctrl (Windows) or Command (macOS); the pointer changes to display a
label: BODY

text: rectangle.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag the pointer and draw a rectangle to select a part of the page.
label: BODY

text: Select a column of text
label: H3

text: 1.Using the Select tool , move the pointer toward a column of text. When the
label: BODY

text: pointer changes to a vertical bar, the Select tool is in column select mode.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: You can force column select mode by pressing Alt as you drag a rectangle over the
label: BODY

text: column of text.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag a rectangle over the column of text. To select text across multiple columns, drag
label: BODY

text: from the beginning of the text in one column to the end of the text you want to select.
label: BODY

text: Select all the text on a page
label: H3

text: 1.Select View from the upper left (macOS) or select the hamburger menu on the upper
label: BODY

text: left and then select view (Windows). Select Page display > Single-page view.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select four times repeatedly in the text area. This method selects all the text on the
label: BODY

text: page regardless of the page layout.
label: BODY

text: Note:If you choose any other page layout, all the text in the document is selected.
label: BODY

text: Copy selected text
label: H3

text: 1.Use the Select tool to select any amount of text on the page.
label: BODY

text: 2.Right-click on the selected text, and then select Copy.
label: BODY

text: You can paste the copied text into comments, bookmarks, and documents authored in
label: BODY

text: other applications.
label: BODY

text: Paste copied text and images
label: H3

text: 1.Open the PDF in which you want to paste the selected text or image.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the area where you want to paste the text or image.
label: BODY

text: 3.(Windows) Press Ctrl + V.
label: BODY

text: (macOS) Press command + V.
label: BODY

text: Convert selected content to other formats
label: H1

text: You convert selected content to other formats by exporting a selection. For example, you can
label: BODY

text: select content and save it as a Word document, Excel spreadsheet, or comma-separated
label: BODY

text: values.
label: BODY

text: 1.Select the Select tool . Press Ctrl (Windows) or Command (macOS) to create a
label: BODY

text: rectangular selection.
label: BODY

text: 2.Drag a rectangle over the content to copy. If you’re selecting text in columns,
label: BODY

text: press Alt (Windows).
label: BODY

text: Note: To select tables that exceed one page, try changing the page display to Single
label: BODY

text: Page before selecting the tables. Then select View > Page Display > Enable Scrolling.
label: BODY

text: 3.Right-click the selection, select Export Selection As, and specify a filename.
label: BODY

text: 4.Depending on the nature of the content, in the Save As Type, select one of the
label: BODY

text: following:
label: BODY

text: •Word Document or Word 97-2003
label: BODY

text: Saves the content as a Word file.
label: BODY

text: •Excel Workbook, XML Spreadsheet, or CSV
label: BODY

text: Saves the content as a table.
label: BODY

text: •Rich Text Format or HTML
label: BODY

text: Saves the content as an RTF or HTML file.
label: BODY

text: Note: To copy a table in RTF, drag the selected table into an open document in the
label: BODY

text: target application.
label: BODY

text: •PowerPoint
label: BODY

text: Saves the content as a PowerPoint (.pptx) file.
label: BODY

text: Fill and Sign PDF Forms
label: BODY

text: You can easily fill, sign, and share your documents using Acrobat's Fill & Sign tool. Types
label: BODY

text: of PDF forms
label: BODY

text: Types of PDF forms
label: H1

text: Interactive forms: These contain fields that you can select and fill in.
label: BODY

text: Flat forms: These do not have interactive fields. It could be a paper form or PDF that
label: BODY

text: hasn’t been optimized for form filling. The Fill & Sign tool automatically detects the
label: BODY

text: form fields like text fields, comb fields, checkboxes, and radio buttons. You can
label: BODY

text: manually add text and other symbols anywhere on the form using the Fill & Sign tool if
label: BODY

text: required.
label: BODY

text: You can complete the forms by entering information and adding your signatures. Acrobat
label: BODY

text: also allows you to send your completed forms to others and securely save them in Adobe
label: BODY

text: cloud storage.
label: BODY

text: Fill and sign PDF forms
label: H2

text: To complete and sign PDF forms, open the form in Acrobat and then select E-Sign from the
label: BODY

text: global bar. Alternatively, you can select All tools >Fill & Sign.
label: BODY

text: It displays the Fill & Sign tools in the left pane. You can now fill in the form fields and sign the
label: BODY

text: form using the sign tools described in the following topics.
label: BODY

text: To fill text fields:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the left panel, select Fill in form fields , and then select the field where you
label: BODY

text: want to add text.
label: BODY

text: It displays a text field along with a toolbar.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select the text field again and enter your text.
label: BODY

text: 3.To reposition the text box to align it with the text field, select the textbox and hover
label: BODY

text: over it. Once you see a plus icon with arrows, move the textbox to the desired
label: BODY

text: position.
label: BODY

text: 4.To edit the text, select the text box. Once you see the cursor and keypad, edit the text
label: BODY

text: and then click elsewhere to enter.
label: BODY

text: 5.To change the text size, select A or A as required.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: Resize the first annotation you place to fit the check box or radio button in the
label: BODY

text: document, and the next annotations you add will be of the same size and will fit the
label: BODY

text: rest of the box/circle fields.
label: BODY

text: 6.To change the text color, select the color from the quick toolbar and select a desired
label: BODY

text: color from the color palette.
label: BODY

text: The default color for signatures is black. To change the color of signatures, you must
label: BODY

text: deselect the Keep signatures black checkbox.
label: BODY

text: 7.To change the text style from normal to combed, from the textbox menu,
label: BODY

text: select ellipsis ()> Character spacing.
label: BODY

text: It changes the text style from normal to combed. To increase or decrease the spacing, you can
label: BODY

text: select the blue arrow icon and then drag it as desired.
label: BODY

text: 8.Once done, select the next field space and then enter your text in the text box. Use the
label: BODY

text: formatting options as desired.
label: BODY

text: Repeat the step to fill all the required fields in the form.
label: BODY

text: To fill radio option fields:
label: BODY

text: 1.Hover over the field with the radio option.
label: BODY

text: It automatically displays the default checkmark or the selected radio field symbol.

text: 2.Select the radio option field to enter the symbol.
label: BODY

text: 3.To change the symbol, select the field again, and then from the menu, ellipsis () and
label: BODY

text: then select another symbol.
label: BODY

text: It marks the field with the selected symbol.

text: To add signature and initials:
label: BODY

text: 1.Create your signature and initials if not already done. To do so:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the Quick action toolbar, select Add your signature or initials
label: BODY

text: 2.To add a signature, select Add signature. In the dialog that appears, type or
label: BODY

text: draw your signature and then select Done.
label: BODY

text: 3.To add your initials, select Add initials. In the dialog that appears, type or draw
label: BODY

text: your initials and then select Done.
label: BODY

text: Note: You may also add an image as your signature or initials. To add an existing
label: BODY

text: image, tap the image icon from the top menu. To take a new picture to be added as
label: BODY

text: your signature, tap the camera icon and follow through with the workflow.
label: BODY

text: 2.To add a signature:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the Quick actions toolbar, select Add your signature or initials
label: BODY

text: Select Add Signature.
label: BODY

text: 2.Your signature appears in the field.
label: BODY

text: Note: Once you add a signature or initial to a form and save it, you cannot edit
label: BODY

text: it again.
label: BODY

text: 3.To adjust the placement of your signature, hover over the signature till you see
label: BODY

text: a plus icon, and then click and move the signature as desired.
label: BODY

text: 4.To adjust the size of your signature, hover over the blue circle at the corner and
label: BODY

text: then hold and drag it as desired.
label: BODY

text: Caution:
label: BODY

text: Once you add a signature or an initial to a form and save it, you cannot edit it again.
label: BODY

text: 3.To add your initials:
label: BODY

text: 1.From the Quick actions toolbar, select Add your signature or initials
label: BODY

text: Select Add Initials. Your initials appear in the field.
label: BODY

text: 2.To adjust the placement of your signature, hover over it until you see a plus
label: BODY

text: icon, and then click and move the signature as desired.
label: BODY

text: 3.To adjust the size of your signature, hover over the blue circle at the corner and
label: BODY

text: then hold and drag it as desired.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you want to use an image as your signature or initials:
label: BODY

text: Sign your name in black ink on a clean, blank sheet of white paper. Sign in the middle
label: BODY

text: of the paper so you don't photograph or scan the edges.
label: BODY

text: Photograph or scan your signature. If you are taking a picture of your signature, make
label: BODY

text: sure that the page is lit and that no shadows fall across the signature.
label: BODY

text: Transfer the photo or scan to your computer. Acrobat/Reader accepts JPG, JPEG, PNG,
label: BODY

text: GIF, TIFF, TIF, and BMP files. You do not need to crop the image. Acrobat/Reader
label: BODY

text: imports just the signature if the photo or scan is fairly clean.

text: Fill in PDF Forms
label: H1

text: Is the form fillable?
label: H2

text: Not all forms are fillable. Sometimes form creators don’t convert their PDFs to
label: BODY

text: interactive fillable forms. Or, they intentionally design a form that you can fill in only by hand
label: BODY

text: or with the Fill & Sign tool. These non-interactive forms are called flat forms.
label: BODY

text: Fill in interactive forms
label: H2

text: An interactive form contains fields that you can select or fill in.
label: BODY

text: 1.If necessary, select either the Hand Tool or the Select Tool from the context menu of
label: BODY

text: the page (right-click on the page to open the context menu).
label: BODY

text: The pointer changes to a different icon as you move it over a field. For example,
label: BODY

text: the Hand tool changes to an I-beam when you can type text into the form field.
label: BODY

text: Some text fields are dynamic, meaning that they automatically resize to accommodate
label: BODY

text: the amount of data you enter and can span across pages.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select anywhere in the form to access options, such as radio buttons. Select inside a
label: BODY

text: text field to type.
label: BODY

text: Press Tab to move forward or Shift+Tab to move backward.
label: BODY

text: 3.When finished, submit the form to either send the data to a server or create an email
label: BODY

text: to send the data.
label: BODY

text: Auto-Complete forms (interactive forms
label: BODY

text: only)
label: BODY

text: The Auto-Complete feature stores any entries that you type in an interactive form field. Auto-
label: BODY

text: Complete then suggests or even automatically enters responses that match your typing in
label: BODY

text: other form fields. The suggestions appear in a pop-up menu, from which you can select a
label: BODY

text: match. The Auto-Complete feature is off by default, so you must enable it in the forms
label: BODY

text: preferences if you want to use it.
label: BODY

text: To remove an entry from the Auto-Complete memory, such as a misspelled entry that you
label: BODY

text: found and corrected later, edit the list in the preferences.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The forms preferences apply to the way that the application handles open forms as you work.
label: BODY

text: The preferences aren’t saved with the PDF forms themselves.
label: BODY

text: Enable the Auto-Complete option
label: H2

text: 1.From the hamburger menu, select Preferences (Windows®), or select Acrobat
label: BODY

text: / Acrobat Reader > Preferences (macOS).
label: BODY

text: 2.In the Preferences dialog, select Forms as the preference category.
label: BODY

text: 3.Under Auto-Complete, choose Basic or Advanced from the menu.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Remember Numerical Data if you want the Auto-Complete memory to store
label: BODY

text: numbers that you type into forms.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: When you select an option in the Auto-Complete menu, a description of how it affects
label: BODY

text: the Auto-Complete behavior appears in the text area below.
label: BODY

text: Delete an entry from the Auto-Complete memory
label: H2

text: 1.Open the Preferences dialog. From the hamburger menu,
label: BODY

text: select Preferences (Windows®), or select Acrobat / Acrobat
label: BODY

text: Reader > Preferences (macOS).
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Forms on the left.
label: BODY

text: 3.Click Edit Entry List under Auto-Complete.
label: BODY

text: 4.In the Auto-Complete Entry List dialog box, do one of the following, and then
label: BODY

text: select Yes to confirm:
label: BODY

text: To remove all entries, select Remove All.
label: BODY

text: To remove some of the entries, select the entries and click Remove. (Shift-
label: BODY

text: select to select multiple adjacent entries; Ctrl-select to select multiple
label: BODY

text: nonadjacent entries.)
label: BODY

text: Change flat forms to fillable (Acrobat Pro)
label: H1

text: You can change a flat form to a fillable form by either using the Prepare Form tool or
label: BODY

text: enabling the Fill & Sign tools. Acrobat and Acrobat Reader users can use the Fill & Sign tool
label: BODY

text: to fill in flat forms.
label: BODY

text: Interactive form
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: document.
label: BODY

text: Flat form
label: BODY

text: To enable the Fill & Sign tools, from the hamburger menu (File menu in macOS)
label: BODY

text: choose Save As Other > Acrobat Reader Extended PDF > Enable More Tools (includes
label: BODY

text: Form Fill-in & Save).
label: BODY

text: The tools are enabled for the current form only. When you create a different form, redo this
label: BODY

text: task to enable Acrobat Reader users to use the tools.

text: Save forms
label: H1

text: To save the completed form, choose Save As from the hamburger menu (File > Save
label: BODY

text: As in macOS) and rename the file.
label: BODY

text: To remove extended Acrobat Reader features, choose Save A Copy (File > Save A
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: following depending upon your operating system:

text: (Includes Form Fill-in & Save)

text: macOS: File > Save As Other > Acrobat Reader Extended PDF > Enable More Tools

text: (Includes Form Fill-in & Save).

text: Print forms

text: 1.Select Print this file from the upper right.

text: 2.Choose an appropriate printer in the Print dialog box.

text: 3.In the Comments And Forms menu, choose one of the following, and then select OK:

text: Text tool.

text: 1.Choose Tools > Prepare a form. In the Fields side panel, choose Clear Form from the

text: You can sign a document to attest to its contents or approve the document. This document
label: BODY

text: explains how to sign a document or agreement using Acrobat or Reader desktop application.
label: BODY

text: To sign a PDF document or form, you can type, draw, or insert an image of your handwritten
label: BODY

text: signature. You can also add text, such as your name, company, title, or date. When you save
label: BODY

text: the document, the signature and text become part of the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: You can also capture a picture of your signature on mobile using Adobe Acrobat Reader mobile
label: BODY

text: app and save it in Adobe cloud storage so that it's synced and available for use across your
label: BODY

text: desktop and other mobile devices.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF document. Select E-sign from the global bar.
label: BODY

text: 2.Create your signature and initials if not already done. To do so:
label: BODY

text: 1.To add a signature, select Add signature. In the dialog that appears, type, draw,
label: BODY

text: or add an image of your signature and then select Done.
label: BODY

text: 2.To add your initials, select Add initials. In the dialog that appears, type, draw, or
label: BODY

text: add an image of your initials and then select Done.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select your signature.
label: BODY

text: 4.The form fields are detected automatically. Hover the mouse over a field to display a
label: BODY

text: blue box. Click anywhere in the blue box, the cursor will be placed at the right position
label: BODY

text: automatically. Type your text to fill the field.
label: BODY

text: To fill the PDF form with your desired color, from the Quick actions toolbar, select the Color
label: BODY

text: icon and then select a color.
label: BODY

text: By default, the signature color is black. To retain the default color of the signature, make sure
label: BODY

text: the Keep signatures black option is unchecked.
label: BODY

text: 5.If you've already added your signature or initials, just select it from the Sign options,
label: BODY

text: and then click at the place in the PDF where you want to add your signature. Skip to
label: BODY

text: the next step.
label: BODY

text: If you are signing for the first time, you see the Signature or Initials panel. Below is an example
label: BODY

text: of the Signature panel.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Apply, and then click on the place in the PDF where you want to place the
label: BODY

text: signature or initial.
label: BODY

text: 7.To move the placed signature or initial, select the field to highlight it and then use
label: BODY

text: the arrow keys. To resize or delete the field, use the options in the field toolbar.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: If you want to use an image as your signature:
label: BODY

text: Sign your name in black ink on a clean, blank sheet of white paper. Sign in the middle
label: BODY

text: of the paper so you don't photograph or scan the edges.
label: BODY

text: Photograph or scan your signature. If you are taking a picture of your signature, make
label: BODY

text: sure that the page is lit and that no shadows fall across the signature.
label: BODY

text: Transfer the photo or scan to your computer. Acrobat/Reader accepts JPG, JPEG, PNG,
label: BODY

text: GIF, TIFF, TIF, and BMP files. You do not need to crop the image. Acrobat/Reader
label: BODY

text: imports just the signature if the photo or scan is fairly clean.
label: BODY

text: Sign an agreement

label: BODY

text: Reader desktop application. You will see a notification that an agreement has been shared

text: with you for signing.

text: You can sign the agreement using one of the following two ways:

text: 1.Go to Acrobat or Acrobat Reader Home and then from under Agreements,

text: It takes you to the Adobe Acrobat Sign page where all the agreements shared or
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: shown below.

label: BODY

text: the link opens the web browser on your mobile device where you can draw
label: BODY

text: or select an image of your signature.

text: Save: When this check box is selected, and you're signed in to Acrobat
label: BODY

text: Reader or Acrobat, the added signature is saved securely in Adobe cloud
label: BODY

text: storage for reuse.

text: 5.Once you complete all the fields and sign, select Click To Sign.

text: 1.Select the link of the agreement received in your email for signing. The agreement

text: opens in a web browser.

text: •Type: Type your name in the field. You can choose from a small selection of signature

text: styles; click Change Style to view a different style.

label: BODY

text: your signature.

text: 1.Open a PDF in Acrobat.

text: Overview of generative AI features
label: H1

text: Use the generative AI features in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader to quickly scan through
label: BODY

text: lengthy, complex PDF content and get answers or generate a summary.
label: BODY

text: Note: The generative AI features in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader support English, French,
label: BODY

text: German, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, or Japanese. To understand the governing terms,
label: BODY

text: review Adobe's Generative AI User Guidelines. To understand Adobe's data handling
label: BODY

text: practices, see Content usage and handling practices.
label: BODY

text: The AI-powered features in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader support multiple document types,
label: BODY

text: including PDFs, DOCX, PPTX, TXT, and RTF files. AI Assistant supports Microsoft Teams and
label: BODY

text: Zoom meeting transcripts. The capabilities improve comprehension and save time across
label: BODY

text: various document types.
label: BODY

text: AI Assistant quickly gets answers to your questions based on your documents in a
label: BODY

text: comprehensive and informative way. It can analyze multiple documents to uncover
label: BODY

text: similarities, differences, and key patterns. With AI Assistant, you can make targeted requests,
label: BODY

text: such as highlighting the differences between PDF contracts. It links to text and data table
label: BODY

text: sources within the document. It also suggests follow-up questions for you based on the
label: BODY

text: primary question. AI Assistant uses the latest AI language model, GPT 4o, to provide more
label: BODY

text: accurate and clear answers to your queries based on more citations. It can extract information
label: BODY

text: accurately from tables and complex documents.
label: BODY

text: Generative summary automatically provides an outline with headings and summaries to
label: BODY

text: highlight key points in the document. The feature generates key insights that help you easily
label: BODY

text: comprehend the PDF content. For a speedier response, it processes PDF content in chunks
label: BODY

text: and simultaneously streams summaries.
label: BODY

text: You can access the generative AI features in Adobe Acrobat Reader, Adobe Acrobat desktop
label: BODY

text: on both Windows and macOS, on Acrobat online, and within Acrobat extensions for Google
label: BODY

text: Chrome or Microsoft Edge. AI Assistant is also available on phones through Acrobat mobile
label: BODY

text: apps (iOS and Android). It isn't available on iPad or Android tablets.
label: BODY

text: Benefits of generative AI features
label: H2

text: The generative AI features in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader significantly improve
label: BODY

text: comprehension, help you get insights, and produce high-quality content quickly. Here are the
label: BODY

text: main benefits.
label: BODY

text: Improved comprehension: You can better understand complex PDF documents
label: BODY

text: because the features provide insights and more context around the content.
label: BODY

text: Enhanced productivity: Work across multiple PDFs and documents in various formats,
label: BODY

text: including Teams and Zoom meeting transcripts, streamlining your workflow and
label: BODY

text: saving time for higher-priority tasks.
label: BODY

text: Impactful content: You can use the content suggestions that the features generate for
label: BODY

text: impactful emails, presentations, meeting notes, and more.
label: BODY

text: Turn off generative AI features
label: H2

text: The generative AI features in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader are turned on by default. However,
label: BODY

text: you can choose to turn them off, if necessary. If you're an admin, you can revoke access to
label: BODY

text: generative AI features for your team or org by contacting Adobe Customer Care.
label: BODY

text: User Guidelines
label: H2

text: User Guidelines governing your access and use of Acrobat and Acrobat Reader generative AI
label: BODY

text: features are found here.
label: BODY

text: In addition, please always use your judgment to evaluate generated output and any source
label: BODY

text: attributions. Acrobat and Acrobat Reader generative AI features are built upon powerful,
label: BODY

text: emerging large language model technologies that may generate outputs that are inaccurate
label: BODY

text: or misleading, or otherwise reflect content that does not represent Adobe’s views. This is
label: BODY

text: especially true if you try to use these features to generate outputs that are unrelated to your
label: BODY

text: source document.
label: BODY

text: Do not use generative AI features to seek legal, medical, financial, or other kinds of
label: BODY

text: professional advice or any opinions, judgments, or recommendations without conducting
label: BODY

text: your own independent consultation or research. Generative AI features cannot replace
label: BODY

text: advice provided by a qualified professional and do not form any such relationship (for
label: BODY

text: example, an attorney-client relationship).
label: BODY

text: Attributions
label: H2

text: When the AI Assistant analyzes a document, it identifies sentences most likely to support the
label: BODY

text: answer to your question. Attribution can take the form of clickable citations or other helpful
label: BODY

text: cues indicating where generated information came from. However, because the AI Assistant is
label: BODY

text: powered by generative AI models, and the technology is still evolving and not perfect, not all
label: BODY

text: answers are helpful or accurate. As a result, the AI Assistant may not find and display answers
label: BODY

text: to your questions — even when the information is in your document. And rarely, the AI
label: BODY

text: Assistant may provide incorrect attributions. For example, you may receive a clickable citation
label: BODY

text: or cue that takes you to an unrelated section instead of providing helpful information on
label: BODY

text: where the answer came from in the document. Please double-check all AI-generated
label: BODY

text: responses.
label: BODY

text: Please note that in our current version, if the language of the question and response is
label: BODY

text: different than the language of your document, AI Assistant won't provide any attribution. In
label: BODY

text: such scenarios, you can try asking questions in the language of the document to receive
label: BODY

text: clickable citations in the response.
label: BODY

text: Feedback
label: H2

text: We provide a feedback mechanism directly within the AI Assistant to help us improve
label: BODY

text: accuracy and other performance issues. This is an ongoing process, and we will continue to
label: BODY

text: work together with our customers and community to harness the power of this new
label: BODY

text: technology responsibly.
label: BODY

text: Content usage and handling practices
label: H3

text: This FAQ addresses Adobe’s content usage and handling practices specific to improving
label: BODY

text: generative AI capabilities in Adobe Acrobat and Adobe Acrobat Reader. For purposes of this
label: BODY

text: FAQ, references to “generative AI capabilities” are specific to Acrobat AI Assistant and
label: BODY

text: Generative summary only. To learn more about how Adobe may analyze metadata and
label: BODY

text: information about your prompt (for example, question type) and document (for example,
label: BODY

text: number of pages, document structure, document type, and other document statistics) for
label: BODY

text: product improvement purposes in Document Cloud generally, see our content analysis FAQ.
label: BODY

text: For more information about Adobe’s security, privacy, and AI ethics practices, see the Adobe
label: BODY

text: Document Cloud security page (and other materials in our Trust Center), the Adobe Privacy
label: BODY

text: Policy, and the Adobe AI Ethics page, respectively.
label: BODY

text: Will adobe ever look at your content while you’re using generative ai in acrobat and
label: BODY

text: acrobat reader?
label: BODY

text: We do not look at your document, prompt(s), or generated responses except in the instances
label: BODY

text: described below.
label: BODY

text: Reported content, bugs, or vulnerabilities. When you report content (e.g., for being
label: BODY

text: harmful, illegal, offensive, etc.), we investigate it by manually reviewing the document,
label: BODY

text: prompt(s), and generated responses to make adjustments to the service to address the
label: BODY

text: issue.
label: BODY

text: User-Provided Feedback. For Acrobat Individual users* and Acrobat Reader users that
label: BODY

text: provide feedback, you have the option to share with us your document, prompt(s),
label: BODY

text: and generated responses during a document session for product improvement
label: BODY

text: purposes that do not include training a Large Language Model (“LLM”). Examples of
label: BODY

text: product improvement include improving the operability of generative AI in Acrobat
label: BODY

text: and Acrobat Reader, as well as reducing hallucination, bias, and toxicity. If you do not
label: BODY

text: wish to share your content, please uncheck the product improvement checkbox when
label: BODY

text: you first provide feedback on a document.
label: BODY

text: If manual review of your content takes place, a limited group of trained Adobe personnel
label: BODY

text: examine the content within an encrypted repository with access controls.
label: BODY

text: What steps do we take to protect your content when you share it with us as part of
label: BODY

text: providing feedback?
label: BODY

text: When you share your documents, textual prompts, and the generated responses with
label: BODY

text: us when providing feedback, we take steps to filter out personal information by
label: BODY

text: applying data masking procedures to this content (i.e., replacing personal information
label: BODY

text: with predefined categories using Named Entity Recognition, e.g., replacing “John
label: BODY

text: Smith” with “PERSON”) prior to using the content for product improvement.
label: BODY

text: Content is stored for 30 days in an encrypted, siloed, Adobe-controlled environment
label: BODY

text: with strict access controls. You can always contact us via the form in our Privacy
label: BODY

text: Policy if you want us to delete this data sooner, or if you want to opt out of the use of
label: BODY

text: your content to improve generative AI capabilities in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader.
label: BODY

text: If you flag content as being harmful, illegal, or offensive or if you contribute content as
label: BODY

text: feedback, how long do we retain that content?
label: BODY

text: The flagged content is only retained for 30 days unless we have other legal reasons to retain it

text: Do acrobat’s generative ai features process my documents when i launch the application or
label: BODY

text: open a file in the application?
label: BODY

text: No. To access Acrobat generative AI features, you must sign into your Adobe account
label: BODY

text: and agree to the Adobe Generative AI User Guidelines surfaced in a one-time “Getting
label: BODY

text: Started” experience when you first interact with such features in Acrobat. This activates the
label: BODY

text: generative AI feature set in Acrobat for all subsequent document sessions. After activation, a
label: BODY

text: user must engage AI Assistant or generative summary on a specific file before processing
label: BODY

text: takes place.
label: BODY

text: If I’m signed into my adobe account, does acrobat’s generative ai features automatically
label: BODY

text: start processing my documents when I launch the application, or open a file in the
label: BODY

text: application?
label: BODY

text: No. Acrobat’s generative AI features, like AI Assistant, do not start automatically processing
label: BODY

text: any of your documents upon application launch or upon opening a file into the application. A
label: BODY

text: user must first activate the generative AI feature set through a one-time “Getting Started” in-
label: BODY

text: app experience as described above. After activation, a user must engage AI Assistant or
label: BODY

text: generative summary on a specific file before processing takes place.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The generative AI features are only available in English for users with Individual or Teams
label: BODY

text: entitlements. Users with Enterprise entitlements may only receive Acrobat generative AI
label: BODY

text: features when their admin assigns them with a paid or trial license, or if they are accepted into
label: BODY

text: one of the programs in our private beta.
label: BODY

text: You can disable the generative AI feature by following the steps outlined here. Once disabled,
label: BODY

text: no documents will be processed through generative AI in Acrobat until you activate the
label: BODY

text: feature set again.
label: BODY

text: What LLMS are we leveraging to power generative ai in acrobat?
label: BODY

text: With AI Assistant in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader, Adobe takes an LLM-agnostic approach,
label: BODY

text: selecting best-in-class technologies that address a range of customer use cases. We currently
label: BODY

text: have integrated the Microsoft Azure OpenAI Service with our proprietary technologies to
label: BODY

text: provide generative AI capability in Acrobat and Acrobat Reader.
label: BODY

text: Does adobe concurrently train any large language models (“LLMS”) with your content
label: BODY

text: while you're using generative ai features in acrobat?
label: BODY

text: No. Acrobat does not train any LLMs on your content concurrent to your interactions with
label: BODY

text: generative AI in Acrobat. Prompts provided to AI Assistant do not modify the underlying
label: BODY

text: model. Your content will not be used to train any LLMs that deliver Acrobat’s generative AI
label: BODY

text: capability. For more information, please refer to the questions above in this help section
label: BODY

text: (Content Usage and Handling Practices).
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: Adobe does not use content from an organization or school account for product
label: BODY

text: improvement for generative AI unless otherwise agreed to by the organization or school.

text: Managing chat history
label: H3

text: What is chat history?
label: BODY

text: Acrobat now allows you to reference past conversations you had with AI Assistant. Chat
label: BODY

text: history includes your textual prompts and generated responses for a specific document or a
label: BODY

text: set of documents you selected, also termed a Collection.
label: BODY

text: How can I see my chat history?
label: BODY

text: Chat history includes your past conversations with AI Assistant and is linked to either a single
label: BODY

text: document or a Collection. To view these conversations, simply open the document or
label: BODY

text: Collection from your list of recent files.
label: BODY

text: The chat history might still contain content from documents you've removed from a
label: BODY

text: Collection. The AI Assistant may also use this chat history as context when responding to your
label: BODY

text: prompts.
label: BODY

text: Where is my chat history stored?
label: BODY

text: It's stored on your local device for Acrobat and Reader’s desktop, mobile, and online apps
label: BODY

text: and in Adobe cloud storage for Acrobat’s online app. It permits you to easily access the
label: BODY

text: conversation to review or continue using AI Assistant.
label: BODY

text: Can I export my chat history in AI Assistant?
label: BODY

text: Export is not currently available. Instead, you can copy the chat history or specific generated
label: BODY

text: responses into your text editor of choice. Learn more here.
label: BODY

text: How can I clear my chat history in AI Assistant?
label: BODY

text: You can clear chat history from the More menu for each individual document or a Collection.
label: BODY

text: Selecting Clear chat history will delete all of the chat history, meaning the document
label: BODY

text: overview, textual prompts (suggested by AI Assistant or provided by you), and generated
label: BODY

text: responses.
label: BODY

text: Can I disable chat history in AI Assistant?
label: BODY

text: This is currently not available to users.
label: BODY

text: Can i share my chat history with others?
label: BODY

text: No, you can’t share your chat history with other users.
label: BODY

text: What happens if I disconnect acrobat from other third-party cloud storage services such as
label: BODY

text: google drive or OneDrive?
label: BODY

text: You'll no longer be able to access your third-party cloud storage files in Acrobat and the AI
label: BODY

text: Assistant chats associated with them.
label: BODY

text: Before You Begin
label: H1

text: Before you begin, ensure that you adhere to the file and usage-related restrictions and login
label: BODY

text: requirements.

text: File considerations The language of the PDF file is English, French,
label: BODY

text: German, Spanish, Italian, Brazilian Portuguese, or
label: BODY

text: Japanese.
label: BODY

text: The file size must be less than 100 MB.
label: BODY

text: The file can have up to 600 pages.
label: BODY

text: The PDF shouldn’t be password protected or have any
label: BODY

text: usage restrictions.
label: BODY

text: The file shouldn’t be a PDF Portfolio.
label: BODY

text: The maximum character limit for the text selection
label: BODY

text: feature in AI Assistant is 8000 characters. The selected
label: BODY

text: text must be on a single page and cannot span multiple
label: BODY

text: pages.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The limits on PDF file size and page count are determined by the server settings and will
label: BODY

text: automatically adjust if the server settings change.

text: Get AI-generated answers
label: H2

text: AI Assistant supports scanned documents. You can scan your paper documents and upload
label: BODY

text: them to Acrobat to get concise summaries and accurate answers to your questions. It also
label: BODY

text: breaks down complex language into key details, making it easy to read and understand
label: BODY

text: contracts directly in Acrobat.

text: AI Assistant
label: H2

text: The AI Assistant feature provides AI-generated answers to your questions based on the
label: BODY

text: content of the selected files. It also highlights the portion of content from where it fetches the
label: BODY

text: answer for more context. The AI Assistant also suggests follow-up questions based on your
label: BODY

text: primary query.
label: BODY

text: To get started:
label: BODY

text: 1.Open a PDF and select AI Assistant in the global bar. To select multiple files, go to
label: BODY

text: Acrobat Home and choose Select files in the Recommended tools for you section,
label: BODY

text: choose your files, and select Open.
label: BODY

text: Note: You can select up to 10 files, each 600 pages long and no larger than 100 MB.
label: BODY

text: Select multiple files
label: BODY

text: Acrobat creates a collection of the selected files and opens the document.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Get started.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select from the sample questions that are displayed based on the content of your PDF
label: BODY

text: file. Alternatively, type your question in the message field.
label: BODY

text: 4.The answer to your question is displayed. The relevant sources are marked with
label: BODY

text: numbers. You can do the following:
label: BODY

text: Select a number to navigate directly to the corresponding section of the document. If
label: BODY

text: there are multiple files, hovering the mouse over the number shows the preview of the
label: BODY

text: referenced document.
label: BODY

text: To hide the attributed sources within the document, select Hide sources from the
label: BODY

text: Options menu.
label: BODY

text: To copy a specific answer, select Copy , or choose Copy full chat from the Options
label: BODY

text: menu to copy the entire conversation.
label: BODY

text: While the AI Assistant generates the response, you can pause the processing anytime
label: BODY

text: by selecting Stop.
label: BODY

text: Move the drag handle left or right to adjust the AI Assistant pane size for better
label: BODY

text: readability.
label: BODY

text: Review related questions that the AI Assistant suggests based on your primary query.
label: BODY

text: To add more files, select Add files.
label: BODY

text: To remove a file from the Collection, select View and manage files in chat,
label: BODY

text: then Remove file from chat.
label: BODY

text: The answer and the source are cited

label: H2

text: Acrobat preserves your interactions with AI features, even after you quit the application. You
label: BODY

text: can view these chat interactions by opening the file from your Recent file list. When you select
label: BODY

text: multiple files, Acrobat creates a collection that includes your chat history for future reference.
label: BODY

text: Get AI-generated overviews and summaries
label: H2

text: The Generative summary feature summarizes the document's organization and content. It
label: BODY

text: also provides a brief overview at the beginning to explain what the entire document is about.
label: BODY

text: Whether you're a researcher, business analyst, or student, the generative AI features help you
label: BODY

text: scan your PDF documents and quickly extract the essence, key points, and insights.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open a PDF file and select the Generative summary icon in the navigation panel.
label: BODY

text: Alternatively, you can select All tools > Generative summary.
label: BODY

text: Select Generative summary
label: BODY

text: 2.If prompted, select Get started.
label: BODY

text: 3.An overview of the document is generated with section headings and summaries.
label: BODY

text: Selecting a summary takes you directly to the corresponding section in the document
label: BODY

text: for more detailed information.
label: BODY

text: Overview of the document
label: BODY

text: 4.(Optional) To copy a specific summary, choose Copy, or choose Copy full
label: BODY

text: summary from the Options menu.
label: BODY

text: If you have questions about the document, scroll to the bottom, and select Ask AI
label: BODY

text: Assistant.
label: BODY

text: Streaming summaries for long PDFs
label: H2

text: When you use Generative summary to scan lengthy PDFs, Acrobat or Acrobat Reader
label: BODY

text: processes the content in chunks and simultaneously streams summaries of the portions that it
label: BODY

text: processes. It helps improve your productivity because you can instantly review the output and
label: BODY

text: stay engaged.
label: BODY

text: The key advantages of streaming summaries include:
label: BODY

text: Real-time streaming: As Acrobat or Acrobat Reader processes a lengthy PDF, it
label: BODY

text: concurrently streams summaries for sections it has already analyzed. It helps eliminate
label: BODY

text: any latency associated with summarizing voluminous content.
label: BODY

text: Segmented display: When you start generating the summary for your content, you'll
label: BODY

text: immediately see summarized content for the sections that the Generative summary
label: BODY

text: feature finished processing.
label: BODY

text: Parallel processing: While you engage with the summarized sections, the feature
label: BODY

text: extracts headings, and generates summaries for the subsequent sections.
label: BODY

text: Use generative AI features in meeting apps
label: BODY

text: You can harness the power of generative AI features in Acrobat to gain insights from
label: BODY

text: transcripts of online meetings in Microsoft Teams and Zoom. Use the generative AI
label: BODY

text: features to summarize discussions or draft emails for meeting notes or action
label: BODY

text: items. You can access the generative AI features from Acrobat Reader, Acrobat
label: BODY

text: desktop and online, and Acrobat for Microsoft Teams.

label: BODY

label: BODY
