text: to add their email addresses to the CC list.
label: BODY

text: Enter the desired information and do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: (Optional) To explore advanced options including signer authentication, reminders,
label: BODY

text: and more, click More Options.
label: BODY

text: To add form fields and specify where to sign, click Specify where to sign.
label: BODY

text: Request signatures – Add Cc, subject, message, More Options
label: BODY

text: If you don't want to use the More Options, skip the next optional step.
label: BODY

text: 4.(Optional) Click More Options, if you want to specify advanced options, such as signer
label: BODY

text: authentication, reminders, and more.
label: BODY

text: By default, the Complete in Order setting is turned on. The numbers by the
label: BODY

text: email addresses reflect the participation order. If you do not want to follow any
label: BODY

text: particular order for signing, toggle the switch to Complete In Any Order.
label: BODY

text: (Optional) Click Add Me, if you want to be included as a signer of the
label: BODY

text: document.
label: BODY

text: Specify authentication type like Email, Password, Social Identity, Knowledge-
label: BODY

text: Based Authentication, Phone, or Acrobat Sign.
label: BODY

text: Password Protect the PDF file.
label: BODY

text: Set a Completion Deadline.
label: BODY

text: Specify the Recipient's Language in the email sent.
label: BODY

text: More or
label: BODY

text: Advanced Options
label: BODY

text: 5.The Specify Where to Fill & Sign window is displayed showing options based on
label: BODY

text: whether you have added one signer or multiple signers.
label: BODY

text: Simplified mode for single signer
label: BODY

text: If you've added one signer, the Advanced Editing mode is off, and you see the
label: BODY

text: simplified option as shown below. To place a signature or another field, click at the
label: BODY

text: desired location in the document and then set the field's properties from its context
label: BODY

text: menu.
label: BODY

text: Simplified mode for multiple signers
label: BODY

text: This mode provides simplified authoring with the capability of assigning fields to
label: BODY

text: multiple signers. When you select a signer from the right pane and add fields in the
label: BODY

text: form, the fields are assigned to the signer. That means those fields will be available to
label: BODY

text: the signer for filling the information and signing the form.
label: BODY

text: You can switch the assignee of any field using the floating toolbar. The assigned colors
label: BODY

text: to the signers make it easy to distinguish the fields for respective signers.
label: BODY

text: Advanced mode for multiple signers
label: BODY

text: If you've added multiple signers, you see the options as shown below. Click
label: BODY

text: the button to place the detected form fields in the PDF document. Alternatively,
label: BODY

text: drag fields from the tabs in the right pane and drop the fields where desired in the
label: BODY

text: document.
label: BODY

text: Note: You can switch between simplified mode and advanced mode for multiple signers.
label: BODY

text: To switch mode, turn off the Advanced Editing switch in the right-pane.
label: BODY

text: 6.When you've placed all desired fields in the document, click Send. The document is
label: BODY

text: sent for signature to the recipients and a confirmation notice is displayed.
label: BODY

text: You receive an email from Acrobat Sign stating that the agreements have been sent to the
label: BODY

text: first signer for signature. The first signer also receives an email with a link to sign the
label: BODY

text: agreement. When the signer adds his or her signature in the signature field and then clicks
label: BODY

text: the Click to sign button, the agreement is sent to the next signer with a link to sign, and so
label: BODY

text: on. Once the agreement is signed by all the signers, everyone gets a copy of the signed
label: BODY

text: agreement.
label: BODY

text: All your signed documents are kept at one place and you can access them from anywhere.
label: BODY

text: Signer's experience
label: H1

text: A signer receives an email with a link to sign the agreement. Also, if the signer uses Acrobat or
label: BODY

text: Acrobat Reader desktop application, the signer sees a notification that an agreement has
label: BODY

text: been shared for signing.
label: BODY

text: Note: Signers are not required to sign up or purchase any Adobe product to sign agreements.
label: BODY

text: They can sign agreements using a web browser, mobile device, or Acrobat / Acrobat Reader
label: BODY

text: desktop application.
label: BODY

text: Send in bulk allows you to upload a form and use that as a template to create and send many
label: BODY

text: (hundreds!) of unique agreements, each dedicated to one external signer. Each agreement is
label: BODY

text: insulated from the others and contains its own audit report. Each recipient is unaware of all
label: BODY

text: other recipients.
label: BODY

text: The sender has access to the agreements through their Home or Documents tab or through
label: BODY

text: the Send in bulk template, which contains an Agreements report that tracks the overall status
label: BODY

text: of the child agreements created from the template. Additionally, the sender can export the
label: BODY

text: field-level data of all completed agreements in a CSV format using the Download Form Field
label: BODY

text: Data action.
label: BODY

text: To access the Send in bulk feature, do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: In the Acrobat desktop app, go to the Tools center, scroll down to the E-Signsection,
label: BODY

text: and then select Send in bulk.
label: BODY

text: Sign in to Acrobat online, select the E-Sign menu in the top navigation bar, and then
label: BODY

text: select Send in bulk.
label: BODY

text: Steps to send in bulk
label: H2

text: 1.Select the Send in Bulk tool as explained earlier. The Send in bulk file upload page
label: BODY

text: is displayed.
label: BODY

text: Add a file:
label: BODY

text: Upload (by search or drag-and-drop) the primary file that you are using to build
label: BODY

text: your agreement template.
label: BODY

text: The selector on the right of the Select a file button allows you to choose from the
label: BODY

text: source where the file resides. The default is your local system.
label: BODY

text: Once a file is selected, the configuration page loads.
label: BODY

text: 3.Add participants:
label: BODY

text: 1. List the participants required.
label: BODY

text: The Sign action is assigned by default.
label: BODY

text: The Sign action allows the participant to enter field data and sign the
label: BODY

text: agreement.
label: BODY

text: Up to 50 participants are supported.
label: BODY

text: Each participant listed receives their own agreement.
label: BODY

text: 2. Enter recipient email addresses followed by commas, or copy and paste a list of
label: BODY

text: email addresses into the Email field.
label: BODY

text: 3. Configure participant authentication by clicking the key icon to the right of the
label: BODY

text: participant.
label: BODY

text: Email is the default authentication method for confirming the identity of each
label: BODY

text: participant and is sufficient to obtain a legal signature in most cases.
label: BODY

text: Password authentication can be added to increase security. When configured, the participant
label: BODY

text: must enter the password before they can interact with the agreement.
label: BODY

text: 4.. (Optional) Add yourself and/or CC'd parties
label: BODY

text: Click Add me to add yourself as a counter signer.
label: BODY

text: Click Add cc to add people you want to be copied when the agreement is sent
label: BODY

text: and complete.
label: BODY

text: 5.(Optional) Add additional files if needed.
label: BODY

text: The initial file selected to start the agreement template is already attached.
label: BODY

text: Upload any additional file(s) that you require.
label: BODY

text: Multiple files can be uploaded.
label: BODY

text: All files uploaded are concatenated into one file for the final agreement.
label: BODY

text: The order the files are listed dictates how the final agreement will look.
label: BODY

text: You can click and drag the files to sort them.
label: BODY

text: You must share this password with the participants out-of-band.
label: BODY

text: 6.Add Agreement Details:
label: BODY

text: Name your agreement. All agreements generated from the Send in
label: BODY

text: bulk template will have the same agreement name.
label: BODY

text: Change the default text in the Message field as appropriate.
label: BODY

text: 7.Edit the Agreement settings (Optional):
label: BODY

text: By default, agreements do not require a password to view the completed agreement,
label: BODY

text: nor do they have reminders set for participants
label: BODY

text: Select Add access password if you require recipients to enter a password to
label: BODY

text: open and view the signed PDF file.
label: BODY

text: Select Set Reminder to set the frequency of reminders to be sent until the
label: BODY

text: agreement is completed.
label: BODY

text: 8.Click Next in the upper right corner of the window.
label: BODY

text: The document is now ready to add any fields that you want the signers to fill in or sign.
label: BODY

text: Note: If you have added multiple files, the files are converted into PDFs and combined into a
label: BODY

text: single document. The combined document is opened for you to add fields.
label: BODY

text: 9.Prepare the Agreement and Add Fields:
label: BODY

text: You can now add any necessary fields to the agreement. Remember that
label: BODY

text: a Signature field must be placed for each signer (including internal counter-singers).
label: BODY

text: There are two methods to apply fields:
label: BODY

text: 1. Simple Authoring is loaded by default in most instances. Simple authoring:
label: BODY

text: Is limited to the most common types of fields:
label: BODY

text: Text input (All Text fields are flagged as Required)
label: BODY

text: Signature
label: BODY

text: Signer's name (Printed)
label: BODY

text: Signer's email
label: BODY

text: Signature date (Read-Only; Supplied by the system)
label: BODY

text: Checkbox
label: BODY

text: Places fields anywhere you click on the document.
label: BODY

text: Allows resizing of fields by clicking the bottom right corner of the field (blue
label: BODY

text: triangle) and dragging the field to size.
label: BODY

text: 2.Advanced Authoring can be enabled by selecting the toggle in the upper right corner.
label: BODY

text: Advanced authoring:
label: BODY

text: Allows access to all field types (highlighted in yellow)
label: BODY

text: Supports form field detection (highlighted in green)
label: BODY

text: Supports Prefill fields (highlighted in pink)
label: BODY

text: Supports field assignment (highlighted in purple and pink)
label: BODY

text: Supports field validation
label: BODY

text: Supports calculated fields
label: BODY

text: Supports conditional fields
label: BODY

text: Allows control of the field text font/appearance
label: BODY

text: Places fields by dragging them from the menu on the right side of the document.
label: BODY

text: Allows resizing of fields by clicking the bottom right corner of the field (blue triangle)
label: BODY

text: and dragging the field to size.
label: BODY

text: Note: You can switch between Simple and Advanced mode by selecting the Advanced
label: BODY

text: editing (on||off) toggle in the upper-right corner.
label: BODY

text: 10.Select Next (in the top-right corner) after all the fields have been placed.
label: BODY

text: 11.Review and Send
label: BODY

text: Review the agreement information and Send if everything is correct
label: BODY

text: 12.Confirmation
label: BODY

text: A confirmation message is shown verifying the agreement has been sent successfully.
label: BODY

text: There are three options to progress from the post-sending page:
label: BODY

text: Manage agreements - Opens the Bulk Sends page with all your agreements: track
label: BODY

text: status, access audit trails, send reminder
label: BODY

text: Send another document in bulk- Prepare another document to send to many people
label: BODY

text: Click Close to return to the Acrobat online Home page
label: BODY

text: Manage your bulk sends
label: H2

text: Bulk sends can be managed from your Documents tab.
label: BODY

text: 1.Navigate to the Documents tab.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Bulk Sends in the list of Your documents on the left side of the window.
label: BODY

text: 3.Single-click the Bulk Send you to want to access, opening the context menu on the
label: BODY

text: right side of the window. The context menu on the right side contains five distinct
label: BODY

text: sections:
label: BODY

text: Metadata (red square): At the top of the menu is the metadata for the Bulk Send
label: BODY

text: template:
label: BODY

text: Image of the Bulk Sends' first page
label: BODY

text: The title of the Bulk Send
label: BODY

text: The date the Bulk Send was sent to the participants
label: BODY

text: The email value of the userID that created the Bulk Send
label: BODY

text: The current status of the whole Bulk Send
label: BODY

text: The Message provided in the initial email
label: BODY

text: Any CCd parties (listed by email value)
label: BODY

text: Actions menu (blue square) - This section contains all of the actions you can take
label: BODY

text: regarding the Bulk Send (parent template). Click the See More link at the bottom right
label: BODY

text: of the section to see all values:
label: BODY

text: Open Bulk Send - Opens the Bulk Send template document for viewing only. No fields
label: BODY

text: are available
label: BODY

text: Reminders – Add a reminder for yourself or everyone else who still needs to sign.
label: BODY

text: Cancel: Cancel the Bulk Send.
label: BODY

text: Download PDF - Downloads the whole (blank) PDF.
label: BODY

text: Download Form Field Data - Downloads a CSV file of the field-level content for all
label: BODY

text: child agreements spawned from this parent Bulk Send that have been completed.
label: BODY

text: Download Individual Files - Provides the option to download the individual PDF files
label: BODY

text: if multiple files were used to create the web form.
label: BODY

text: Hide/Unhide Bulk Send- Hide/Unhiding the Bulk Send simply removes (or adds) the
label: BODY

text: Bulk Send from your normal Manage page view.
label: BODY

text: Share - Shares the Bulk Send along with its status with the user email you provide.
label: BODY

text: Shared web forms can be viewed on the Manage page, but do not allow editing.
label: BODY

text: A PDF copy of the Bulk Send parent document (without added fields) is emailed to the
label: BODY

text: sharee.
label: BODY

text: View Activity Report
label: BODY

text: View the current status of all child agreements created by the Bulk Send parent
label: BODY

text: template.
label: BODY

text: Add Notes - Allows the user to make personal notes for the Bulk Send.
label: BODY

text: Agreements summary/filter (green square) - The Agreements section shows up to five
label: BODY

text: values that reflect the number of child agreements in each status. If no child
label: BODY

text: agreements are in a given status, the status is not exposed, so you may see fewer than
label: BODY

text: five line items. Clicking any one status will produce a filter list of those child
label: BODY

text: agreements:
label: BODY

text: All - Shows all (child) agreements that have spawned from the Bulk Send (parent
label: BODY

text: template).
label: BODY

text: In Progress - Indicates that the child agreement is waiting for the participant to
label: BODY

text: complete their signature.
label: BODY

text: Canceled - Indicates that either the sender explicitly canceled the child agreement, or
label: BODY

text: the participant declined to sign.
label: BODY

text: Completed - Completed agreements have successfully obtained all signatures from all
label: BODY

text: participants on the agreement.
label: BODY

text: Waiting for You - Indicates that the agreement is waiting for the sender to countersign
label: BODY

text: the agreement.
label: BODY

text: Activity for the Bulk Send parent template (orange square) - The Activity > link at the
label: BODY

text: bottom of the context panel opens a chronological list of the enablement actions
label: BODY

text: taken against the (parent) Bulk Send template (eg: Creation, Completed events).
label: BODY

text: Adobe Acrobat supports a range of solutions for electronic and digital signatures. These
label: BODY

text: solutions include certificate signatures that let you sign PDF files with a certificate-based
label: BODY

text: digital ID. Certificate signatures are also known as digital signatures. Acrobat lets you create
label: BODY

text: your certificate ID. However, the common approach is to work with a certificate ID from a
label: BODY

text: trusted third-party certificate authority. Additional signing options in Acrobat include
label: BODY

text: integration with Adobe Acrobat Sign.
label: BODY

text: Why use certificate signatures?
label: H2

text: Many business transactions, including financial, legal, and other regulated transactions,
label: BODY

text: require high assurance when signing documents. When documents are distributed
label: BODY

text: electronically, it's important that recipients can:
label: BODY

text: Verify document authenticity—confirming the identity of each person who signed the
label: BODY

text: document
label: BODY

text: Verify document integrity—confirming that the document has not been altered in
label: BODY

text: transit
label: BODY

text: Certificate-based signatures provide both of these security services. Many businesses and
label: BODY

text: governments have chosen to set up a certificate-based digital signature infrastructure within
label: BODY

text: their organization. They use third-party certificate authorities to provide independent identity
label: BODY

text: validation. Examples include:
label: BODY

text: For instance, companies in the European Union who need to comply with advanced or
label: BODY

text: qualified electronic signature requirements in eIDAS e-signature regulation or the ETSI PAdES
label: BODY

text: standard (PDF Advanced Electronic Signatures).
label: BODY

text: What can I do with certificate IDs?
label: H2

text: Once certificate-based digital IDs have been provided to end users, they can
label: BODY

text: use Acrobat or Acrobat Reader software to sign PDF files and validate files they receive from
label: BODY

text: others.
label: BODY

text: Sign documents
label: H3

text: Sign PDF files using certificate IDs
label: BODY

text: Place a signature box anywhere on the page
label: BODY

text: Add multiple signatures to a page
label: BODY

text: Add a time stamp to the document when working with a configured timestamp server
label: BODY

text: Certify a document with a visible or hidden signature so that recipients can verify
label: BODY

text: authenticity with or without seeing a visible signature on the page
label: BODY

text: Automatically embed certificate data to support long-term validation
label: BODY

text: Validate documents
label: H3

text: Validate all signatures, confirming the identity of everyone who signed the document
label: BODY

text: Validate document integrity by tracking all previously signed versions of a document
label: BODY

text: to verify changes made during the document’s lifecycle
label: BODY

text: Set privileges and permissions for others
label: H3

text: Certify a document while leaving portions of it available for form filling, signatures, or
label: BODY

text: comments
label: BODY

text: Use Acrobat Pro software to enable users of Reader 9 or later to sign with certificate IDs
label: BODY

text: Use Acrobat Standard or Pro to encrypt a PDF document with a certificate ID to restrict
label: BODY

text: usage such as printing, editing, or copying
label: BODY

text: What if my organization isn’t prepared to set up certificate-
label: BODY

text: based signatures?
label: BODY

text: Consider signing up for Adobe Acrobat Sign online, the leader in e-signatures and web
label: BODY

text: contracting. With Acrobat Sign, you can get PDF, Microsoft Word, and other documents sent,
label: BODY

text: signed, and filed instantly. And best of all, Adobe hosts it securely, so your IT department
label: BODY

text: doesn’t have to do the work of setting up a signature infrastructure.
label: BODY

text: Resources
label: H2

text: Adobe Approved Trust List (AATL): The Adobe Approved Trust List is a program that allows
label: BODY

text: millions of users worldwide to create digital signatures that are trusted whenever the signed
label: BODY

text: document is opened in Acrobat or Reader software. Check out the current members.
label: BODY

text: Adobe Security and Privacy Portal: A good first stop for all things security and privacy at
label: BODY

text: Adobe.
label: BODY

text: Certified Document Services: Certified Document Services (CDS) was the predecessor to the
label: BODY

text: AATL.
label: BODY

text: Content Security Library: Extensive documentation on Adobe certificate signature
label: BODY

text: administration.
label: BODY

text: Managing Digital IDs: Help pages for digital ID management.
label: BODY

text: A certificate-based signature, like a conventional handwritten signature, identifies the person
label: BODY

text: signing a document. Unlike a handwritten signature, a certificate-based signature is difficult to
label: BODY

text: forge because it contains encrypted information that is unique to the signer. It can be easily
label: BODY

text: verified and informs recipients whether the document was modified after the signer initially
label: BODY

text: signed it.
label: BODY

text: To sign a document with a certificate-based signature, you must obtain a digital ID or create a
label: BODY

text: self-signed digital ID in Acrobat or Acrobat Reader. The digital ID contains a private key and a
label: BODY

text: certificate with a public key, and more. The private key is used to create the certificate-based
label: BODY

text: signature. The certificate is a credential that is automatically applied to the signed document.
label: BODY

text: The signature is verified when recipients open the document.
label: BODY

text: When you apply a certificate-based signature, Acrobat uses a hashing algorithm to generate a
label: BODY

text: message digest, which it encrypts using your private key. Acrobat embeds the encrypted
label: BODY

text: message digest in the PDF, certificate details, signature image, and a document version when
label: BODY

text: signed.
label: BODY

text: Certificate-based signature in a PDF form
label: BODY

text: Steps to add a certificate-based signature to a PDF
label: H2

text: 1.Open a PDF in Acrobat and choose All Tools > more > Use a certificate in the
label: BODY

text: global bar.
label: BODY

text: Alternatively, from Acrobat Home, select See all tools. In the Protect section,
label: BODY

text: select Use a certificate, and then select a file you want to certify.
label: BODY

text: 2.The Use a certificate tool is open on the left pane.
label: BODY

text: Select Certify (visible signatures) to certify with a visible digital signature,
label: BODY

text: and then select Drag New Signature Rectangle in the dialog box that
label: BODY

text: appears.
label: BODY

text: Select Certify (invisible signatures) if you want to certify the document
label: BODY

text: without a visible signature.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select OK in the Save as Certified Document dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 4.If you've selected, Certify (visible signatures) in step 2, use the mouse to drag and draw
label: BODY

text: a rectangle area where you want your signature to appear.
label: BODY

text: 5.In the Sign with a Digital ID dialog box, choose the Digital ID you want to use for
label: BODY

text: certifying the document and select Continue, or select Configure New Digital ID to
label: BODY

text: create a new ID.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Review to review the document content before signing, then select Sign. Save
label: BODY

text: the PDF when prompted. Your document is now certified.
label: BODY

text: Certifying and signing documents
label: H2

text: The Use a certificate tool lets you apply two types of certificate-based signatures. You
label: BODY

text: can Certify a document, attest to its content or approve a document with the Digitally
label: BODY

text: sign option.
label: BODY

text: Digitally sign
label: H3

text: When you Digitally sign with a certificate, the signature is considered an approval signature.
label: BODY

text: Certify (visible or invisible signatures)
label: H3

text: Certify options provide a higher level of document control than Digitally sign. For documents
label: BODY

text: that require certification, you must certify the documents before others sign them. If a
label: BODY

text: document has already been signed, the Certify options are disabled. When you certify a
label: BODY

text: document, you can control the types of changes other people can make. You can certify with
label: BODY

text: or without displaying a signature.
label: BODY

text: Signatures made with the Certify or Digitally sign optionscomply with data protection
label: BODY

text: standards specified by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). In
label: BODY

text: addition, both signature types comply with the PDF Advanced Electronic Signature (PAdES)
label: BODY

text: standard. Acrobat and Acrobat Reader provide an option to change the default signing format
label: BODY

text: to a CAdES format. This option is compliant with Part 3 of the PAdES standard. The timestamp
label: BODY

text: capability and native support for long-term validation of signatures (introduced in Acrobat
label: BODY

text: 9.1) is in compliance with Part 4 of the PAdES standard. The default signing format, when set
label: BODY

text: up accordingly, is compliant with Part 2 of the PAdES standard. You can change the default
label: BODY

text: signing method or format, in the Signatures panel of the Preferences dialog box. Under
label: BODY

text: Creation & Appearance, click More.
label: BODY

text: Setting up certificate-based signatures
label: H2

text: You can expedite the signing process and optimize your results by making the following
label: BODY

text: preparations in advance.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: Some situations require using particular digital IDs for signing. For example, a corporation or
label: BODY

text: government agency can require individuals to use only digital IDs issued by that agency to
label: BODY

text: sign official documents. Inquire about the digital signature policies of your organization to
label: BODY

text: determine the appropriate source of your digital ID.
label: BODY

text: Get a digital ID from your own organization, buy a digital ID (see the Adobe website
label: BODY

text: for security partners), or create a self-signed one. See Create a self-signed digital ID.
label: BODY

text: You can’t apply a certificate-based signature without a digital id.
label: BODY

text: Set the default signing method.
label: BODY

text: Create an appearance for your certificate-based signature. (See Create the signature
label: BODY

text: appearance.)
label: BODY

text: Usethe Preview Document mode to suppress any dynamic content that can alter the
label: BODY

text: appearance of the document and mislead you into signing an unsuitable document.
label: BODY

text: For information about using the Preview Document mode, see Sign in Preview
label: BODY

text: Document mode.
label: BODY

text: Review all the pages in a document before you sign. Documents can contain signature
label: BODY

text: fields on multiple pages.
label: BODY

text: Configure the signing application. Both authors and signers should configure their
label: BODY

text: application environment. (See Set signing preferences).
label: BODY

text: For details on the full range of configuration options in enterprise settings, see
label: BODY

text: the Digital Signatures Guide.
label: BODY

text: Choose a signature type. Learn about approval and certification signatures to
label: BODY

text: determine the type you should choose to sign your document. (See Signature types.)
label: BODY

text: Set signing preferences
label: H2

text: Signing workflow preferences control what you can see and do when the signing dialog box
label: BODY

text: opens. You can allow certain actions, hide and display data fields, and change how content
label: BODY

text: affects the signing process. Setting signing preferences impacts your ability to see what you
label: BODY

text: are signing. For information on the available signing preferences, see “Signing Workflow
label: BODY

text: Preferences” in the Digital Signature Guide.
label: BODY

text: Customizing signature workflows using seed values
label: H2

text: Seed values offer additional control to document authors by letting them specify which
label: BODY

text: choices signers can make when signing a document. By applying seed values to signature
label: BODY

text: fields in unsigned PDFs, authors can customize options and automate tasks. They can also
label: BODY

text: specify signature requirements for items such as certificates and timestamp servers. For more
label: BODY

text: information about customizing signatures using seed values, see the Digital Signature Guide.
label: BODY

text: Create the appearance of a certificate-based signature
label: H2

text: You determine the look of your certificate-based signature by selecting options in the
label: BODY

text: Signatures panel of the Preferences dialog box. For example, you can include an image of
label: BODY

text: your handwritten signature, a company logo, or a photograph. You can also create different
label: BODY

text: signatures for different purposes. For some, you can provide a greater level of detail.
label: BODY

text: A signature can also include information that helps others verify your signature , such as
label: BODY

text: the reason for signing, contact information, and more.
label: BODY

text: 1.(Optional) If you want to include an image of your handwritten signature in the
label: BODY

text: certificate-based signature, scan your signature, and save it as an image file. Place
label: BODY

text: the image in a document by itself, and convert the document to PDF.
label: BODY

text: 2.Right-click the signature field, and select Sign Document or Certify with Visible
label: BODY

text: Signature.
label: BODY

text: Note: You can also create an appearance using the Signature preferences:
label: BODY

text: Hamburger menu > Preferences > Signatures (Windows) or Acrobat >
label: BODY

text: Preferences > Signatures (macOS).
label: BODY

text: 3.From the Appearance menu in the Sign dialog box, select Create New Appearance.
label: BODY

text: 4.In the Configure Signature Appearance dialog box, type a name for the signature
label: BODY

text: you’re creating. When you sign, you select the signature by this name. Therefore,
label: BODY

text: use a short, descriptive title.
label: BODY

text: 5.For Configure Graphic, choose an option:
label: BODY

text: No Graphic
label: BODY

text: Displays only the default icon and other information specified in the Configure Text
label: BODY

text: section.
label: BODY

text: Imported Graphic
label: BODY

text: Displays an image with your certificate-based signature. Select this option to include
label: BODY

text: an image of your handwritten signature. To import the image file, select File, select
label: BODY

text: Browse and then select the image file.
label: BODY

text: Name
label: BODY

text: Displays only the default signature icon and your name as it appears in your digital
label: BODY

text: ID file.
label: BODY

text: 6.For Configure Text, select the options that you want to appear in the signature.
label: BODY

text: Distinguished Name shows the user attributes defined in your digital ID, including
label: BODY

text: your name, organization, and country.
label: BODY

text: 7.For Text Properties, specify the writing direction and type of digits used, and then
label: BODY

text: click OK. See also Enable right-to-left languages.
label: BODY

text: 8.(Optional) If the dialog box includes the Additional Signature Information section,
label: BODY

text: specify the reason for signing the document, the location, and your contact
label: BODY

text: information. These options are available only if you set them as your preferences in
label: BODY

text: the Creation and Appearance Preferences dialog box (Preferences > Signatures >
label: BODY

text: Creation & Appearance > More).
label: BODY

text: Set up a roaming ID account
label: H2

text: A roaming ID is a digital ID that is stored on a server and can be accessed by the subscriber.
label: BODY

text: You must have an Internet connection to access a roaming ID and an account from an
label: BODY

text: organization that supplies roaming digital IDs.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the Preferences dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 2.Under Categories, select Signatures.
label: BODY

text: 3.For Identities & Trusted Certificates, select More.
label: BODY

text: 4.Expand Digital IDs on the left, select Roaming ID Accounts, and select Add
label: BODY

text: Account.
label: BODY

text: 5.Type the name and URL for the roaming ID server, and select Next.
label: BODY

text: 6.Type your user name and password, or follow the directions to create an account.
label: BODY

text: Select Next, and then select Finish.
label: BODY

text: Once the roaming ID is added, it can be used for signing or encryption. When you perform a
label: BODY

text: task that uses your roaming ID, you’re automatically logged in to the roaming ID server if your
label: BODY

text: authentication assertion hasn’t expired.
label: BODY

text: PKCS#12 modules and tokens
label: H2

text: You can have multiple digital IDs that you use for different purposes, particularly if you sign
label: BODY

text: documents in different roles or using different certification methods. Digital IDs are usually
label: BODY

text: password protected. They can be stored on your computer in PKCS #12 file format. Digital
label: BODY

text: IDs can also be stored on a smart card, hardware token, or in the Windows certificate store.
label: BODY

text: Roaming IDs can be stored on a server. Acrobat includes a default signature handler that can
label: BODY

text: access digital IDs from various locations. Register the digital ID in Acrobat for it to be available
label: BODY

text: for use.
label: BODY

text: Store certificates on directory servers
label: H2

text: Directory servers are commonly used as centralized repositories of identities within an
label: BODY

text: organization. The server acts as an ideal location to store user certificates in enterprises that
label: BODY

text: use certificate encryption. Directory servers let you locate certificates from network servers,
label: BODY

text: including Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) servers. After you locate a
label: BODY

text: certificate, you can add it to your list of trusted identities so that you don’t have to look it up
label: BODY

text: again. By developing a storage area for trusted certificates, you or a member of your
label: BODY

text: workgroup can facilitate the use of encryption in the workgroup.
label: BODY

text: For more information about directory servers, see the Digital Signature Guide.
label: BODY

text: Import directory server settings (Windows only)
label: H2

text: You import directory server settings using security import/export methodology or a security
label: BODY

text: settings file. Before, you import settings in a file using import/export methodology, ensure
label: BODY

text: that you trust the file provider before opening it.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the Preferences dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 2.Under Categories, select Signatures.
label: BODY

text: 3.For Document Timestamping, select More.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Directory Servers on the left, and then select Import.
label: BODY

text: 5.Select the import/export methodology file and select Open.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select the Signature Properties button to check the current signature status if the file
label: BODY

text: is signed.
label: BODY

text: 7.Select Import Search Directory Settings.
label: BODY

text: 8.Select OK, if prompted to confirm your choice.
label: BODY

text: The directory server appears in the Security Settings dialog box.
label: BODY

text: Export directory server settings (Windows only)
label: H2

text: Although it is preferable to export security settings, you can export directory settings as an
label: BODY

text: import/export methodology file. Use the file to configure the directory server on another
label: BODY

text: computer.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the Preferences dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 2.Under Categories, select Identity.
label: BODY

text: 3.Enter your name, organization, and email address to create your profile.
label: BODY

text: 4.Under Categories, select Signatures.
label: BODY

text: 5.For Document Timestamping, select More.
label: BODY

text: 6.Select Directory Servers on the left, and then select one or more servers on the
label: BODY

text: right.
label: BODY

text: 7.Select Export, select a destination, and then select Next.
label: BODY

text: 8.To prove that the file came from you, select Sign, add your signature, and then
label: BODY

text: select Next.
label: BODY

text: 9.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: To save the file, specify its name and location, and select Save.
label: BODY

text: To send the file as an attachment, type an email address in the To box,
label: BODY

text: select Next, and then select Finish.
label: BODY

text: Note: See also Export security settings.
label: BODY

text: Add a timestamp to certificate-based signatures
label: H2

text: You can include the date and time you signed the document as part of your certificate-based
label: BODY

text: signature. Timestamps are easier to verify when they are associated with a trusted timestamp
label: BODY

text: authority certificate. A timestamp helps to establish when you signed the document and
label: BODY

text: reduces the chances of an invalid signature. You can obtain a timestamp from a third-party
label: BODY

text: timestamp authority or the certificate authority that issued your digital ID.
label: BODY

text: Timestamps appear in the signature field and in the Signature Properties dialog box. If a
label: BODY

text: timestamp server is configured, the timestamp appears in the Date/Time tab of the Signature
label: BODY

text: Properties dialog box. If no timestamp server is configured, the signatures field displays the
label: BODY

text: local time of the computer at the moment of signing.
label: BODY

text: Note: If you did not embed a timestamp when you signed the document, you can add one
label: BODY

text: later to your signature. (See Establish long-term signature validation.) A timestamp applied
label: BODY

text: after signing a document uses the time provided by the timestamp server.
label: BODY

text: Configure a timestamp server
label: H2

text: To configure a timestamp server, you need the server name and the URL, which you can
label: BODY

text: obtain from an administrator or a security settings file.
label: BODY

text: If you have a security settings file, install it and don’t use the following instructions for
label: BODY

text: configuring a server. Ensure that you obtained the security settings file from a trusted source.
label: BODY

text: Don’t install it without checking with your system administration or IT department.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the Preferences dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 2.Under Categories, select Signatures.
label: BODY

text: 3.For Document Timestamping, click More.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Time Stamp Servers on the left.
label: BODY

text: 5.Do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: If you have an import/export methodology file with the timestamp server
label: BODY

text: settings, click the Import button . Select the file, and select Open.
label: BODY

text: If you've a URL for the timestamp server, select the New button . Type a
label: BODY

text: name, and then type the server URL. Specify whether the server requires a
label: BODY

text: username and password, then select OK.
label: BODY

text: Set a timestamp server as the default
label: H2

text: To be able to use a timestamp server to timestamp signatures, set it as the default server.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the Preferences dialog box.
label: BODY

text: 2.Under Categories, select Signatures.
label: BODY

text: 3.For Document Timestamping, click More.
label: BODY

text: 4.Select Time Stamp Servers on the left.
label: BODY

text: 5.Select the timestamp server, and click the Set Default button
label: BODY

text: 6.Select OK to confirm your selection.
label: BODY

text: Share
label: H1

text: You can quickly share a link to a PDF document with others for viewing or commenting. The
label: BODY

text: document shared as a link opens in any browser on any device. The document is stored
label: BODY

text: securely in Adobe cloud storage. Recipients get an email with a link, and they can click the
label: BODY

text: link to view and comment on the document in a browser; no sign-in is required.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open a PDF in Acrobat or Acrobat Reader and select Share in the upper-right corner.
label: BODY

text: 2.(Optional) Select Link Setting and ensure that People can comment toggle is on.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select the appropriate option to share the PDF:
label: BODY

text: Enter the recipient's name or email and select Invite. You can add a message
label: BODY

text: and a deadline.
label: BODY

text: Select any third-party App and follow the onscreen instructions.
label: BODY

text: Select Create a link to share and share copied link with recipients.
label: BODY

text: Select Send a link or attach this file to an email and follow the onscreen
label: BODY

text: instructions.
label: BODY

text: PDF sharing options
label: H2

text: Add name or email to invite - Enter the name or email of the recipient. If necessary,
label: BODY

text: add a message, or Add deadline, and select Invite.
label: BODY

text: Add name or email to invite
label: BODY

text: Create a link and share using third-party apps. When you select any available third-
label: BODY

text: party app like Microsoft Outlook, Gmail, WhatsApp, Microsoft Teams, or the default
label: BODY

text: email client, Acrobat creates a shareable link and opens the respective application
label: BODY

text: with the copied link in the message draft. Alternatively, select Create a link to share,
label: BODY

text: then copy and share it with the intended recipients.
label: BODY

text: Share a link to the file
label: BODY

text: Send an anonymous or public link in an email
label: H2

text: An anonymous or public link makes the files accessible to anyone who clicks the link.
label: BODY

text: Follow the steps below to create a review link, and share it using your email client.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Share in the upper right. You get either of the two options:
label: BODY

text: Get link: You get this option when a file isn't synced to the cloud. Select Get
label: BODY

text: link to sync the file to the cloud. Once the file is synced, the get link option
label: BODY

text: changes to Copy link. Select Copy link and share it as desired.
label: BODY

text: Copy link: You get this option if the file is already synced to the cloud or shared
label: BODY

text: with someone.
label: BODY

text: 3.By default, the People can comment switch is turned on. To share the file only for
label: BODY

text: viewing, select Anyone can access and comment in the Share dialog box, and then
label: BODY

text: switch the toggle next to People can comment to turn it off.
label: BODY

text: 4.The link is created and copied by default. Share the link with other recipients. You can
label: BODY

text: also perform any of the following actions from the right pane:
label: BODY

text: Add People: Select Share, then enter the email addresses of the people you
label: BODY

text: want to share the file with.
label: BODY

text: Unshare File: Select Share. The profile icons of the people you have shared the
label: BODY

text: file with are displayed next to Shared with. Select the profile icon to open the
label: BODY

text: Shared with the dialog box. Select Unshare in the lower-right to stop sharing
label: BODY

text: the file with others.
label: BODY

text: Mark up text
label: H2

text: You can use markup tools to give suggestions for formatting the text, structuring a document,
label: BODY

text: or for providing other edit suggestions. Markups and comments don’t change the actual text
label: BODY

text: in the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Note: The Insert text and Replace selected text commenting tools are now available for
label: BODY

text: shared PDF files, making it easier for you to suggest changes and provide feedback directly
label: BODY

text: within the document.
label: BODY

text: Highlight, strikethrough, or underline text
label: BODY

text: comment
label: BODY

text: You can use the Select text or Markup tools to add markups to your text.
label: BODY

text: Using Select Text Tool
label: H2

text: 1.Open a PDF.
label: BODY

text: 2.Use the Select text tool to select the text you want to mark up.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the markup toolbar that appears, take one of the following actions as desired:
label: BODY

text: To highlight text, select Highlight text
label: BODY

text: To strikethrough the text, select Strikethrough text
label: BODY

text: To underline text, select Underline
label: BODY

text: To redact text, select Redact Text & Images
label: BODY

text: To copy the text, select copy with formatting
label: BODY

text: To edit the selected text, select Edit
label: BODY

text: Using Markup Tool
label: H2

text: 1.Open a PDF.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the Quick actions toolbar, select the Highlight text tool and then move the
label: BODY

text: cursor over the text that you want to highlight.
label: BODY

text: 3.With the Highlight tool selected, you can highlight multiple sections of text by just
label: BODY

text: dragging over the text. Once you’re done, deselect the tool.
label: BODY

text: 4.To add other markups, expand the Highlight tool menu and select the tool for other
label: BODY

text: markups.
label: BODY

text: Change the color of the markup
label: H2

text: Click the markup.
label: BODY

text: 2.From the mini toolbar that appears, select the color icon.
label: BODY

text: 3.From the color palette, select a desired color.
label: BODY

text: The markup appears in the selected color.
label: BODY

text: Delete The Markup
label: H2

text: To delete the markup, select the markup and then select delete
label: BODY

text: Add a comment to the markup
label: H2

text: 1.Double-click the markup.
label: BODY

text: It pops open a comment box.
label: BODY

text: 2.Alternatively, click (Control-click for macOS) on the markup and select the note icon.
label: BODY

text: It opens a comment box.
label: BODY

text: 3.Type your message in the comment box and then select Post.
label: BODY

text: Replace text
label: H2

text: 1.From the Quick actions toolbar, select Add comment
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Replace selected text.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select the text that you want to replace.
label: BODY

text: The selected text is crossed out.
label: BODY

text: 4.Double-click the selected text and then type the text to be inserted or added.
label: BODY

text: The insertion caret appears. To indicate that a new paragraph should be added,
label: BODY

text: press Enter, and then close the pop-up note without adding text. The paragraph
label: BODY

text: insertion caret appears.
label: BODY

text: Insert text
label: H2

text: 1.From the Quick actions toolbar, expand the Comments tool menu and then
label: BODY

text: select Insert text.
label: BODY

text: 2.Click between the words or characters where you want to insert text.
label: BODY

text: 3.Do any of the following:
label: BODY

text: Type the text that you want to insert.
label: BODY

text: To indicate that a new paragraph should be added, press Enter, and then close
label: BODY

text: the pop-up note without adding text. The paragraph insertion
label: BODY

text: caret appears.
label: BODY

text: To indicate that a space should be added, press the spacebar, and then close
label: BODY

text: the pop-up note without adding text. The space insertion
label: BODY

text: caret appears.
label: BODY

text: Note: You can also indicate text edits by using the Select tool to select text, right-click the
label: BODY

text: selected text, and then choose a text edit annotation.
label: BODY

text: Export text edits
label: H2

text: In Acrobat for Windows®, you can export text edits directly to the Microsoft® Word document
label: BODY

text: that the PDF is based on to revise the source document. To use this feature, you must use
label: BODY

text: PDFMaker to convert your file from Word to PDF. Before you export your text edits, make
label: BODY

text: sure that insertion comments use the exact text, including spaces and paragraph returns, that
label: BODY

text: you want to add. If you add extra instructional words (such as “Add the following:”), these
label: BODY

text: words will have to be deleted manually from the Word document.
label: BODY

text: In Acrobat on Windows®, you can export text edit comments directly to an Autodesk
label: BODY

text: AutoCAD document that the PDF is based on to incorporate your edits. To use this feature,
label: BODY

text: you must use PDFMaker in AutoCAD to create the PDF.
label: BODY

text: Share a PDF for review
label: H1

text: Use the Acrobat to easily share PDF files for review from your desktop application, the
label: BODY

text: Acrobat web, or Acrobat Reader mobile app. When reviewers click the URL in the email
label: BODY

text: invitation from their computer, they can easily provide their feedback in a browser without
label: BODY

text: having to sign in or install any additional software.
label: BODY

text: You can use the service to share PDF files for review in one of the following ways:
label: BODY

text: Send an anonymous or public link in an email
label: H2

text: An anonymous or public link makes the files accessible to anyone who clicks the link. Follow
label: BODY

text: the steps below to create a review link, and share it using your email client.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Share in the upper right. You get either of the two options:
label: BODY

text: Get link: You get this option when a file isn't synced to the cloud. Select Get
label: BODY

text: link to sync the file to the cloud. Once the file is synced, the get link option
label: BODY

text: changes to Copy link. Select Copy link and share it as desired.
label: BODY

text: Copy link: You get this option if the file is already synced to the cloud or shared
label: BODY

text: with someone.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The computer must be connected to the Internet to start a shared review in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: You can also start a shared review directly from other applications that use PDFMaker,
label: BODY

text: such as Microsoft Word. Choose Home > Create PDF and share link.
label: BODY

text: 3.By default, the People can comment switch is turned on. To share the file only for
label: BODY

text: viewing, select Anyone can access and comment in the Share dialog box, and then
label: BODY

text: switch the toggle next to People can comment to turn it off.
label: BODY

text: 4.The link is created and copied by default. Share the link with other recipients. You can
label: BODY

text: also perform any of the following actions from the right pane:
label: BODY

text: Add People: Select Share, then enter the email addresses of the people you
label: BODY

text: want to share the file with.
label: BODY

text: Unshare File: Select Share. The profile icons of the people you have shared the
label: BODY

text: file with are displayed next to Shared with. Select the profile icon to open the
label: BODY

text: Shared with the dialog box. Select Unshare in the lower-right to stop sharing
label: BODY

text: the file with others.
label: BODY

text: Reviewer experience
label: H2

text: The reviewers receive an email invitation with a link to the review PDF. When they select the
label: BODY

text: link or the Open button in the invitation, the PDF opens in a web browser. They can use the
label: BODY

text: commenting tools to add comments to the PDF. They can also use Acrobat Reader or
label: BODY

text: Acrobat desktop applications to add comments.
label: BODY

text: Send personalized invitations for commenting
label: H2

text: 1.Open the PDF in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Share.
label: BODY

text: Note:
label: BODY

text: The computer must be connected to the Internet to start a shared review in Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: You can also start a shared review directly from other applications that use PDFMaker,
label: BODY

text: such as Microsoft Word. Choose Acrobat > Create And Send For Review.
label: BODY

text: 3.Enter the email addresses of the recipients or choose from the Address Book.
label: BODY

text: 4.Enter a message to the recipients (optional).
label: BODY

text: Initiate a review using @mention in a PDF
label: H2

text: Use @mention in your personal commenting notes to start a review. The @mentions includes
label: BODY

text: your organizational contacts and your synced personal contacts list. The moment you use
label: BODY

text: @mention in a PDF file, the review mode gets enabled for you. The reviewers get an invitation
label: BODY

text: email with a link to the Document Cloud shared review file.
label: BODY

text: Reviewer experience
label: H2

text: The reviewers receive an email invitation with a link to the review PDF. When they click the
label: BODY

text: link or the Open button in the invitation, the PDF opens in a web browser. They can use the
label: BODY

text: commenting tools to add comments to the PDF. They can also use Acrobat Reader or
label: BODY

text: Acrobat desktop applications to add comments.
label: BODY

text: Hosting a shared review on SharePoint or Office 365
label: H2

text: Shared reviews are the most collaborative form of review because participants can read and
label: BODY

text: reply to the comments of other participants. Comments from participants are stored in a
label: BODY

text: repository on an internal server. Acrobat synchronizes comments at regular intervals to
label: BODY

text: download all the latest changes. Reviewers are notified of new comments as they are added,
label: BODY

text: and they can see and reply to comments made by other reviewers.
label: BODY

text: You can use your own internal server location, such as a Microsoft SharePoint
label: BODY

text: workspace/subsite, if your recipients work behind a firewall and all have access to a common
label: BODY

text: server.
label: BODY

text: Initiate SharePoint-based shared review
label: BODY

text: using Acrobat
label: BODY

text: Before you initiate a review, ensure that you have a SharePoint site and reviewers have write
label: BODY

text: permission to your site. Now, to host the shared review, you can do one of the following:
label: BODY

text: Let Acrobat automatically create and configure a document library within your SharePoint
label: BODY

text: server’s subsite.
label: BODY

text: Choose a subsite and the respective document library that you may have already created and
label: BODY

text: configured.
label: BODY

text: 1.Open the PDF document in Acrobat, and then select Send for Review in
label: BODY

text: the Tools pane.
label: BODY

text: 2.Select Send for Shared Commenting in the toolbar.
label: BODY

text: 3.Select Automatically collect comments on my own internal server from the
label: BODY

text: drop-down menu, and then click Next.
label: BODY

text: 4.Choose SharePoint subsite, and then provide the URL of your subsite on the
label: BODY

text: SharePoint server. Click Next.
label: BODY

text: Acrobat automatically creates and configures a new document library
label: BODY

text: (named AcrobatSharedReviews) within your subsite to initiate the shared review.
label: BODY

text: Note:If you don't want Acrobat to automatically configure the review, you can
label: BODY

text: click Choose a subsite to select the document library that you have already created and
label: BODY

text: configured.
label: BODY

text: 5.Choose distribution method and the way the file should appear when it’s sent, and
label: BODY

text: then click Next.
label: BODY

text: 6.To save this shared review profile for future use, provide a name and then
label: BODY

text: click Next, or click Next to use the default.
label: BODY
